name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the State of the Energy Union (2017/2523 (RSP)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, once again I would like to thank you for the invitation and for the opportunity to present to you the Second State of the Energy Union Report, only a few hours after it was adopted this morning by the College. As you may remember, Parliament was one of my first stops in presenting the first report as well, and this is no coincidence. It reflects the importance I see in working very closely with you, the European Parliament, in co-piloting the Energy Union. Only through close partnership can we ensure that the legislative proposals of the November package will be adopted over the next nine months.  This is the objective I presented last week in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), in line with the December Declaration of our three institutions. A quick adoption is important so that our proposals can be swiftly transposed by the Member States and put into action. It would also send an important message to EU citizens that, when it comes to the Energy Union, we mean business. ‘We’ being all EU institutions. While negotiations on the legislative proposals are ongoing, my colleagues and I are not sitting and waiting. To the greatest extent possible, the Commission will already start the implementation of the Energy Union on the ground. This is one of the key messages of the second State of the Energy Union: while 2016 was a ‘year of delivery’, 2017 will be a ‘year of implementation’. What does that mean in practice? It means that, apart from the upcoming legislation on the low-emission mobility, we have delivered on all Energy Union proposals, and we are now ready for the next phase. The second State of the Energy Union serves exactly for that next phase. It give us a good overview of where we stand and what has been achieved both at EU and national levels. Our thorough analysis shows that the European Union is largely on track. For instance, among major global economies, Europe is one of the most greenhouse gas efficient. This creates significant ‘first-mover opportunities’ for European companies. But we are in no way in a position to rest on our laurels. Other parts of the world are also speeding up their efforts; they are also modernising their economies, and they are also increasing their competitiveness. There is no room for complacency if we want to remain global leaders in areas such as clean technologies.  The State of the Energy Union Report therefore also looks forward and identifies the work that still has to be done; it sets the political priorities for this year. In line with the Energy Union Strategy, these priorities go far beyond energy and climate alone. The Energy Union is about accelerating the modernisation of our entire economy: making it low-carbon; making it efficient in the use of energy and resources; making sure our economy is socially fair and consumer-oriented; and strengthening the Energy Union’s external dimension. In the current, ever-changing and volatile geopolitical context, we need European global leadership. This is true in the field of climate action but also for safeguarding our competitiveness, jobs and economic interests. Such an over-arching approach implies strengthening the ties between the Energy Union Project and other European flagship policies, such as the circular economy, the Digital Single Market, the Security Union, our Skills Agenda, the EU’s economy and climate diplomacy, our investment policies, and so on. What does it mean in practice? Simply put, when we look at the modernisation of our economy, we will also need to look at: the huge job potential of the green economy; the heavy economic costs of air pollution; the threats of cyber-attacks, and many other areas. It means we must make sure that each and every new measure benefits consumers, especially the vulnerable ones. It means that we will make real progress this year on providing the missing infrastructure links. We will look deeper into how we can avoid stranded assets, for example when preparing the next list of Projects of Common Interest. It means that we must step up even further our investment policies, and for this purpose we will set up investment platforms on the ground in all Member States. It also means that we will make Europe’s global leadership more concrete by helping the developing world, Africa in particular, jump over the fossil age. These are just a few examples to give you the gist of the report. As you can see, a lot remains to be done. With the State of the Energy Union, I am also launching a second Energy Union Tour. I will once again visit the Member States, and I hereby invite you to join me when I visit your constituencies. Even in the event that you cannot join me in person, I encourage you to help me bring the message of the Energy Union to your electorates. Help me convey the urgency of the energy transition, and the opportunities it brings to our citizens. As I have mentioned earlier, we intend to make 2017 the Energy Union’s ‘year of implementation’. I will therefore use this tour to campaign and push for the swift implementation of the Energy Union not only at national level, but also at local level, which is becoming increasingly important. I will discuss, with government representatives, the importance of presenting their National Energy and Climate Plans. We will together ensure that drafts will be presented by the end of 2017. I will also emphasise the need for a broad consultation of the plans not only within the Member States with all relevant stakeholders, but also with the neighbouring Member States on a regional level. At the local level, my tour will be a good opportunity to showcase some of the most promising and innovative projects of cities and regions. It is important that we provide such projects with a strong tail-wind and match them with financing. I am glad to share with you that we are actively working on that, in cooperation with the Committee of the Regions. Showing concrete progress on the ground will help our citizens to visualise and grasp the multiple benefits of the clean energy transition. Distinguished Members, let me once again thank you for your support in realising our joint ambition. I will stop here, as I would like to listen to the comments and suggestions of the honourable Members on today’s report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. If we think for a moment, our energy policy has had one main goal for the last 10-15 years. And it has been fighting climate change by reducing CO2 emissions. All energy policy has, in fact, been subordinate to this goal. And I'm not saying that that goal was wrong. But now what the European Commission has proposed - this package of eight bills - introduces what I think is a long-needed addition to this goal. In other words, we need to start thinking not only about climate change, but also about the competitiveness of our citizens and businesses and the price of energy. And the way we can simultaneously stick to our climate change goals and reduce prices for consumers, especially for our industry, is by introducing a very basic principle that works completely everywhere in the economy: competition. By releasing market barriers, we will send the right signals to create more competition for or between energy producers in the Member States. We need to remove restrictions, both physical and regulatory, for this competition to exist. Competition is not possible in a situation where there are still large subsidies for both fossil fuels and renewable energy. So, at the same time, we will have to look at how we can sensibly reduce market-distorting subsidies for all players, for all sectors, by promoting competition, while, of course, adhering to our climate goals, but thinking about lowering prices for citizens and businesses to become more competitive.

name: Dan NICA
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President Šefčovič, thank you for your work in making the energy union a priority European project and for delivering the winter energy package together with your colleagues in the Commission. The European Union still imports more than half of its energy needs, but progress is being made to diversify resources, routes and energy suppliers. The better our energy efficiency, the less dependent we will be on external energy suppliers. Energy efficiency will allow us to invest more in job creation and innovation. The money should be better spent on sustainable energy production, increasing energy efficiency and upgrading energy networks, and ensuring clean and affordable energy for industry and European citizens. I emphasize the importance of electricity interconnections and the strengthening of internal lines in order to further integrate the internal market in electricity. We need to facilitate cross-border flows of electricity across the Union, while ensuring the security of the system. With regard to renewables, according to Commission estimates, 25 Member States have already exceeded their 2015/2016 indicative targets in 2015. So we need to see how we can stimulate investment in renewable energy. Also, a wider introduction of renewable sources in the energy system will need important changes in the design of the electricity market. In debating the state of the energy union, we must also focus on future measures. Therefore, the current energy package must be an opportunity to launch the transition of our industrial base. We will be able to use up to € 177 billion in public and private investment in 2021. With the implementation of policies 900,000 jobs can be created in the European Union.You can count on the support of our political group, Mr Vice-President Šefčovič, and we will strengthen the provisions of this very important energy package.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! I would just like to remind you that clean energy is, of course, a very important one of the most important goals of the Energy Union, while there is another goal that we should not lose sight of, namely energy security. This is a goal much more elementary for some, so it is often the case that we want energy first, then we wonder if it is pure energy and energy that we are willing to pay for. The basis of energy security (already mentioned by a colleague) is the diversification of supplies. On the other hand, if we look at statistical data, we can see that the situation is not improving, because according to statistics, the dependence of the Union on the import of energy resources increased from 52% in 2010 to almost 56% in 2015 and it seems, as indicated by the forecasts that it will increase to 60%, so with such a high dependence on external energy supplies, diversification is of paramount importance for Europe's energy security and should be the backbone of the Energy Union. And above all, there is the issue of new gas sources and independence from the dominant supplier from the East, but in this matter we receive both positive and very worrying signals from the Commission. For example, the strategy of greater use of liquefied natural gas and the prospects for The Northern Gate, which will allow the transmission of gas from Norway via Denmark to Poland and other countries of the continent. On the other hand, projects to launch capacity from the East, such as NordStream2 or the decision on the OPAL gas pipeline, are in clear contradiction to the principles of energy security and are completely incomprehensible to many Europeans, and undermine confidence in the European Commission. This also applies to the issue of capacity markets - this proposal is also controversial, because in principle it will make the EU dependent on gas imports. I would ask you to reflect on these two points, because it is extremely important for many countries and citizens of the European Union.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: for the ALDE Group. - Mr President! This is perhaps one of the most important things we will do during this term of office when we draw up the forthcoming energy union. As several colleagues have said, it is important for us to be competitive, that we should be able to keep good prices both for private consumers and for industry, that we should be able to ensure that we are a progressive part also when it comes to renewables, and not least energy security. So that in a world that is becoming increasingly anxious, we know that we can manage our energy supply to private individuals and to industry. I myself will have the privilege of working on the renewable energy component, and I have noted today that the Commission's report on renewable energy has been released, which shows that we are already well on track to reach the 20% renewable energy target is set for the year 2020. It is gratifying. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the "blue card" procedure.- Mr President, dear colleague, you said, among other things, that 29% - the percentage proposed for 2030 compared to 2012 - could be more ambitious in terms of renewable energy.On the other hand, you said that the report shows that we do not have enough resources to support renewable energy, and on the other hand, I want to ask you: do you think it is right for the cost of green certificates to be borne by the population?

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: answer (“blue card”).- Mr President!Of course, there are several things we can do.I am market-based as a liberal.This makes me believe in a common energy market where we have pricing driven by the market.I can recommend my colleagues to take a closer look at the Nord Pool area.For example, when colleagues from Estonia became full members of Nord Pool's energy market, costs for private individuals have been reduced, security has been increased and costs for industry have been reduced.This has also created increased demand, which means that investments will increase in the future.I do not think that it is primarily with political instruments that we do it, but by creating a common market and having political goals, we can achieve this without too many subsidies that actually harm the market where we are.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are constantly discussing the state of the energy union and we are finding more and more problems each time. It has been two years since the creation of the energy union was announced. In the meantime, all that has been done is to promote policies to serve the needs of the competitive market, to promote the interests of multinationals, and to increase the powers of the Commission to the detriment of the sovereign rights of states. No substantial action has been taken on the Union's serious problems with energy supply, lack of energy security and energy isolation in the Union states and territories. No action has been taken on the energy poverty plaguing peoples. As long as there are people in the Union who are deprived of the right to equal and cheap access to energy, a public development good, this will mean that the energy union has failed. If we want to fight energy poverty, we must end neoliberal austerity policies and, with a comprehensive plan, actively support millions of our fellow citizens. If our ambition to lead the Union in the development of renewable energy sources is sincere, then the priority of their entry into the grids must be ensured and a comprehensive proposal for their promotion must be submitted. Here, of course, I must say that I welcome the statement made today in the Commission communication, namely that the gas fields in the eastern Mediterranean are very promising for the Union's supply, but I must also stress that, if the goal set for promotion of domestic energy sources, then we must see in practice the support of development efforts for deposits in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the energy union is much more than a framework strategy for secure, affordable and climate—friendly energy. Sixty years ago, cooperation in the field of energy in Europe led to the European Union. Today, the energy union is a unique opportunity for us Europeans to strengthen and reinforce this cooperation in troubled times. For a well—functioning energy union, we clearly need a high level of investment and cooperation among the Member States – and not primarily, in terms of gas and electricity, for infrastructure, but also for upscaling renewables and increasing energy efficiency efforts and exploiting the clear synergies between these aspects. The Commission again confirms in its report the determination of the Commission to make the European Union the world number one in renewables, but the legislative proposals of the winter package do not live up to the promises; rather they put brakes on the energy transition and simply do not address key problems and market distortions. There is no real incentive to cut fossil fuel consumption. It allows subsidies to fossil fuel and also keeps the privileges of nuclear energy. Loopholes in the Energy Efficiency Directive are left unaddressed as well. According to the report, there was a very modest 0.4% growth in the share of renewables in the EU’s total energy use last year.  Clearly we must accelerate our efforts. The proposal still does not contain proper incentives for further deployment of renewables. Instead it undermines market access for renewable energy sources. While regulated household energy prices in about half of the EU are – rightly – identified as a problem, there are no effective proposals for dealing with energy poverty, instead of those distorting measures. I also see a lack of proper support for prosumers, such as energy cooperatives, to compete fairly in the market. The problem of energy dependency is also well addressed in the report, but the importance of energy efficiency in fighting against it is underestimated. Finally, one issue remains almost untouched – the poor enforcement of the existing legislation affecting the energy market. This also implies that the Commission must make sure that nuclear installations are not exempted from public procurement provisions or competition law, which currently is not the case. Despite the report stating that we are well on track, I believe that a lot more needs to be done in order to achieve a unified energy market and a sustainable, secure energy system.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Dear Mr. PRESIDENT!With regard to a quick agreement, I would like to assure the honorable Member that I really consider the steps taken in the field of energy efficiency to be very important - if only because this is indeed one of the best ways of combating energy poverty.However, I would also have a quick question, two.One is that the measures and legislation taken at European level here - perhaps everyone here will pass them - and then, behind them, the governments behind the backs of the Members will whistle about it all.Do you see any perspective on how to persuade governments, member states, to negotiate, at least on the energy mix?Or the second, how can governments be curbed to back-and-forth, shape consumer prices in certain places?

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Blue card answer.- Thanks for asking!Mr Szanyi asked about very important issues.On the one hand, the implementation and enforcement of existing energy regulations in the Member States is a key issue.And in this, I think that the Commission is not using all the means at its disposal to actually implement the provisions not only on energy efficiency, but also on renewable energy sources, competition law in the energy market, public procurement law.Here are the tasks for the European Commission.With regard to price distortions, both the draft Energy Union and the winter package state quite clearly that these price-distorting provisions must be introduced.However, these need to be replaced by measures that can effectively curb energy poverty.This is a primary task for both the Member States and the European Commission.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very happy to see in the so-called winter package numerous proposals for prosumers and the energy communities. It is certainly a step forward, and I welcome and congratulate the Commissioner, but at the same time there are steps backwards, in our view, which could instead undo any progress towards the climate and energy objectives that Union aims. We realize that it is not easy to manage a situation where such conflicting interests are sometimes focused on a single person, such as the Commissioner, and therefore I am in solidarity with you. However, I believe that it is simply scandalous to have eliminated the dispatching priority for renewable. It is true that green technologies are more mature and cheaper than a few years ago, but until the externalities of fossils are computed and with the capacity mechanisms still contemplated at least until 2026, as it would seem, talk about the same competitiveness with other technologies, of technological neutrality, in my opinion - to use a term that is fashionable - is fake news. I therefore return to underline the distortion of the market induced by the 300 billion in direct and indirect subsidies - the source is the International Monetary Fund - which in Europe end up feeding the fossil energy economy. When it comes to technology neutrality, the free market forgets this huge elephant in the room that is periodically ignored. This is without considering the climatic and geopolitical benefits of the renewable transition. We know that there are reliable studies - I can give them to you, but you will know them - which estimate the potential of decentralized energy production by citizens at European level with impressive data: in 2030, 112 million prosumers, including schools, local communities and hospitals, would have the potential, alone, to respond to 19% energy demand in the European Union;in 2050 this response would reach 45% with half of the citizens involved.In the newly adopted state of the Union, mention is made of financing mechanisms, and here I come with a proposal: there is no regulatory framework for crowdfunding, cross-border crowdfunding and crowdfunding for numerative investments.So I urge the Commissioner to consider such a proposal, to provide a legal framework because in this case we could stimulate the private investment of individuals and communities that we so much need.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mister President! Commissioner Šefčovič, I would like to congratulate you on your Energy Union initiative, because I believe that you are making a major contribution to bringing the goals of the Energy Union closer to the Member States of the European Union and also to European citizens. The goals of the Energy Union are important, namely increasing security of supply, sustainability and the competitiveness of the Member States, moving towards a resource-efficient economy, decentralized models and modern generation technology - as you said: modernizing the economy with new ones Investment platforms contribute. Perhaps one could also take up what Mr Tamburrano said. You have now proposed a EUR 10 billion modernization fund as part of the new winter package. I believe that it is very important to also achieve the ambitious goals of the winter package, namely to make Europe the world leader in renewable energy, to increase energy efficiency by 30% and to focus on the consumer so that the consumer can benefit from lower prices can. Let me just mention the eco-market design and the enormous investment potential for companies as an example. I think this is a good thing and you, Commissioner, are a good promoter of it.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Televisions were invented once, then the color ones.The rich had colored and the poor had not, but there was no tax to make poor people buy these televisions.Thanks to this, after a few years, all the poor also had a color television.If taxes were imposed to buy everyone color televisions, they wouldn't have them at all, or they would have them at the level of Soviet products.It's the same with energy.Rich countries can have fantasy and fight for the environment, and poor countries must be allowed to do as they wish.When they get rich, then they will be able to fight for the environment.Just Poland needs coal-based energy: cheaper.I want to point out that at this point, Europe is already an open-air museum in comparison with China.America is about to shoot forward and we will also be an open-air museum compared to the United States, which is ending the fight against global warming.Please kindly take this into account.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: - Mr Chairman! I congratulate the European Commission on delivering almost all legislative solutions to the European Parliament - we are working on them. The energy union is becoming a fact, although we still need to implement it, and above all, we must have constant contact with citizens so that they feel how important it is for them, because it does not reach everywhere. It is indeed an energy union, a union of citizens who can feel safe and at the same time have cheaper energy. We know all this, but the citizens do not know so precisely, and this is one of the factors of our integration. I would like to ask the Commissioner, what impact will the recent statements by the President of the United States have on our energy policy and also on the energy union? They are important to us, because first of all, in my opinion, they threaten the implementation of the Paris Agreement - and yet we agreed that all the largest issuers (we are not as big an issuer as the United States) will apply these rules - which results in specific conclusions and specific questions for us. For example, we have agreed that Member States will not have binding targets for energy savings or renewable energy - does anything change in this regard? We also have proposals from the Energy Union to reduce emissions from electricity production, and that applies to fossil fuels. The United States is going in a completely different direction, and such restrictions could eliminate some fuels and make energy more expensive. This directly reduces the competitiveness of our industry in many countries. And another issue, perhaps very specific - we asked the European Commission a very important question: are there already known legal bases against which the legality of the construction of NordStream2 could be assessed? I would like an answer to these questions.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: - Commissioner, let me start by thanking you for all the proposals out there. I have done that before, but I do it with a lot of conviction. You have worked hard on this together with your colleagues, but you are doing it in a transparent, open way, together with Parliament and with the stakeholders, and our group greatly appreciates that. We had a debate before on the entry ban for Muslims in the United States and I found the replies of the group chairmen very similar on one point. More than ever we are going to have a European Union that stands there, that offers a solution in self-confidence, the other Vice-President of the Commission, Ms Mogherini. And that is what we have to do in this dossier, because don't forget that there is also a negative wind on the other side of the ocean when it comes to climate and energy, so we need our own, self-assured policy. We must go for that with determination, and this group will support, but also further strengthen, all the proposals you make. You know our ambitions to set higher targets in the field of energy efficiency and renewable energy, targets that also have binding effect. That has worked in the past. Why shouldn't that be the case in the future? And finally, something we often forget, but the Commissioner knows that: governance. You need very good and strong European-driven governance and on that point too, we will be submitting reinforced proposals together with the other political groups.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, this communication is very welcome, given the urgency around the need to mitigate the negative effects of climate change. Within the scope of the Energy Union Framework Strategy, I particularly welcome the increased focus on clean energy, rather than solely green energy. This is key. While the need for radical reductions in carbon are clear and well known, there are other notable pollutants such as NOx and PM which also have hugely detrimental effects on both human health and the environment, and these need to be addressed.  The Commission communication does mention health. I welcome the reference to the new NEC Directive and the reiteration – albeit only in a footnote – that in 2013 more than 450 000 people are estimated to have died prematurely from air pollution in the EU, and lost days at work caused by respiratory disease amount to a EUR 15 billion loss to the EU economy.  It is becoming ever more evident that the transition to clean – and not just green – transport must be given priority. I would like to see a clear preference given to investment in projects that combine the two objectives of lowering greenhouse gas emissions, and lowering other pollutants. This should include incentives at the level of the citizen. It is no coincidence that people experiencing fuel poverty are often also those who experience the worst possible health outcomes. The transition to clean energy is already having a profound effect on the global energy market, and there are clear indications that clean energy is delivering record levels of investment, particularly in renewables and other new technologies. Let us make sure that we harness this momentum to create record—breaking levels of health improvement also.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! I would like to start by thanking Vice-President Šefčovič for all the hard work he does to bring the Energy Union to life. It is really much needed! This status of the energy union, which we are discussing today, shows with all the desired clarity that action is needed. Action if the EU and Europe are to take on global leadership in climate, renewable energy and energy efficiency. And action if we are to meet the objectives of the energy union and strengthen the green transition. It requires ambitious goals, courage, and it requires action! Because we can see from the report here today that there are actually countries that are becoming more dependent on imports of energy from outside. And we can see from the report that the European transmission networks are not well equipped to handle this integration of renewable energy, which is absolutely crucial. And we can see that if we put energy efficiency the highest, then we can make significant progress, not least through renovating buildings. These are initiatives that reduce energy costs for European citizens, initiatives that simultaneously improve the indoor climate and create healthy buildings, all at the same time as creating local jobs, ie for the benefit of us all. It requires that we also find ways to free up private funding so that private funds can come into play. I welcome this report, I look forward to working with you. We have a lot of things we need to do here in the next period if we are to take on global leadership.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it has been two years since the Commission introduced the Energy Union with great pomp. From the beginning, I was very skeptical about fulfilling the great visions in the document. And the reality confirms my doubts - the electricity networks that we urgently need are not being built in any way, and apparently no common backbone infrastructure is planned. The electricity market is still dysfunctional, the joint purchase of natural gas is not working, so I could continue. On the other hand, in the area of ​​legislation, we are overwhelmed by thousands of pages of the new winter energy package. It seems that the aim of the European Energy Union is just to create stacks of paper. And to the very discussion of documents related to the Energy Union. In my opinion, documents such as ETS, ESR, LULUCF should be discussed together with the current winter energy package, as they are closely linked. At the same time, negotiations in the Council are failing, and the Commission seems to be planning to discuss the governance of the Energy Union first, which I think needs to be discussed last. What interests me eminently is that the citizens of the European Union have money to pay for energy, and that is not addressed at all, only that sometimes someone mentions that something like that exists and that it is simply a problem. I think we should move from paper to practical action, that would be more positive.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: – Mr President, we are in the midst of an energy revolution. Renewables are growing like never before and costs are falling rapidly. Now we have to seize the moment. I am, however, worried that the winter package proposed by the Commission is a missed opportunity if we want to unleash the full potential of the green transition. If we do not act now, we will not only fail in meeting our climate obligations, we will also miss out in reaping the rewards of being leaders of green innovation. We need to create a climate that attracts scientists from all over the world who want to come here and create breakthrough technologies, and we need to support the shift to new products and clean tech start-ups. Therefore, I call on my colleagues to stop protecting the old and start embracing the new. Only then will Europe be the true global leader in the green transition.

name: Roger HELMER
text: – Mr President, the main element of the Commission’s current proposal is the revision of the ETS system. You recognised the problem that you call carbon leakage. I call it driving energy-intensive businesses offshore, and you have decided to give these industries free allowances to redress the balance, but you have created your own catch—22: if you give them enough allowances to stay competitive you have no hope of achieving emissions targets, but to achieve your emissions targets you cannot give them enough allowances. You face a stark choice between competitiveness and emissions targets. You cannot have both. You are not cutting emissions; you are merely driving them offshore. You have also created a structure which involves perpetual market intervention and distortion and creates a field day for lobbyists and lawyers, as industries fight each other for an ever-decreasing pot of free allowances.  The proposal to offer a tiered structure for different industry sectors only exacerbates the problem, and the use of the top 10% as a standard implies that 90% of European industries will be at a competitive disadvantage anyway. We face competition from China with massive cheap coal-fired generation, and from the US where Donald Trump promises to make low-cost energy a main driver of the US economy. A few years ago, our new President, Mr Tajani, said that our energy policies were creating ‘an industrial massacre in Europe’. Today’s proposals are the final coup de grâce.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, we need energy. We need it to heat our homes, to provide the businesses that create our food, and we even need it for this Chamber. But energy has a cost. The EU wants a low—carbon secure and competitive economy; they have created this framework strategy for a resilient Europe with a forward—looking climate change policy. This sounds positive, optimistic, an energy utopia – but it is not the reality people will live in, is it? EU policy will control the sources, flow, distribution, delivery and billing of the whole of the European energy industry. It will suppress national governments’ abilities to provide the best energy services and prices for their people. In truth, once again, it is a classical big government power grab. Infrastructure will be paid for by the taxpayer, corporate subsidies will be paid for by the taxpayer, and higher bills will be paid for by the taxpayer, while all profits will be distributed between the EU and global corporations. The user is always the loser in the EU.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: -  Sir. Chairman! Thanks to Vice-President and Commissioner Šefčovič for the statement. I agree with the Commissioner that we are well on our way, however, I have already heard a number of political statements and regrets today, which ultimately stem from the fact that the Member State in question has left its citizens in the lurch when it comes to energy policy in years. With the winter package, we therefore have a good starting point, and we now have the opportunity here in Parliament to improve both the text and the content of the package. It is clear that there are a number of challenges. We must reduce dependence on our imports from Putin's Russia and from the Middle East. We must create a single market for energy in Europe, and we must make better use of the energy we now have in Europe. There are plenty of opportunities in the directives that now exist regarding energy efficiency, renewable energy, electricity market design, governance, etc. As rapporteur for energy efficiency in buildings, I can already see that there are plenty of opportunities. One of the nuts we need to have cracked in that directive is to have private funds released for energy renovations. We know that they are only new buildings that make up one and a half percent of the building stock per year. The remaining old building stock in Europe is inefficient, expensive and poor. That is why there is a real need to trigger some private pension funds in Europe.

In all, the President of the European Parliament, the President of the Republic of Latvia and the Democrats and the Democrats, have the ambition of the ambassador.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: - Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I consider the winter energy package to be the most crucial material recently tabled. It is very important that the resulting legislation is reasonable and contains technically achievable objectives. It is therefore necessary to approach all 8 legislative proposals very carefully and not only in terms of great ambitions to make changes at all costs. Energy infrastructure has been in place in the EU for 150 years and is an essential part of everyone's life. Everyone needs to shine and heat at affordable market prices, so it is not possible to jeopardize the functioning of the energy system in any way. I am glad that the Commission is making such an effort with the Energy Union. The European Union needs efficient energy. I believe that if we embark on the path of modern technologies with an emphasis on safety, we can really improve the whole energy system. However, it is not possible for us to change this system only from above without supporting the competitive environment, which is the biggest engine of new technologies.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Mr President, three energy packages later we are still trying to achieve one important objective: make the Energy Single Market work for businesses, for consumers and for our environmental goals. Three packages later, the electricity market is still the fourth—lowest ranked service according to the Consumer Scoreboard. It shows one thing quite clearly: that protecting national energy production and sticking to rigid centralised systems is not the right answer. Therefore, one key objective for all of us in building the Energy Union should be to bring the European energy market up to speed with the 21st century by bringing technology and utilities together. But let us take smart meters, for instance, where, eight years after the Third Energy Package, some countries are still discussing whether the deployment of smart meters is relevant or not. In the meantime, some countries are already talking about advanced smart meters that provide real-time data instead of near real-time data, enabling real-time data flows and data-sharing within the energy markets, with this being absolutely essential to build competitive and innovative energy markets for tomorrow. Therefore, we should discuss whether smart meters should be made mandatory so that all consumers have real-time data and real-time control over their energy consumption.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: - Mister President! Europe is well on the way to achieving its environmental goals. We are climate champions when it comes to CO2, renewables and savings. But we are also world champions when it comes to energy costs for small businesses and private households, especially in lagging regions. We are world champions in the bureaucratic burden for industry. It is therefore good that the Commission has this time analyzed the consequences of the legislation more closely, avoiding overlapping legislation, more precisely, but not yet sufficiently. I don't think that a binding savings target of 30% makes sense for all countries and for all industries. Because this saving target also applies to green energy. If we want green energies in cars and buildings, we cannot at the same time prevent this structural change through the need to save renewable energies. But that's not all, unfortunately. We as parliament - i.e. the left, the liberals - want 40% less energy consumption. 40%, although the Commission's Impact Assessment says it would thwart the ETS system. We would have to intervene again, take certificates off the market, the industry would again be unsettled and disappointed in Europe. So let's remain ambitious when it comes to saving energy, but please don't overdo it, because otherwise we will sell Europe's industry. We are against planned economy constraints on savings that are designed to last for decades. We are for energy legislation that breathes, for moderate energy savings in line with incentives and markets.

name: Martina WERNER
text: - Mister President! First of all, I would like to thank you for the good suggestions on the “Clean Energy” package. And now the ball is here with us in the field and of course with the council. We will now work at full speed to set the right course for a European energy union in this legislative period. The Commission has put forward good and, above all, binding proposals for the Energy Efficiency Directive and renewable energy sources. This is an important first step. But here, too, I say very clearly: Courage to be more ambitious. Regarding energy efficiency, the Commission is unfortunately only proposing “business as usual”, although the goals for 2020 have already been achieved and there is still great potential. We Social Democrats are therefore calling for a 40% energy efficiency target at EU level and binding national targets. Binding national targets are vital as they ensure that all Member States do their homework. And the same applies to renewable energy sources: Courage to be more ambitious. And here, too, we will pursue a 40% target, including binding national targets.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, solidarity, as provided for in the Lisbon Treaty, should be a founding principle of the Energy Union. The construction of Nord Stream 2 and decisions about the Opal pipeline undermine this principle, making the countries of my region, in particular Ukraine, less resilient to Russian energy blackmail. Both projects also increase the European Union’s dependence on one source of energy supplies. This should be considered by the Commission.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Vice-President of the Commission for his presentation. You mentioned, Mr Šefčovič, that for you, 2017 means implementation and it means real business, and you can certainly prove that very easily because, as you know, there is one project that is in conflict with the whole idea of the European Energy Union and in conflict with its aims, and that is Nord Stream 2. It is increasing dependence on Russia and increasing dependence on gas. It is distorting competition and it is changing the architecture of the European energy markets. It will be a means for Gazprom to assume an even more dominant market position and it is also in conflict with the rules in the third Energy Market Package about unbundling. So, if you want to make the project of Energy Union credible and stable, you need to act. You need to stand up for the legislation that we have and the aims we have, and take a clear view and clear action. It is very easy to prove that you mean business with Energy Union. Please do that.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: - Mr President, I consider the winter package to be an important step in setting up a new energy framework in Europe. As Commissioner Šefčovič said, this is the biggest reform of European energy since the introduction of centralized systems. I consider the proposals contained in it to respond correctly to the changing nature of the European energy sector and to the new requirements of market organization. However, I see some shortcomings in this package. Above all, this is the Energy Efficiency Directive, which does not reflect much on what Parliament has pointed out in recent years. For example, Article 7, which I consider to be insufficient in the form presented, which still allows for loopholes and exceptions that have been adopted in the past. Similarly, I would like to see a much larger share of low-carbon resources in the energy mix, and all this will be emphasized by our factions when discussing this package.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: –We already had an interesting exchange of views in the ITRE committee last week on how to approach the Energy Union. I would like to emphasize three points here today. The first point is that we must take into account the affordability of the proposals that are put on the table. For my country alone, for example, there is a bill of EUR 4.38 billion waiting to adapt our energy system to the new targets by 2030, and even then the costs for efficiency are not taken into account. Secondly, it is also important to make it attractive to invest in energy efficiency. To this end, it should be possible to adjust Eurostat's accounting rules to possibly spread the investments for energy efficiency over different financial years. A third element is what the Commission calls smart financing, namely that financial institutions must also be involved in order to make investing more financially attractive.

name: Herbert REUL
text: -  Mister President! We talk about it all the time: Europe. We have to make sure that the Europeans have approval for the European project. We are constantly making sure that Europe is strong. Then we would actually have to make sure that Europe is economically strong, because that is the important prerequisite. It is therefore dangerous if the entire energy policy is based solely on climate policy considerations. You also have to have the factor under control: What burdens and costs does this entail, what effects does it have on citizens, consumers and the economy? I miss that. Then it is not the time to make a new plan every day or to announce higher percentages. We already had that at Lisbon: higher, further, better, being the very best. It's much smarter to take small steps and demonstrate success. Action is not needed, not plans. I am firmly convinced of that. There are some interesting things in this mountain of paper that we have before us. The first is: I think it is wise that we are moving away from this subsidy patchwork of renewables, but rather have the requirement to organize this through tenders and to approach it in a market-based manner. I think this is a smart contribution that can save a lot of costs. On the other hand, however, it is not at all intelligent to inflate this ACER - i.e. the attempt to improve the pipeline networks and the monitoring of the pipeline networks by making a European authority even bigger, more effective, even more effective, even more heavily. That is not the correct answer. It works! We don't have a problem at the moment that it doesn't work with the line network operators. What is missing is what the colleague just said: that there are not enough lines. This is not a problem of surveillance and new authorities or organizations, but of investment. And Investments are only made if those who operate the networks can also earn money with them.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Mr President, energy is key to the cohesion of the Union. The current political uncertainty outside Europe should serve as a catalyst to strengthen our energy union project. I think it is crucial to move towards a new model, to improve the objectives to meet our commitments, to maintain the European leadership in renewables. For this reason, the Commission proposal remains scarce and a more ambitious proposal for renewables must be made and, of course, maintaining the binding targets of the Member States. We have to move towards the energy independence of Europe. We need to provide Europe with safe, affordable and environmentally friendly energy and we have to increase transparency: price transparency to avoid situations such as the striking increases that have occurred, for example, in my country, Spain, during the past week. It is an opportunity for economic modernization and for the creation of quality employment that also takes into account citizens in vulnerable situations. You have to give an answer of ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the recast of the Renewable Energy Directive is a key part of the Clean Energy package. I am delighted that I will have the chance to work on the proposals that will shape European renewable energy policy for the decade to come and will decide whether we will achieve our goal of remaining the world leader in renewable energy technologies. I have been asked on numerous occasions in the past week what my priorities for the Renewable Energy Directive are. The answer is very short: investor certainty. Ensuring the climate is right to attract investment into the European renewable energy sector is the key challenge we face in the recast of this directive. It will be important that we put in place an ambitious, but achievable and stable, legislative framework. This is something that we have failed to do in recent years, the biofuels area being a case in point. In Europe we are often great at patting ourselves on the back in terms of decarbonisation efforts, but the reality is that the rest of the world is waking up to the potential of clean energy sources at a time when our investment is falling due to policy uncertainty. Europe’s share of global investment in renewable energy has reduced from 50% in 2005 to 20% in 2014. European investment in renewable energy dropped by around 20% between 2014 and 2015 for the good reason that the rest of the world sees the benefits of renewable energy. Costs are coming down, but there is a great opportunity for us here and we must grasp it. It is not just about saving the planet: it is about economic benefits and job creation. We must support it with legislation.

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: – Mr President, I believe that reaching a 27% EU common target for renewables without setting national targets is not possible. One of the reasons for the success of the EU, and why the EU became a global leader for renewables, was our 20-20-20 programme with targets for each Member State. I do not believe in systems in which everybody is responsible for everything. Mr Šefčovič, if you want to fly with your – or our – Airbus 380 energy package, you must distribute as a good manager responsibilities to every member of the crew – responsibilities with higher priority than flexibility in each Member State. That is why I want to ask you, Mr Šefčovič, to initiate a revision of the European Council decision not to set national targets which was taken in October 2014. I hope that after the change of that decision I can wish you a safe flight with that Airbus 380 energy package.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to thank the Commission for putting energy and climate protection in the Energy Union at the forefront of today's communication. We still need priority for climate protection, even after the election of Donald Trump, when times are getting a little tougher. But there are very clear signals from the international partners that we are continuing with the agenda after Paris. A few years ago, I would not have thought that China, for example, would commit itself to continue, even if there is some uncertainty in the US. However, we must not achieve our climate protection goals in such a way that we drive industry out of Europe. In two weeks' time in Strasbourg we will have a difficult discussion ahead of the vote on emissions trading, and I believe we need a good compromise solution. That means that everyone has to do their part. That is why I attach so much importance to the proposal you made in November on the subject of energy efficiency. If we take an important step in the building sector, for example, then we do not need to burden industry unduly. And traffic must also make its contribution. Here we are still waiting for a suggestion. I hope he's coming very soon, I even hear that this Friday this week. We must continue to include aviation in emissions trading because the things that have been discussed at international level are not yet sufficiently clear and ambitious. In order to treat the other industry fairly, too, we should not let aviation get away with obligations.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we all appreciate this package, which is certainly one of the EU's most integrated and decisive strategies, because several elements are at stake. The productivity of our industrial manufacturing system is at stake, the environment is at stake, the health of citizens is also at stake - I think these days in how many cities in Europe are suffering from negative air quality, even in Europe. highly developed cities, in highly developed regions, in advanced countries, and also for finances, for the costs of bills for both businesses and citizens. But if we really want to make a green revolution, we need to raise the bar of ambitions a little. We say this from a group that is very convinced of this, which hopes to have a large majority in Parliament, and we say it to you, who are sensitive to these issues. Raising the bar of ambitions, for example, means having higher targets on renewables. We are well advanced with those of 2020, but we look further, also for the certainty of the industries, and we make Europe an advanced point, also for the related European industry. It is also necessary to strengthen the elements of quality and novelty. I am thinking of consumers and all the possibilities of distributed energy. It's not a niche, it can really become ... (interrupted by the President).

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome Mr Šefčovič’s work on this Energy Union, and it is one of the challenges we are facing in the Union. It is encouraging that the growth of the EU economy is starting to decouple from CO2 emissions, so economic growth is possible without increasing emissions. It is clear from the State of the Union speech that we heard, and which we saw in the papers, that more investment is needed, especially in electric transmission lines across the borders, to really create the reaches because with better functioning reaches we have better functioning energy markets. Despite all the efforts we have made in the EU and the Member States, renewable energy sources still constitute only 16.4% of the EU’s final energy consumption. From these figures, I also think that we have to see that the EU cannot rule out any sort of renewable energy sources, not even biomass, but we have to guarantee they are sustainably produced. Energy efficiency in homes also very much improves people’s quality of life.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr Vice-President, I greet you for presenting the report on the progress of renewable energy within the framework of the Energy Union. This progress is now more important than ever, because with the beginning of the new American administration, a new matrix in the political and economic relationship on a global scale also began. And in this matrix, energy, due to its role in economic competitiveness and the well-being of populations and its impact on the sustainability of the planet, is and will be at the center of geopolitics and geoeconomics in the coming years. The European Union has been a leader in the energy transition and must continue to be, combining efficiency, security, market integration, research, innovation and investment in infrastructure. And renewable energies are the focus of differentiation. But progress is not enough: 12% of the total energy and 28.3% of the electricity consumed is very little. We must act faster, review the renewables directive, invest in decarbonising transport and invest in new interconnections. Here are three examples of what we have to do to move faster.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I regret that in the catch-the-eye procedure that now follows I cannot call on all of the speakers who have been registered, because we are already quite late in time.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). - Mr President, Vice-President Šefčovič, the Energy Union can be a vehicle for job creation and for the benefit of all citizens, as long as we finally manage to put citizens at the heart of this effort. That is why we must act immediately, as you said, by setting up investment platforms in the Member States, but at the same time the Commission must respect its responsibilities in the energy mix. In Greece, for example, we are gradually replacing lignite in electricity generation. But we need support to ensure adequacy and safety in extreme conditions, for example by extending interruptibility or maintaining free rights, as we voted in ITRE to change the ETS. We also need support in tackling energy poverty, with targeted Community funding but also with encouragement from individuals. Increasing the energy efficiency of buildings and homes in the South will give us jobs, make a profit, reduce the bill and benefit the health of citizens, as long as we explain all this immediately, so that citizens can embrace this effort.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, technological changes, political commitments in the environmental field, the constant change of the international situation and the increasing energy efficiency in almost all global economies are imposing important transformations on the energy market. Yet the Europe of energy remains a sum of national markets which are weakly integrated with one another, with negligible physical exchanges, different operating mechanisms and a wide divergence of internal prices. It is essential for Europe to rediscover unity in the name of energy, starting with the theme of a single gas market: Europe's dependence on imports highlights the need for a common European natural gas market to guarantee both storage and delivery, in order to be able to absorb any interruption in supplies without trauma. The failure of the ECSC and Euratom, created to avoid the risk of energy insecurity, must lead us to reflect on the mistakes made and re-launch with new enthusiasm a wide-ranging energy policy, an Energy Union with an ambitious and stable regulatory framework.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, Mr Šefčovič, energy union presupposes equal treatment for all and, at the moment, this is not the case with Greece. First of all, our farmers, who are on the streets protesting against the troika's tax evasion policy, are paying dearly for agricultural oil because the troika has imposed an increased excise duty, which does not allow these people to be productive. Secondly, there is the famous energy poverty. The Greek people are impoverished. At the same time, the excise tax on heating oil has skyrocketed. The whole of Greece is thawing. This is happening, Mr Šefčovič, because the troika is imposing increased taxes. Is it possible for this situation to continue? How will Greece proceed? How will it be found in a competitive advantage? These are crucial questions, Mr čefčovič, and you must answer them because the Greek people no longer tolerate the troika policies.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, the energy union is an instrument for the energy oligopoly, which will take advantage of the liberalization of the market to manipulate it at will. We have seen it these weeks in the case of my country, in Spain, when prices doubled while exporting to France continued and a good part of the generation, including the most efficient cycles, remained suspiciously closed. Will the Commission promote any investigation into these events or will its Commission continue to accept actions always in favor of the large electricity companies, the same in renewables as in the social bond, even in contravention of European regulations? Liberalization and market power for the large oligopolies are one and the same thing, and, therefore, other policies, those of energy sovereignty, that must be promoted. In your documents, the efficiency and renewables targets lack ambition and, of course, there are regrettable absences. And in terms of distribution and commercialization, references to decentralization are a bad match due to their commitment to the market, which in the big ones are going to eat the small ones.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: - Thank you very much for the energy package that has been presented, the importance of which has already been said by colleagues who have spoken before me, so I believe that building a real, strong and independent energy union must be based on clear and coherent plans and action.Today, however, we lack that.The Nordstream 2 project is a major challenge not only for the emerging energy union, but also for testing the unity and solidarity of the European Union as a whole.A project that is not economic in nature and does not fit in with the goals set by the European Union - to reduce dependence on one supplier.This is a geopolitical project and I would therefore like to call on the Commissioner to undertake a comprehensive economic, environmental and political assessment of the Nordstream 2 project.This project must not be allowed to become a source of opposition, a turning away from solidarity and unity between the Member States.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members not only for their encouraging words and strong support, but also for the call to be even more ambitious in our efforts to transform the European energy system and to do it through robust governance. I would like to assure you that, whenever it is possible to improve our proposals, we are ready to work very closely with the Members of the European Parliament and with the Council to make sure that the proposal we put on the table last November really leads to the most profound transformation of the energy systems in Europe since they were built in today’s centralised and fossil-fuel-centred way. Our two afternoon plenary debates confirmed that we in Europe are following developments in the USA with growing anxiety. My colleague, High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini, was discussing with you one hour ago the problems with visas and the proper treatment of visitors to the United States. And I will, of course, say a few words about climate action and the Paris Agreement. I want to make it very clear that, for us, the Paris Agreement is a historic achievement. It is a binding international treaty which was jointly negotiated, approved and ratified and has entered into force, and we are ready to continue our communication and exchange of views with the United States because we believe we have very strong arguments. The implementation of the Paris Agreement is important not only for preserving life on our planet, for preserving mankind, but also because it has huge potential for modernising our economy: from bringing electricity to the 1.3 billion people on this planet who do not currently have access to it to really accelerating the implementation and use of all the innovations we have in our labs and our companies. I also want to make it very clear that Europe is ready to continue to lead in these efforts. I know that this readiness to provide leadership is very much welcomed by our partners across the world, be it on energy transition or climate action, be it in the area of development aid, where we want to use our clean technology to provide access to electricity to the peoples in Africa and in Asia, or be it on free and fair trade. I hope that this realistic and pragmatic discussion will take place again in the United States because I can hardly think of any other nation which is so affected by weather-related disasters, be it hurricanes or whirlwinds, or any of the other tragedies we have seen on our screens. You have been highlighting the importance of putting citizens as consumers at the centre of our efforts and using this energy transition to fight energy poverty and air pollution, and I absolutely agree with you. This is a must for the European Union. We cannot lose 450 000 people every year because of high pollution. We cannot have, on our TV screens, pictures of our cities which remind us of Beijing or Delhi, and we cannot accept the fact that 50 million Europeans have to choose between paying their energy bills or buying food for their families. Therefore, we are introducing what I believe will lead to a more common approach in fighting energy poverty. The European Observatory on Energy Poverty will be up and running by the end of this year. We will be talking about how, jointly with the EU Member States, we can tackle this challenge together. We believe that energy efficiency is a very important part of the answer, and that new electricity market design, with strong rules on the procedure leading to disconnection, should be another very important lever for improving the situation of our citizens. I know that Europe’s mayors – who very often are the first addressees of citizens’ complaints about air pollution or energy poverty or vulnerable sections of society – are ready to work with us very actively in the Global Covenant of Mayors for Climate & Energy. I understand all those honourable Members who have reminded us of the importance of energy security. You know that we are dealing with that very seriously, and I think this is strongly reflected in our report: 22 out of 28 countries are actually better off; having better infrastructure and interconnectors with reverse flows is giving us much more confidence; the European market is much more liquid than it ever was before; we are open to LNG and to Caspian gas; and we are ready to develop the East Med gas reserve with its huge potential, probably as big as that of the Norwegian reserve. We are also putting into practice rules which will no longer allow any abuse of a dominant position in the European market. In this context I would also like to thank and congratulate the Maltese Presidency because today they managed to secure the mandate for trilogue on the security of gas supply and I believe that, working together with the representatives of the European Parliament, this very important legislation on providing greater security of supply for European consumers will be agreed very soon. The last two points I want to mention concern investment and infrastructure. I totally agree with Mr Kelly, who underscored the importance of regulatory stability, vision and the alignment of goals at global, European, national and local levels. We have to work on that, and if we achieve it I am sure that we will also be able to secure investment because this represents a huge investment opportunity for private investors and for cities, and I am sure there will be huge demand in terms of putting all the new and innovative technologies at the service of our citizens. Mr Tamburrano suggested that we could use crowd funding, and this is actually one of the options we are studying under the Capital Markets Union. We are going to explore the possibilities here and look at how we can merge these two unions and use the potential of capital markets to invest in European energy infrastructure. I totally agree with you when we talk about investment that it should be smart investment. We should be very careful about stranded assets. We should think twice about where we put both private and public money. And this leads me to my last point, on excessive infrastructure. I was listening to you very carefully and I know very well your concerns on Nord Stream 2. I want to reassure you that European law would be fully respected, and that we are highlighting the fact that, even in such a harsh winter as this one, the transport capacity used for getting Russian gas to Europe is somewhere between 50% to 60%. I would emphasise too that we have consensus in the European Union – and the High Representative could be the best witness to that because we discussed it in the Foreign Affairs Council too – about the preservation and continuation of the Ukrainian gas transit route. There is consensus among all the EU Member States that we want to have it operational after 2019. I would like to thank the honourable Members for a great debate. I am looking forward very much to working on our proposals which are on the table and on the proposals on low-carbon mobility which we are going to present in the course of this year.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - Given the current political uncertainty, we must strengthen our Energy Union project. Energy is a fundamental pillar for the cohesion of States. The second report on the State of the Energy Union shows that the energy transition is a fact. But we run the risk that several Member States will not reach the 2020 targets. We must redouble our efforts to steer this transition correctly into the next decade. I consider it crucial to improve the targets to meet our commitments, mainly in the field of renewable energy. We must uphold the binding targets of the Member States, to consolidate European leadership in renewables and move towards greater energy independence for Europe. We need to provide Europe with safe, affordable and environmentally friendly energy. It is necessary to increase transparency in energy prices, to increase consumer confidence and avoid price rises that create social alarm, as has occurred in Spain in recent weeks. This energy transition is also an opportunity for economic modernization, and for the creation of quality employment, which also prevents citizens from being in a situation of energy vulnerability.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – I believe that a true European Energy Union is crucial if we want to revive and modernise the entire European economy. By overcoming energy fragmentation or ‘energy islands’ we are moving to a cheaper, more efficient and cleaner energy era. I believe that the completion of the Energy Union is as well extremely important if we want to achieve the goals of the Paris climate change agreement. However, I am still very concerned by such projects as the Nord Stream II, which completely sabotage the main goal of reducing energy dependence on third countries such as Russia.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - The second State of the Energy Union report highlights the start of the transition to a low-carbon economy in order to achieve the 2020 targets for emission reduction, energy efficiency and renewable energy. The report highlights good progress towards completing the Energy Union: the EU is now on the right track, particularly with regard to reducing emissions and increasingly competitive renewables, with a slightly lower total consumption to 20%. Now it's time to move on to the next step. Vice-President Šefčovič well underlined the opportunity to make 2017 the year of concrete and effective implementation of the Energy Union. The report has a clear imprint on the future, defining priorities not only for the energy sector, but also taking into account socio-economic aspects, such as the need to accelerate the boost to the economy, enhancing the employment potential of the sectors. green in accordance with the trends of circular economy and climate diplomacy. I am sure that Parliament will contribute to consolidating this path, starting with the substantial work that awaits us on the legislative dossiers of the "Clean Energy for All Europeans" package presented last November.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - The role of the European Parliament, in working closely with the Commission, is essential for the implementation of the Energy Union strategy. I am pleased that this European Union advance on energy in relation to CO2 emissions targets, compared to last year, will move to the next stage and this year will be the year of implementation, both nationally and locally. New proposals for low-carbon mobility need to strengthen the eEnergy Union and this will be possible if it enjoys robust governance. Governance must also take into account energy efficiency and security, electricity interconnections and the strengthening of internal lines, the integration of renewable energy and new technologies used for conventional energy production. Progress in diversifying resources, routes and energy supplies is visible, but the EU still imports more than half of its energy needs. We need to reduce energy dependence through efficiency. By investing, energy efficiency will create innovation and jobs, but by focusing on sustainable energy production, clean and affordable energy can be provided for industry and European citizens.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - Given the current political uncertainty, we must strengthen our Energy Union project. Energy is a fundamental pillar for the cohesion of States. The second report on the State of the Energy Union shows that the energy transition is a fact. But we run the risk that several Member States will not reach the 2020 targets. We must redouble our efforts to steer this transition correctly into the next decade. I consider it crucial to improve the targets to meet our commitments, mainly in the field of renewable energy. We must uphold the binding targets of the Member States, to consolidate European leadership in renewables and move towards greater energy independence for Europe. We need to provide Europe with safe, affordable and environmentally friendly energy. It is necessary to increase transparency in energy prices, to increase consumer confidence and avoid price rises that create social alarm, as has occurred in Spain in recent weeks. This energy transition is also an opportunity for economic modernization, and for the creation of quality employment, which also prevents citizens from being in a situation of energy vulnerability.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: in writing. - The Energy Union is about building a single competitive energy market and implementing the European climate goal. The basic tool for achieving these goals is energy efficiency. At this point, I would like to return to the topic of doubling the capacity of the Nord Stream gas pipeline. Nord Stream-2 may have a significant impact on these objectives and on the security of supply. Looking rationally, ignoring political understatements, long-standing disputes and fears resulting from historical experience, it must be admitted that the construction of the second line of the Nord Stream gas pipeline is rational. Converting the energy from gas to electricity is at least 20% more efficient than from coal, while CO2 emissions are only 40% of that resulting from its combustion. An additional physicochemical aspect is the high flexibility of electricity production, which perfectly harmonizes with wind energy. Gas turbines are the perfect way to be efficient during the so-called peak wages. This will allow the increase of energy efficiency in the EU to 30% and more. The designers of Nord Stream-1 (it's a pity not Jamal-2) perfectly understood the geopolitical superiority of this project. For a new project, a community method will be needed. Investments with links to EU countries in the Baltic region should be considered, which will enable Community exploitation and price fixing. I also believe that it is advisable to consider an alternative to Nord Stream-2 - a return to the JAMAL-2 idea. At the same time, natural gas supplies should be diversified by expanding LNG terminals.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - I would like to thank Vice-President Sefcovic for his persistent and hard work. I attach particular importance to the soon-to-be-launched European Energy Union Tour, where you will visit each Member State and hear their views. It is precisely this attitude, close to the people and with national interests in mind, that can make Europe strong. The Clean Energy Package opens a new chapter in energy union integration. I believe that we all agree on the basic goals of the Energy Union. Let us make Europe's energy supply affordable, make our markets competitive, while putting the Union on a sustainable path. However, there are already significant risks in achieving energy market integration. These risks can also be discovered in the Clean Energy package. We need to be careful not to make the same mistake of responding to every change with centralization. In my opinion, the strength of the European Union lies in its diversity. Different solutions to different opportunities drive the continent forward and ensure renewal. I believe that a better Europe does not always mean more Europe. We must not always find an answer to the new challenges by setting up another common institution, but by strengthening subsidiarity. I hope that the electricity market reform that is just starting will keep these principles in mind and we will find not only a quick but appropriate answer to the existing problems.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - The implementation of the postulates of the energy union, especially ensuring energy security for the member states, is one of the greatest challenges facing the European Commission. Energy security should be the overarching principle guiding the Commission when drafting new legislation. Meanwhile, the recently published "Clean Energy Package for Every European" shows that it is going in an entirely opposite direction. In the draft presented by the European Commission, concerns are primarily about the criteria that Member States will have to meet in order to launch the so-called capacity markets.
