Capacity mechanisms are of key importance for the energy security of the Member States struggling with energy shortages. Each country should therefore be able to shape this market on the most favorable terms for itself. Meanwhile, the European Commission proposes to introduce an extremely restrictive emission limit (550 g CO2 per kilowatt hour) for technologies that can be used in the construction of capacity markets. This means discrimination against carbon technologies. This is a provision that is potentially contrary to the EU Treaties, which state that a Member State has the right to "determine the conditions for the use of its energy resources, the choice between different energy sources and the overall structure of its energy supply" (Article 194 TFEU). Meanwhile, the European Commission's proposal on emissions is an attempt to circumvent this principle and exert pressure on individual countries when it comes to the selection of energy carriers. Additional concern is the fact that the Commission places environmental protection over Member States' energy security.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: signed up. - The European Commission's main priority this year is to focus on implementing what has already been adopted in the energy union strategy. The second priority must be to manage the balance between competitiveness and CO2 targets. Offshoring CO2 emissions is not a solution. I believe that the balance must be struck at the level of the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS), which must become an effective tool to facilitate the transition to a competitive and low-CO2 economy. Negotiations on the ETS legislative text will begin soon. I emphasize that the negotiating parties must take into account the situation of the sectors exposed to the phenomenon of emissions relocation and the limitation of business closures within the Union, given the additional indirect costs generated by the ETS scheme, which are not properly offset. New proposals for low-carbon mobility need to strengthen the energy union, and this will be possible if it is to benefit from robust governance. Governance must also take into account energy efficiency and security, electricity interconnections and the strengthening of internal lines, the integration of renewable energy and new technologies used for conventional energy production.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! The Commission's recent winter energy package is the basis for the creation of the European Energy Union and the first building block of Hungary's energy independence. By improving energy efficiency, modernizing buildings and spreading renewable energy, we can finally disconnect Hungary from Russian gas taps. If energy efficiency increases, not only will the overhead bill be cheaper, but tens of thousands of quality jobs can be created in Hungary. In the construction of the Energy Union, it is important to spread wind farms and solar panels, which are the cheapest forms of energy today. It is incomprehensible why these had to be banned in Hungary. Part of the Energy Union is also the termination of long-term, unfavorable gas contracts with third countries. For example, if we had not re-concluded the Russian gas contract last year, Hungarians would have received 40% cheaper today. All this because we could buy gas from the world market much cheaper. An energy union would also be good at preventing irresponsible governments from harming their own citizens. The energy union is good for the Hungarian people, provides Hungary with cheaper and more predictable energy, and leaves more in our wallets at the end of the month. The Commission must implement its ambitious plans as soon as possible, only then can we be independent of the Russians, and only then can we keep the overhead bills low.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The EU is on the right track when it comes to energy policy. The European Energy Union is currently in the second phase of development, ie 2017 is the year of implementation of the adopted legislation, which is beginning to be applied, both at the European level and at the national level. The EU economy is one of the most efficient economies in the world in terms of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and, according to all relevant indicators, will achieve the set targets for 2020 in terms of energy efficiency and renewable energy sources. One of the important goals of the European Union within the Energy Union is the transition to a low-carbon economy. There is a need to make better use of the potential of the Member States in this area, thus securing a large number of jobs for EU citizens and maintaining competitiveness. Achieving energy independence as another goal of the Energy Union also affects the stability of economic growth, which is equally important in the current turbulent and volatile global geopolitical situation. In order to achieve the desired goals, it is necessary to strengthen the energy connection between the economies of the EU Member States. Implementing these goals would bring the EU closer to energy independence, which would have a positive effect on the Union's economy, especially if we know that today the Union spends more than a billion euros every day on energy imports from third countries.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - I thank Vice-President Šefčovič for presenting the second report on the state of the Energy Union in the European Parliament on the same day as it was published. This report shows three key things. Firstly, it is good news that the modernization of the EU economy and the transition to a low-carbon economy are becoming a reality. The second is the role of renewable energy. For the first time in history, it is cost-competitive and sometimes even cheaper compared to fossil fuels. It employs more than one million people across Europe, attracts more investment than many other sectors, and has reduced our imports of fossil fuels by € 16 billion. But it is essential to maintain this trend. The third point is the approval of the Paris Agreement and its subsequent rapid ratification, thanks in part to the role of the Slovak Presidency. In the current context, this agreement will need to be defended and enforced even more vigorously. Personally, I consider the progress made since the publication of the first report on the state of the Energy Union in November 2015 to be very good, although the most difficult part - implementation - awaits us this year. As Commissioner Šefčovič pointed out in his speech, the Energy Union is not exclusively about energy and climate. Let us not forget that its purpose is to speed up the fundamental modernization of the entire European economy so that it is low-carbon and energy and resource efficient.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- With regard to the European Commission's winter energy package, I would like to address today in this very brief space that I have to express some important aspects: First, to say that it is necessary to set more ambitious targets for renewable energies and that these targetsare also binding on States.Second, guarantee self-consumption, define what charges and disproportionate processes are and prevent self-consumption from being penalized as is currently happening in the Spanish State.The non-application of charges on self-consumed energy should be clear.Expand the groups that can be included within the concept of collective self-consumers.And, finally, eliminate agrofuels and preserve the use of the land for food production, preventing energy crops or afforestation of agricultural lands.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - There is no doubt that the main priority in creating the Energy Union must be to strengthen the energy security of the European Union in the spirit of solidarity and trust. In order to make the Community immune to external energy crises and to reduce its dependence on specific fuels, suppliers and supply routes, it is necessary to undertake a series of actions aimed at diversifying energy supplies in terms of sources, suppliers and routes. Meanwhile, the Nord Stream 2 project not only stands in the way of the implementation of the Energy Union, but also harms the solidarity and mutual trust of the Member States. The attitude of the European Commission is also incomprehensible, which on the one hand rightly emphasizes in all EU strategic documents the need to bring about a significant diversification of energy sources and routes, and on the other hand accepts investment projects that make the Member States even more dependent, in particular in Central and Eastern Europe, on gas from Russia. The gas pipeline connecting Russia and Germany under the Baltic Sea is an investment inconsistent with the interests of the Community, the foundations of the energy union and the provisions of the European energy security strategy. I hope that the European Commission will finally take action to prevent this damaging project from happening.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – We must not ignore the wider geopolitical repercussions of our policies in the Energy Union. For instance, allowing the doubling of the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline has a destabilising effect on Ukraine, since it will enable Russia to reroute all the gas currently transiting though the former. As you know, full-blown war recently returned to eastern Ukraine, with indiscriminate shelling of civilians and soldiers alike. Therefore, it would be extremely irresponsible to help Putin by giving him another weapon to strangle Ukraine. In hybrid warfare, financial destabilisation can play a very significant role. Furthermore, the rerouting of the gas from the Ukrainian pipeline would put our eastern Member States in a more precarious position, since we currently lack sufficient interconnectors for the gas to make its way back from Germany. The current political climate should push us towards decreasing our energy dependence on Russia, instead of further solidifying our ties with this unreliable partner by investing in new infrastructure projects, which would become stranded assets once we truly pursue our goal of becoming energy independent.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- This single energy market represents an inseparable agenda of the objectives of the major European groups in the sector and of the powers that defend their interests.Essentially, it advocates the liberalization of the "energy market", putting pressure on Member States to speed up the privatization process of what is still public.Without recognizing that, against wonderful promises, neither workers nor consumers benefited from liberalization.Energy is a strategic sector, fundamental to the country's sovereign economic development, supported by scientific knowledge, technological progress and environmental sustainability.Sufficient reason to be kept in the public sphere, under democratic scrutiny and control.This report is incompatible with these principles.And this is our posture and the reality gradually comes to prove us right!

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: written. - The State of the Energy Union report, published today, shows that the EU is on track to meet its 2020 energy and climate targets. Emissions have fallen by 22% and the share of renewables is now 16%, with both targeting 20% ​​by 2020. So we are on the right track. Developments also show that economic growth and environmental responsibility are not opposites. At the same time as EU emissions have fallen by 22%, GDP has grown by 50%. Sustainable growth is possible. Internationally, European industry is already the cleanest in the world. In terms of production value, we produce less emissions than our competitors. Still, we still have a lot of opportunities to increase energy efficiency and develop cleaner technologies. This also opens up new export opportunities. I am particularly pleased that the Commission has taken aim dekarbonisaatiosta serious about traffic. With better transport planning, digitalisation and the electrification of transport and advanced biofuels, we will be able to cut transport emissions quite significantly already in the coming years. The European energy market needs more transparency, market conditionality and healthy competition. It also requires better electricity and heat transmission connections. This is also necessary to improve energy security and energy efficiency.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on managing migration on the Central Mediterranean Route (2017/2547 (RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I believe that the upcoming informal summit in Malta, starting on Friday, will be an opportunity for us to show that efficient – and at the same time human – management of migration is possible and is a must, if we work together, both as Europeans in solidarity and in partnership with our friends, the countries of origin and of transit. We must repeat once again, as we did here just an hour ago, that refugees must be welcome. This is a strong position that the European Union has and will continue to have. At the same time, without any contradiction – and, on the contrary, with some complementarity – we must say that the pain and the deaths caused by smugglers have to be stopped. I have seen with my own eyes people who have managed to survive – their stories are ones that nobody should have to live through, nobody should have to listen to. It is, first and foremost, a humanitarian duty not only to save lives but also to protect the lives of the people who are migrating. As you know very well, in the last two years we have been working literally day and night to reduce human suffering, first and foremost, and to reduce the loss of life on the various routes leading to Europe: in the Mediterranean Sea, of course, but also in places where the loss of life and the violation of human rights are less evident to the TV cameras, in particular in the desert. In the central Mediterranean, our Operation Sophia alone saved more than 32 000 people last year. Each and every one of them represents a precious result for me in a war that we are at last waging as the European Union. We also apprehended more than 100 smugglers, who are now in the hands of the law. Our migration compacts with five African countries have started to reduce substantially the irregular flows. For instance, the number of people crossing irregularly from Niger into Libya has decreased to its lowest level in years. We thus see that our action is starting to deliver in real terms, the first concern always being to save and protect human lives. The report adopted yesterday by the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Development on the role of our external action on addressing the movements of refugees and migrants encourages me to keep on this path of closer cooperation with third countries, including in relation to regular channels for entry to the European Union. I would ask for your support on this specific point because, among the commitments made by the European Union with our partners at the Valletta Summit last year was that of working more on the regular channels for migration. The more we work to prevent irregular flows, the more we need to offer regular channels. We know very well that this is a difficult debate in each and every one of the Member States and also in this Parliament. It was not by chance that, back in December, the Commission increased the resources for various mobility opportunities, and this is just the beginning. Last year we had more than 4 500 deaths at sea in the central Mediterranean. Believe me, I wish we could name each and every one of them because, as long as we refer just to numbers, it is much easier to forget them or to see this as a phenomenon. Each and every one of these people has a history, a story, a name and a future – or they should have had. Yet at times we do not even know their names. That is why all of us in the European Union need to do more, in a spirit of solidarity among Europeans and with our partners, who also have to take some ownership of the management of this problem. When we see people dying in the desert, or close to the Libyan coast, we need to have discussions with, and to help, our partners do their part to save lives and to make sure that the protection of human beings and their human rights is fully taken on board – and I will come back to that in a minute. We all need to do more, first of all to end the suffering, and to manage human mobility better. Last week I presented a package of additional measures, worth EUR 200 million, that will feed into the discussion at the Malta Summit the day after tomorrow. Migration has, of course, always existed. I have been accused many times of constantly pointing out, firstly, that, until a couple of decades ago, migration used to be from Europe to the rest of the world and, secondly, that if we had to live without migrants in all our societies and all our economies we would suffer a lot of negative consequences. Imagine the cost of non—migration to our European economies and you will realise that, indeed, we are talking not about a bad phenomenon but about a phenomenon that needs to be managed, first of all, as I have said, in order to protect human beings. We all know that there is no easy way to stop the suffering and manage the phenomenon better. We know very well that the real solution implies, first of all, the economic development of Africa and also the democratic development of Africa. Here our daily work is ongoing, with the compacts with the five priority countries, the external investment plan, the trust fund, and the overall work we are doing in partnership, in particular, with Africa and also working – and I know Commissioner Mimica will be joining us for the following debates – in the framework of our cooperation and partnership with the African Union and the different countries in Africa, as well as with civil society and citizens in Africa, because we know very well that the key to development lies not only in the economy but also in society and a civil space in which Africans can find their place and their way. Apart from that, we also have to focus now on what kind of quantitative and qualitative leap we can make in our joint work and the immediate steps we can take together and with our partners. So we name three proposals that will be on the table at the Malta Summit on Friday that I believe can be fully in line with the partnership approach we have taken on the central Mediterranean routes and with the African partnership from the beginning of last year and can also constitute a clear change and a clear step forward in having a more effective result. First, we want to increase training for the Libyan coastguard. I am sure many of you remember a meeting we had here in this building several months ago with the cast and the director of Fuocoammare, the documentary film that is now nominated for an Academy Award. They told us one simple thing, among many others, namely that we should do something about the Libyan territorial waters because, while before we were seeing people dying close to Lampedusa in international waters, we are now seeing people dying in Libyan territorial waters. We cannot act inside Libyan territorial waters: that is a Libyan responsibility. But we can help and we can train and support the Libyan authorities in this work. This will be one of the things I will discuss tomorrow with Prime Minister al-Sarraj. It will not be the only one, but I will come to that in a minute. Just a few days ago Operation Sophia launched the second package of training for a carefully vetted group of officials from the Libyan coastguard and navy and we now propose to increase the training even more substantially, including – and this is a very important point for me – human rights, women’s rights and respect for international standards and obligations. Secondly, we propose to step up our efforts on the southern borders of Libya at the point before the migratory flows enter a country that is, by definition, a difficult country in which to operate. We have already started to facilitate a common approach between Libya, Chad and Niger, in particular. Managing their common border is an interest they share, inter alia for security reasons. They see us as Europeans with our main focus always on the migration flows through Libya towards Europe – and I see a lot of attention paid to this, not in this Chamber but certainly in terms of public opinion – but there is also a flow of a different kind going from Libya to the south, to the Sahel and possibly connecting with the Lake Chad region and with Boko Haram. There is a security challenge there too: to control the border south of Libya in a more effective way. So managing this common border is in their common interest as neighbours, and it is also in our interest as Europeans. We are active in the region with three missions and operations and are already training local security forces, including in respect for human rights. I stress this because, for me, this is a key component of all the training we do with local forces. These are powerful tools. We can make them even more powerful, improving cooperation among all actors in the region and taking a regional approach, including working with the African Union and its newly elected leadership, as we have the new African Union Commission President who was the Foreign Minister of Chad until a few days ago. Thirdly, we will increase our support – at least this is my proposal – for the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) and the UNHCR. For me this is key, because you can act to the north, at sea, and to the south, in the Sahel, but the presence you already have now in Libya is there and will not disappear by itself. We all know very well that the human-rights angle of this is extremely serious, so we have to find a way of addressing the dramatic situation of stranded migrants inside Libya in a very challenging security situation. In recent weeks I have met both Filippo Grandi, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, and William Swing, the General Director of the IOM. Together we discussed ways in which the European Union can increase its support to the IOM and the UNHCR in order for them to work more, and better, inside Libya and chiefly in the places where the migrants are. For me, cooperation with these two organisations is the best possible way to guarantee the protection of human rights for migrants inside the country. A first project, worth EUR 20 million, was adopted in December under the Trust Fund for Africa. It will allow IOM to offer alternatives to the first group of 5 000 stranded migrants and take action to improve the dreadful conditions in detention centres. I believe that this will be a key element of our policy, where we will need to work as a team – the UNHCR, IOM and the European Union, together with the Libyan authorities, in trying to create the conditions for this to work. All these actions are designed with the bigger picture in mind. It is not an issue for today’s debate, but I think it is essential to keep clearly in mind that the key element of our work is supporting peace and reconciliation in Libya. Again, as I said, this is not an issue for this debate, but this is my main work. Our work with Libya goes far beyond the issue of managing migration. I know this is the top priority for political parties, governments and public opinion in Europe, but believe me when I tell you that the main point for us is working on finding a political solution to the crisis in Libya. I discussed this with Martin Kobler, the UN Special Envoy, just a few days ago here in Brussels, and again this will be the main point we will discuss tomorrow with Prime Minister al-Sarraj here in Brussels. We will also be discussing it with the Foreign Affairs Council on Monday. However, while we keep working to reach a political solution for Libya, there is much we can do in the meantime – working with the Libyan coastguard and navy, working with mayors and local authorities, working with Libya’s neighbours – not only to the east and west but also to the south – as a Libyan neighbour ourselves, because the European Union is a neighbour to Libya, and, with respect, trying to help and trying to focus – as I said – on a political solution that can bring stable democracy to the country, uniting it more than it is now. We will continue to work in partnership along the lines we defined together in Valletta last year in partnership with our friends, not only the authorities but also civil society organisations, and in partnership with the international organisations and the UN system with which we are involved.  In a week’s time in Malta we will have the first stocktaking exercise of the Valletta Summit action plan. Next week I will have the pleasure of initiating it, with the Maltese Foreign Minister, in order to see, with our African partners and the partners from the northern part of Africa, where we are on the implementation of the action plan and what is the way forward in terms of partnership. I believe that, as Europeans, we have finally started to play our part. We are starting to see some results. I mentioned the tens of thousands of lives which have at last been saved, but even if there was only one person dying at sea or in the desert, and whether we saw it or not, this is a responsibility and a problem that we are ready to try to solve. Again, it is not just a European responsibility. It is also a responsibility we have to share with our African partners and, specifically here, our Libyan partners. I hope – and I believe – that the Heads of State and Government in Malta on Friday will commit even more strongly to saving lives, both at sea and in the desert, to fighting the smugglers and to protecting the dignity of all human beings. This also means being true to our values, and that links us to the previous debate here in this Chamber. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Commissioner Mogherini.Mrs Winberg, I overlooked you earlier and gave the Commissioner the floor.They had reported on the agenda.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: – Mr President, before we start the debate on this item I would make the following points: this item was added to the agenda after Beatrix von Storch tabled a major interpellation on managing migration in the Mediterranean, on behalf of ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Colleague!This is not a request to speak ...

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: – Mr President, I do not have the rule, but this was something we tabled.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Colleague!You have every opportunity to publish it.But the instrument of speaking on the point of order is there for you to come up on the point of order, and only that. If everyone always speaks up who has put an item on the agenda, then we end up somewhere.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Madam High Representative, first of all thank you for your mobilization and to remind us once again that it is in our interest, as the European Union, in 2017, not to lose sight of the Mediterranean, because it is true that working for the security of the Mediterranean means investing in our security, but that requires coordinated actions and the mobilization of a range of instruments. I would like to draw attention to several points. The first priority, you said, is to continue to save lives. Yes, faced with the impossibility of entering Libyan waters, we have bet on support for the country's coast guard. This is the right approach. This is why it is necessary to release new funds for this project. But this is not the only solution. We should really think about how to counter the actions of traffickers who exploit the distinction between "territorial waters" and "international waters". What could the role of Frontex be? I would also like to ask a question about the Seahorse network, which should be operational in the spring. Do we have a more precise timetable for the results to be achieved? Second emergency: stabilize Libya and ensure that migrants there are treated with dignity. Yes, we must continue to support the country's efforts, keep in mind that the situation is fragile and we must pay particular attention to the country's southern borders. I wonder to what extent certain minorities, such as the Toubous, could be included in border management. Third point: the coasts of Libya are, in fact, the starting point of 90% of migrants wishing to reach Europe, but Libya is not the country of origin of migrants. That is why we must continue to work with the countries of origin. Niger is a very good example: 70 people in May, 1,500 in November. What about others?For that, indeed, as the European Union, we must also continue the efforts to open legal channels for migration.Last question: we must not lose sight of countries such as Tunisia and Egypt.How do you see Egypt's role in managing migration?The country is making efforts.It is important that we continue to support them.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, the truth is that when you hear Mrs Mogherini speak, she tends to start by congratulating her and thanking her for the work that she is doing on her, of which we are all aware of her. It is true that the foreign policy of the European Union had not played much role in the management of migratory flows, which were always dominated by the interior ministers, by internal policy. In the past year, both the Commission and the Council have worked very hard. There you have the Valletta summit, the new partnership framework, the pacts on migration, the high-level dialogues and the agreements and not agreements signed, for example, with Turkey or Afghanistan. In fact, something quite unusual has happened and that is that the weight of foreign policy has been put into motion with great energy, precisely to achieve the objectives that Mrs. Mogherini described today with respect to the central Mediterranean route. Now the question we must ask ourselves is whether all that effort is going in the right direction. There are some results, it is true, insufficient, but what matters most to me is whether the horizon is the one we must agree on. Are we really managing to respect what Mrs. Mogherini always defends: human rights, the dignity of people who emigrate? Can the efforts of the Commission and this Parliament really do more than the efforts or the urgency of the Council in obtaining concrete results on how many people we have managed to avoid entering the European Union? Which of the two powers will finally have more force? The future depends to a large extent on that answer, and I believe that the prestige of the European Union. Today, the central Mediterranean route is the deadliest in the world: in just one month, more than two hundred people have died. Achieving the stabilization of Libya should probably be the central element, but not only. I think we have to continue to appeal to the efforts of the member states to defend dignity ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: for the ECR Group. -  Sir. Chairman! The truth about the EU's response to the migration crisis is that there has been ineffective symptom treatment. In both 2015 and 2016, we have seen around one million people migrate to Europe, and all initiatives so far have only resulted in pushing refugees and migrants on a more dangerous route, not in solving the fundamental problems that give the incentives to come from the neighboring areas to Europe. Basically, the only humane, the only realistic and the only concrete solution to the challenge of migration is to implement a variant of the Australian model, where we take the bread out of the mouths of human traffickers knowing that there is no longer an economic incentive to come to Europe. A model where we help the refugees where they are most numerous and where the weakest refugees are, namely in the immediate areas. That we invest massively in emergency aid and safe zones instead of believing that the world's poor can be prevented from coming to Europe, as long as it is financially possible to pay human traffickers, with the clear knowledge in mind that one has a an incredible opportunity to stay, either temporarily or permanently, once the European authorities find their way. Until we realize this, all our attempts in this House to tackle the issue will only push people onto more and more dangerous routes and only create more distress and misery, both for the people concerned and for the European countries, who can not handle the situation.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say thank you, Madam Commissioner, for your engagement, your commitment and your good intentions. It goes without saying that the European Union should always contribute to stability, growth and the protection of human rights and democracy in our neighbouring countries, but we must never, ever, outsource our own responsibilities and obligations in respect of migration policies and people in need, or externalise our borders. In times where, on a daily basis, we witness what the ugly face of populism in power really means, all decent and progressive forces on this continent need to unite. We need to put our differences aside and take the bold steps required to preserve the values that created the foundations of this very Union on the ruins of the Second World War. Openness, respect, a rejection of nationalism and egoism and, instead, the promotion of human decency, these are what we must now engage in. Europe flourishes when we work together, and when we act on the basis of visions and hope, rather than our fears and prejudices. I hope that is the spirit in which you will work in Valletta this weekend and I wish you much success. I hope we bring back the message that what we need now are shared values and shared responsibilities for the people in need. Please, Madam Commissioner, bring that message back.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Mogherini, the agreement with Turkey continues to be criticized, and one is looming with Libya, which is even more disturbing. I wonder what is the point of the protests of the European leaders against Trump when they themselves prepare legally questionable operations and ignore the clear recommendations expressed by the UN Commissioner for Human Rights, according to which repatriations to Libya should not be made and not even landings in Libya in operations search and rescue, because fugitives run serious risks: torture in detention camps, violence against women, executions. We know from the UN that the danger is not the smugglers, it is the traffickers, the uncontrolled militias and public officials of a crumbling state. I would like to ask the Council to desist from dangerous agreements on Friday in Valletta. I ask this especially of Italy, because of our country's colonial past. I ask the Commission to get out of duplicity. At the same time, it cannot be considered unrepeatable the agreement with Turkey, to say that the first concern is to save lives, and to plan the training and financing of Libyan coast guards and Libyan law enforcement agencies and their coordination with our border forces ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Earlier today during the debate on President Trump's entry ban on Muslims, I heard you, Commissioner Mogherini, say that the European Union will not turn away from people who have the right to protection. You also said that the travel ban is only a temporary and illusionary solution. I fully agree with you, but I cannot reconcile that with your proposal to make agreements with Libya to stop refugees on the coast and to pay a lot for it. Refugees do not travel to Europe because there is a gap in the border, refugees come to Europe because they flee from war or poverty or hunger. Throwing away development money to close a gap in the border while we can also spend it on opportunities for young people in Africa, isn't that exactly what you warned us about earlier, a temporary and illusionary solution? If we give Libya a license to stop and detain refugees, then we do exactly what we accuse Trump of, we turn away from the people who need protection. And haven't you read it in "Die Welt am Sonntag" about that German ambassador in Niger who labels official Libyan detention camps as concentration camps as we know them from Nazi Germany? Camps where people are executed when they become overcrowded, when there is a lack of space. If we ignore that, then we don't need Trump for our moral bankruptcy.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Maltese Prime Minister, Mr Muscat, has predicted that the number of people crossing to Europe will reach record levels. Most of these people will come from Libya to Italy via people traffickers, as we know. The best way to stop these huge numbers of people illegally coming into Europe and to stop the large numbers of tragic deaths in the Mediterranean is surely to turn the boats back and process the migrants offshore. This is what Australia did, and it worked. That is why six European countries have now been in private talks with Australia, asking them which way to work things out, because they know that the EU way is failing. People traffickers are criminals. Only today, we have been warned by Italian officials that jihadis are actually plugging the gaps in funding for their actual campaign by smuggling people into Europe, because their oil money is running out. The EU, and many people in this Chamber, need to realise that their naive, soft-hearted approach to migration has not only failed, but has actually cost lives and funded terrorism and crime.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the unelected High Representative indicated by an Italian Prime Minister who is also unelected does not want to hear the voice of us populists, who instead are elected by the citizens. Today in Brussels the Libyan leader proposes to extend operation Sophia to Libyan waters, but he does not tell us, and Europe does not tell us, where he then wants to take illegal immigrants, migrants, through these ships. This is the point on which the generic 15 minutes of the High Representative's report does not clarify. The same command of the EUNAVFOR MED Commission tells us that between a third and a half of the total of Tripolitania is connected to the trafficking of migrants, and we should believe that these government forces will collaborate with the objectives that are required by many European countries, from which there is is the request for rejections? You use very generic language: the report speaks of a line of protection, but it does not say by whom and by what, you cite the Sophia operation but diplomatic sources indicated by France Press admit that it certainly saved human lives which the High Representative always tells us about, but it has been a source of attraction for migrants. This is the failure of these operations, they are only a source of new attraction. The story never ends, if a serious pushback operation is not started which, for example, the Italian Navy would certainly be able to indicate. You will provide the Libyan Navy with new means, but you don't even know who controls it. Who knows, people linked to terrorism will control it. Who knows, who knows? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, in the Libyan-Italian migration axis of the Central Mediterranean, the Union has implemented, in cooperation with the Italian authorities, a policy of controlling and navigating the uncontrolled influx of migrants. I want to make a comparison between Libya-Italy and Greece-Turkey. Italy may monitor and intervene, due to sea distance, on loaded ships departing from the Libyan coast. Greece is unable to do the same due to the small distance of the archipelago from the coasts of Asia Minor. The Union is even planning to send troops to Libya, due to government instability, to fight smuggling networks. Turkey does not fight these networks and instead rewards them, controls them and threatens the Union. In Italy there is a main entrance gate. In Greece, each island and small island is a corresponding gateway and the hot spots are increasing at a rapid pace with which the unemployment of young people is increasing. I want to give a piece of advice to the Union: if you really want to tackle migration flows, do not look at Greece and Italy. Focus on the main culprit, which is Turkey.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, at this point in history it is difficult to have a debate on migration without taking the opportunity to reaffirm that the bottom line is that Europe remains committed to acting as a safe haven for those fleeing war and persecution and who are eligible for protection. Despite our long debate on how we should go about it, that must remain our core principle forged through the very worst of times. That must be the starting point for our discussions and we must be the example to the world on this issue. The situation in Libya remains precarious and the EU must stand ready to help without imposition. But while the Libyan people must remain masters of their own destiny, the EU does have a crucial role in helping with aid and expertise in helping Libya to build up its border management and its asylum systems, improving its law enforcement capabilities and helping in its fight against terrorism. We are already doing a lot as a Union, but we must stand ready to do more. It is only with a functioning Libyan State that we will ever have a proper chance to agree together on enhanced cooperation to sustainability and safely manage migration flows while defeating terrorism, destroying trafficking networks’ business models and ultimately saving lives. That said, we must be careful to avoid giving the impression that a magic bullet addressing migration flows from Libya can suddenly appear from one day to the next. It is a lengthy process, and there are many steps yet to be taken before there are proper functioning State operators there. We have to acknowledge this or risk alienating our citizens on this issue and playing into populists’ hands.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! In 2016, more people came via the Mediterranean route than ever before. Over 4,500 people have drowned and that is why the Commission has our full support for all measures that can save lives, that put an end to the smugglers and the situation of the battered refugees in the Libyan camps. What kind of perverse attitude is it from Mr Borghezio to criticize the fact that refugees are saved from drowning because that makes them want to flee again? What kind of attitude is that? Nevertheless, questions remain: What about the cooperation with the Libyan government after the disaster that we helped to cause there, for example with the coast guard, which is not part of the government's means at all, but someone completely different? But one thing is unacceptable, namely that there is not a line in this proposal about legal immigration, not a line about the fight against the causes of displacement, not a line about thoughts on Dublin and succession, no information about the obligations of the Member States to finally get into the funds to deposit. You can be absolutely sure: this advice will be successful. You don't really ask for it; he'll do the little bit of what you wrote down.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, the High Representative spoke today about the European way, when we critically debated President Trump’s executive order, and while I cannot agree more that the EU must step up to the plate, as a values-based global player, we are hardly in a position to preach on migration or on the treatment of refugees. The deal, or so-called Statement, with Turkey, set the tone for cynical outsourcing of EU responsibilities. Doctors Without Borders refuses European funds as a result. And look at the failure of European Member State governments to secure our common borders, and to provide proper shelter for those fleeing war! They still do not have a common position on the war in Syria, and the numbers of people coming to our shores and dying at sea are still very high. But instead of learning from past mistakes, this Turkey arrangement now risks becoming a blueprint for more deals, including with Libya. So I would like to know how refugee and migrant rights will be respected in a situation where camps are labelled as resembling concentration camps, and torture is taking place. How does managing borders square with the right to asylum and how do we make sure that EU ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Mr. President, in response to the inhumane measures announced by Mr. Trump, Mr. Weber, the leader of the European conservatives, quickly came out to clarify that we do not build walls but build bridges.I imagine that those bridges are the bridge with Turkey, with Afghanistan, with Sudan, Pakistan or Nigeria to deport people who are denied international protection here.Or maybe the bridge was referring to that agreement that will be signed with Libya so that it is the Libyan coast guard that intercepts migrants and refugees at sea and takes them back to Libya.There is a report from the United Nations two months ago documenting malnutrition, forced labor, sexual abuse, torture and beatings in immigrant centers in Libya.Some say they are like concentration camps.Well, that's where those bridges of solidarity from the European Union lead: to those centers.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: -  Mister President! Amnesty International reported the worst atrocities against refugees in Libya, and I repeat the report from the German embassy in Niger, which I have already quoted, which speaks of the most serious systematic human rights violations in Libya. I quote literally: "Authentic cell phone photos and videos prove the concentration camp-like conditions in the so-called private prisons." Such reports confirm that there must be no return of refugees to Libya. With the training and equipment of the Libyan coast guard, however, it is also clear that the member states are trying to circumvent the violation of the international refoulement ban. Politically, however, it makes no difference whether we send the people back into Libyan chaos or empower the country's coast guard to do so. Anyone who helps to subject people to torture in Libyan detention camps is jointly responsible for the most serious human rights violations. I also find it alarming that the Maltese Presidency has recommended that the Commission reconsider its interpretation of refoulement.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: -: "Managing Migration and Saving Lives": that is the title of this debate and they are both the last things the European Union has done in the past year.Because the EU does not manage migration, but facilitates it and Brussels does not save lives, but causes more victims.Because thanks to your open borders policy, these illegal immigrants keep coming.On the way to social services, made nice by years of EU policy of free care, free home and free money.And even now that no one, here too, can no longer ignore the fact that terrorists among the asylum seekers is not hysteria but the reality, even now here you happily continue to facilitate, promote immigration to Europe and promote the loss ofour freedom and our security.Enough is enough.Our borders must be closed.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, saving lives at sea is a priority, just as it is a priority not to let the lives we have saved at sea exploit, and unfortunately this happens in some states. The High Representative's intervention focused on Libya. This is the central point because, just as we have faced, like it or not, with the agreement with Turkey, the Balkan route and therefore the eastern interest in the Mediterranean, in the same way we must face, not alone, but with partners and neighboring countries of the European Union and third countries, the issue of immigration. We are dealing with the package of seven directives on the common European asylum system in Parliament and it is very important above all, in addition to the issue of Libya, to address the knot of European lists of safe countries, not national lists but European lists. This is a very important thing in addition to the problem solving package.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are very concerned by the willingness of the Maltese Presidency to replicate the EU-Turkey agreement with Libya and we are also if it takes different forms, such as this idea of ​​training the Libyan Coast Guard to push people back trying to reach the EU. Libya is an unstable country, it has not signed the Geneva Convention, certainly it cannot be considered a safe country. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights in its report speaks of torture, rape, violence of all kinds and a document from a German embassy that emerged just today compares the camps in Libya even to concentration camps. What other evidence is needed? In the days of Trump's uncivil and illegal executive order and the massive outcry that has arisen, we should give a different signal. A few months ago a declaration was signed in New York committing everyone to greater sharing of responsibility for refugees and migrants. Knowing that 86% of displaced people are housed in developing countries, how can the EU do its part if every effort by the Council and Commission seems to be aimed at externalizing our borders and responsibilities? Agreement with Turkey, migration compact and the inadmissibility checks included in the Dublin reform that risk creating a large filter at the entrance. Instead, why don't you work with Libya on a vast resettlement plan to wrest people from the horror they suffer every day?

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, Ms Mogherini really excelled herself today with 18 minutes of complete hot air, as usual. Let us go back to who created these problems in Libya. It was Blair, Sarkozy, Cameron, and Obama – all gone, and cheered on by this place – yet we are expected to clean up their mess. But I have an answer. We should consider building a wall. A wall of nation-state naval frigates to block this invasion. And then we deploy special forces, again nation state special forces, to destroy the people traffickers and their vessels. Let us get tough, because our human rights and our safety as European citizens are under threat. Let us take a leaf out of President Trump’s policies. Let us protect our borders, our way of life, our culture and our liberties because – I tell you – they are under threat, and I for one, as the only female UK politician that stood by Mr Trump, am actually in total support of what he is doing. You have got such a rocket coming to you! You think Brexit was bad: well, Trump is with a nuclear warhead.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: - More than 13,000 people have died in the Mediterranean in recent years and our main priority here must be to prevent even more people from losing their lives by drowning. I am convinced that the only way to prevent that is to ensure that people do not get into those rickety boats at all. So that means that our focus must be on the southern coast of the Mediterranean and we must work with the countries in the region to guard borders, to tackle criminal smugglers and to protect and guard refugees. The plans that the Commission presented here today tie in nicely with this. But of course it is not new. In fact, it's something we've been saying for years. And when I look back on the past years, I have to conclude that the harvest is a bit meager. I have two questions about that. First of all, in June the European Council called for measurable results to be achieved and the first migration agreements to be concluded by the end of 2016. Except in the case of Niger, I don't see any of that and I wonder when we will finally make some progress on that. The second point about the Libyan Coast Guard: What is a realistic timeframe for the Libyan Coast Guard to get going to perform the tasks you expect them to do? And why, throughout the proposal in the Commission communication, I see nothing at all about, for example, the full implementation of phase 2 and phase 3 of the EU Navfor mission and the mandate given to it?

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - Minkejja li l-Unjoni Ewropea ilha snin titkellem dwar l-immigrazzjoni, dwar nies li jitilfu ħajjithom hekk kif jippruvaw jaqsmu lejn l-Ewropa, dwar mijiet ta 'eluf ta' persuni jistennew biex jitilgħu mil dic tan-nies li jagħmlu l-flus minn hêz l-aktar vulnerabbli, ftit li xejn rajna soluzzjonijiet konkreti li verament għamlu differenza. Sorsi differenti bħalissa qegħdin jitkellmu dwar miljuni ta ’persuni jistennew fil-Libja biex jaqsmu lejn l-Ewropa. Is-sitwazzjoni hija kritika u, la jikkalma t-temp, se nerġgħu niffaċċjaw influss qawwi ieħor mingħajr m’għandna soluzzjonijiet adegwati. Soluzzjonijiet effettivi jistgħu jintlaħqu jekk ikun hemm azzjoni diretta hêz it-traffikanti fl-istess ħin li jkollna kurituri umanitarji fejn persuni li qed ifittxu asil ikollhom id-dritt japplikaw, mingħajr bi jitggja li jibg it-traffickers. Neħtieġu skemi li jagħtu l-opportunità ta 'passaġġ sure u legali għar-rifuġjati u immigranti li għandhom dritt għall-asil b’mod ikkontrollat ​​u effettiv fejn tkun tista' tingħata protezzjoni internazjoni udistribġ. L-obbligi internazzjonali li dejjem iggwidawna għandhom jibqgħu jiġu mħarsa. Fl-istess ,in, hemm bżonn aktar minn qatt qabel li l-Unjoni Ewropea tkun proattiva u tiffoka aktar hêz ir-reġjun tal-Mediterran, xurt il-ġtieġa li titkellem u tinnegozja mar-reġjun tal-Afrika ta 'Fuq f taorsdem bi nibdew naraw l-ewwel sinjali ta 'stabilità f'reġjun daqstant problematiku.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, once upon a time there was an infamous deal with Turkey that never achieved the status of an international agreement and against which many of us raise our voices here, in this European Parliament, because it was not only inhumane to externalize the so-called 'crisis migratory in the Mediterranean ”, but, above all, because it was an ineffective response. All he did was divert the pressure to Libyan hell, now a veritable cursed route in which so many people risk their lives and lose it. That is why it is sad that many of us feel more identified with the quality of the speech, and especially the response, of the Canadian Prime Minister, Justin Trudeau, than with that offered so far by the European authorities. But the Council is meeting in Malta and I once again call the Council's attention to the need to include, in a comprehensive response and in line with European values, legal avenues so that immigration can have a chance and, in particular, so that refugees can challenge their claim for humanitarian protection to the European Union. Humanitarian visas blocked by the Council! Humanitarian visas are essential so that we can put together a humanitarian response to this tragedy in which so many people are risking their lives and ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a fact: in the absence of further action, migratory flows along the Mediterranean route will intensify in the coming months. Nothing surprising, I feel like saying. We are facing a structural phenomenon that requires joint interventions and targeted policies and not isolated actions aimed at blocking flows to Europe. Saving lives remains a priority for the Commission as well. Together we evaluate the choice of the most suitable tools to coordinate search and rescue activities. We do not outsource our borders in the illusion of stopping migratory flows from Libya - no matter whether on land or in territorial waters - and then lead them to detention centers, real concentration camps where very serious and systematic violations of human rights are recorded. Thinking that the success of a migration policy is measured above all in terms of repatriation and readmission does nothing but distance us from the idea of ​​common and global management that this Parliament adopted just under a year ago.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Five thousand dead in the Mediterranean in 2016 and tens of thousands of refugees in deplorable conditions in Greece and Bulgaria tragically show that Europe has not been able to manage migratory flows along the Mediterranean or other routes, it does not have an asylum system common to function effectively and continues to feed the business of drug dealers by not opening legal and safe routes for immigrant refugees, namely through humanitarian visas. The Malta Summit will be a failure and a shame if we are committed to externalizing our responsibilities and borders. Supporting the training of Libyan UNHCR and AOM structures to save and guarantee dignified treatment for migrant and Libyan refugees, yes, Ms. Mogherini, but not to impose readmission agreements or replicas of illegal business with Turkey on an ungoverned Libya . It would be unseemly and counterproductive. It is imperative that our governments wake up, reinvigorate European solidarity to respond to those inside and outside, like Trump and his strategist Putin, who want to destroy the European Union because they want to destroy democracy and, for that, they ride the xenophobic forces, racists, nationalists, who want to prevent us from fulfilling basic obligations towards refugees and migrants.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2016 there were more than 180 000 people who tried to reach the coasts of Europe by crossing the Mediterranean route and we know well that, unfortunately, so many did not make it through this hell. The plan presented by the Commission indeed initiates cooperation with Libya, our most problematic neighbor: training the Libyan Coast Guard on sea rescue may be a first step, but it is by no means a solution for the whole Mediterranean and, above all, for those territories that can no longer bear - having been left alone - the weight of hundreds of thousands of people arriving from all over Africa, the Middle East and then on the Libyan, Sicilian and Greek coasts remain blocked, sometimes remain in real lagers. We know that Europe needs a different and decisive approach and an internal immigration plan, because solidarity and relocation have not worked. The figures on relocation are still too low, really unacceptable. So we hope that the day after tomorrow's summit will have a different approach on this too.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, Mr Mimica, the European Union must turn its attention to the Aegean islands, which Erdoğan now threatens to replenish with refugees, mainly illegal immigrants, in the Aegean islands where 16,500 are trapped. refugees and mainly illegal immigrants whose inhabitants can no longer bear it. If you visit these islands, the locals will tell you that the situation has reached a dead end. In Samos, where I will be at the weekend, the situation is explosive. The same happens in Lesvos, the same in Chios, which I visited on January 15th. And there the inhabitants react. They can no longer stand other illegal immigrants, because most of those gathered there are illegal immigrants. Another thing they can not stand is to create new hot spots. Measures must finally be taken. The 66,500 relocations from Greece to the European Union must finally take place.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Mr. president. Look, the ombudsman has just told you and has just criticized you because in the agreement, the non-agreement, with Turkey neither an impact nor an analysis of the impact on human rights was made and she has criticized you for considering Turkey a country safe. They have not resolved these requests and those criticisms of the ombudsman and now a similar agreement is being considered with Libya, in this case to help the coast guard to return refugees trying to reach Europe to the Libyan coast. Look, Libya, in addition, I want to remind you that it is a country that has not ratified the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees of the year 51 and a country that an ambassador just recently said in Niger that it has fields that are assimilable to the fields of concentration. Under these circumstances, this cannot continue like this and this agreement cannot be made. And I want to remember today also, because we are talking about the management of the central Mediterranean route, that there are still deaths in the Mediterranean because we do not have a maritime rescue operation in the Mediterranean. Operation Sofia is not that. And now the NGOs are alone doing the work that governments should do.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, the European Union, after failing to control the flow of illegal immigrants from Turkey to Greece, is now preparing to reap new laurels, trying to stem the flow of illegal immigrants from Libya to Italy via the Central Mediterranean. . In this context, it wastes, for no reason and to no avail, large sums of money which it could allocate in order to rectify, eliminate or, in any case, reduce the problems faced by distressed Europeans. It could also give this money to the countries from which the illegal immigrants come to get some development. None of this works. It continues to pursue the same failed policy. Ms Mogherini has previously said that Europeans must show solidarity. Agree. But first the Europeans must show solidarity with the Greeks who, for the seventh consecutive year, are suffering from the implementation of the memoranda. What does the European Union do, it gives four hundred euros for each illegal immigrant, it provides free food and health care, ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Mediterranean is a migratory region at the center of which is the Schengen border, the external border of the European Union. Yet Europe is moving slowly. The exceptional migratory wave that has hit Europe confronts us with ancient problems, which require urgent and concrete answers. There are still too many migrants dying along the Mediterranean route. It is necessary to stabilize the countries from which smugglers depart and to definitively break the networks that feed the trafficking of human beings. Most of these people are forced to flee their country due to conflict, persecution, human rights violations or situations of misery. It is essential to improve the exchange of good practices with third countries. It is necessary for the European Union to succeed in building a real common partnership with the countries bordering the Mediterranean, if it really wants to address the problem adequately and consistently.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, on behalf of High Representative Madam Mogherini, I would like to convey her regret and apologies for not attending this parliamentary debate in full due to the conflicting agenda points that led her to the continuation of talks between Serbia and Kosovo this evening in Brussels. This has indeed been a very interesting debate. As we have seen on previous occasions, the honourable Members hold somewhat divergent views when it comes to the issue of migration. However, I also take note that the large majority of the honourable Members support our approach to migration management, complementing our long-term efforts, such as the Partnership Framework, with the short-term measures outlined in our recent communication on the Central Mediterranean. I am very grateful for this support.  Even though some may like to present it in this way, there is no quick fix to the current situation. Only by applying a comprehensive and tailor-made approach – not replicating any other arrangements – continuing to save lives at sea, cracking down on smugglers and traffickers, addressing the root causes of migration and working more in particular with our African and international partners, will we be able to more effectively manage migration. This is what we will be taking from our debate today.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - Undoubtedly, the discussion on the management of migration along the route through the Central Mediterranean is important, but the focus of the debate, in my opinion, should be more on how to stop migration on all routes to Europe. Our efforts must focus on addressing the root causes of migration from Africa and the Middle East, because until the situation there stabilizes, I do not see how the migration flow will stop. I support the idea of ​​strengthening controls at sea and land borders as a temporary measure to tackle this unprecedented security crisis. However, we must not delude ourselves in any way that this will be enough. We must be able to fight both the traffickers and their extraordinary ingenuity, bordering on impudence and costing more and more lives.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The vast majority of migrants entering Europe illegally via the central Mediterranean migration route are economic immigrants. The only way to prevent hundreds of thousands from trying to cross the Mediterranean into Europe once the weather has improved, risking their lives, is to focus on the external aspects of migration. There would be a need to establish safe zones outside the EU, to allow the processing of asylum applications outside the EU or at the EU's external borders, and to set up migration and asylum centers in third countries. We should conclude further agreements so that new, alternative lines of migration do not emerge and there is a great need for stronger action against human traffickers. However, it would also be important to recognize that maritime rescue should not lead to automatic legal entry into EU territory, as this encourages migrants from North Africa to attempt dangerous crossings with ships in poorer condition in the hope of being rescued. This approach would also be in line with the resolution “Protecting Lives and Controlling Migration to Europe” adopted by the General Assembly of the European People's Party in November 2016, which contains the migration policy of the party family. At the same time, in addition to the Central Mediterranean, due attention must continue to be paid to the Western Balkans route, and the countries along this route must also be supported. The number of arrivals is expected to increase significantly from March.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - Libya is currently the origin of the vast majority of displacement of refugees and immigrants who are heading on practically suicidal journeys towards European territory. The Council understands that after the controversial "agreement" signed with Turkey, the eastern Mediterranean route (Greece) is "stabilized" and is now seeking measures to stop the irregular departure of immigrants from Libya. If the management carried out with Turkey has been harsh criticism both in the legal and moral aspects, the possibilities offered by the chaotic and unstable situation in Libya increase the uncertainty about the measures that the European Council can agree on at its informal meeting in Valletta this 3 February. The Socialist Group has requested that this point be introduced in plenary session so that Parliament can pronounce itself prior to said summit and demand for migration management a humanitarian approach and respectful of international law, a common European immigration policy based on the principle of solidarity, consistent in its internal and external facets, as well as the opening of safe and legal routes that offer an alternative for the thousands of people who continue to have to risk their lives to reach our shores.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in South Sudan (2016/2509 (RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, when South Sudan became independent in 2011 there were high hopes for the future of the world’s newest state. Six years later, those hopes lie in tatters. Although 18 months of brutal civil war were formally brought to an end by a peace agreement in August 2015, fighting continues throughout much of the country. Hundreds, perhaps thousands, continue to die each month.  On 1 December last year, the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in South Sudan noted that a steady process of ethnic cleansing was underway in the country, using starvation, gang rape and the burning of villages. The United Nations Secretary-General warned in November that South Sudan stood on the edge of the abyss, with a catastrophe imminent. Around one-and-a-half million refugees have fled to neighbouring countries, while almost two million persons are internally displaced. Some four million persons are short of food, with more than one million children under the age of five acutely malnourished. There is a danger of widespread famine later this year.  Faced with this bleak situation, the European Union is very much engaged in addressing these immense challenges. The European Union, as a witness to the 2015 peace agreement, is working vigorously to support its implementation. The European Union is an active member of the peace monitoring institutions established by the agreement and is providing financial assistance for implementation of parts of the agreement. The European Union works as closely as possible with the countries of the region and with the Intergovernmental Authority on Development and the African Union collectively to encourage implementation of the peace agreement. Although South Sudan, much to our regret, has not yet acceded to the Cotonou Agreement and is therefore not eligible for the full range of development support, the European Union remains committed to help. In 2016, the European Union provided EUR 143 million for humanitarian assistance to South Sudan, as well as for supporting the provision of basic services. We fear that this year’s needs maybe even greater.  The European Union is also providing financial assistance to neighbouring countries to assist them to deal with the enormous influx of refugees. Let me take this opportunity to commend Uganda, in particular, for its compassion and efficiency in sheltering over 650 000 refugees.  The European Union has imposed an arms embargo against South Sudan and is lobbying – so far without success – for the United Nations Security Council to follow suit.  The European Union is particularly shocked at the gross violation of international human rights and international humanitarian law that have been perpetrated by all parties with complete impunity. An individual who orders or commits criminal acts of violence must be brought to justice. To this end, the European Union stands ready to support the African Union in establishing as rapidly as possible the hybrid court for South Sudan envisaged in the peace agreement.  Let us seize the opportunity today to send a number of clear messages to all parties in South Sudan. There can be no military solution to the divisions of South Sudan. All parties must observe the ceasefire in full and repudiate any speech inciting ethnic hatred. The United Nations mission in South Sudan must be allowed to exercise its mandate in full, and without hindrance. The regional protection force that was mandated by the UN Security Council last year to reinforce the United Nations mission in South Sudan must be deployed swiftly. The South Sudanese authorities must allow unrestricted humanitarian access to those in need. All parties must be brought into an inclusive political process based on the 2015 peace agreement, which remains a blueprint, if properly implemented, for establishing a functional institutional framework for the state of South Sudan.  We welcome the national dialogue announced by President Salva Kiir in December last year. Any step to foster dialogue and reconciliation between many groups in South Sudan is welcome. A political dialogue and consultation should be representative of, and trusted by, the entire population of South Sudan. Such a process should be initiated without delay and without obstacles. There is no shortcut to full and fair representation. I urge President Salva Kiir and the transitional government to look again at the structure of the national dialogue, with a view to ensuring that it is a generally inclusive process. In particular, we hope that a way can be found, and should be found, to allow the South Sudanese Council of Churches, which is widely seen as an impartial interlocutor, to play a central role in the national dialogue.  Let me also mention the Cotonou Agreement again. As mentioned, the development needs of South Sudan are evidently vast, yet we cannot release all the funds potentially available as long as South Sudan has not acceded to the Agreement. We urge the transitional government to move forward rapidly with accession. South Sudan is, sadly, a country which has known more war than peace.  The European Union will continue, in close coordination with the United Nations, the African Union, the United States and the countries of the region, to do everything it can to support the South Sudanese leadership to take decisive steps to embrace peace and to build a state that serves the interests of its citizens. Thank you very much for your attention. I look forward to our discussion.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Despite its great natural resources, South Sudan - the youngest and one of the least developed countries in the world - is facing a growing humanitarian crisis and instability. The political dispute between the former and current president turned into a brutal conflict. Massive internal ethnic displacement is taking place: over a million inhabitants of this country seek refuge in neighboring countries. South Sudan is in the forefront on the world map determining the level of risk of a humanitarian crisis. Therefore, it was very nice to hear from the Lord about the actions that will be taken. I hope that they will be implemented very quickly, otherwise we will face another humanitarian disaster on an international scale. Steps should be taken to bring an immediate end to hostilities, which must be accompanied by peaceful political consultations. In this context, the involvement of the African Union is important, but also the European Union should act to strengthen international cooperation in support of the peace process in South Sudan in order to avoid a humanitarian crisis.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr. President, four years of civil war, tens of thousands of deaths, three million displaced persons, ethnic violence: genocide is imminent. Torture, assassinations, gang rapes, recruitment of child soldiers: atrocities are on the increase. I condemn the total disinterest of the international community in the catastrophic situation in South Sudan, as evidenced by the rejection of a resolution imposing an arms embargo and sanctions by the United Nations Security Council. This is absolutely absurd. For several weeks now, humanitarian organizations and United Nations experts have sounded the alarm on the pre-genocidal situation. Ethnic cleansing has been underway since early December in several regions of the country. The Blue Helmets can no longer ensure the safety of the population and must withdraw. It is one of the most horrific human rights situations in the world. I recall the responsibility of the political leaders of South Sudan, both the President, Salva Kiir, and the former Vice President, Riek Machar, to protect their people. They are both responsible for appalling atrocities and massacres. There is an urgent need to embark on a journey of dialogue to implement the peace agreement and a ceasefire. Commissioner, I will end by asking you what the European Union can do, with all these instruments at its disposal, in diplomacy and in compliance with the Cotonou Agreement, to stop the resurgence of the conflict and the violations of human rights. human rights in South Sudan?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as an enthusiastic supporter of South Sudan’s independence, it is very sad for me that there is so little to celebrate in its first five years in existence as an independent state. It has been plunged into civil war, and there have been widespread war crimes and atrocities committed ever since 2013. I naturally welcome the recent joint calls from IGAD, the UN and the African Union for a cessation of hostilities, and it is an encouraging sign today that rebel leader Riek Machar has indeed backed this call, but the fighting sadly goes on. I note that the King of Morocco is on an official visit today to South Sudan, and this coincides with Morocco rejoining the African Union after 35 years of absence. Dare I say, at a time when the European Union is shrinking thanks to Brexit, it is encouraging to see that the African Union is actually expanding.  A further source of expansion for the African Union could come from the re-recognition of Somaliland, a promise that was made to me in person by a South Sudanese leader prior to independence. We must now hope that the talks in South Sudan can return under the national dialogue format, reminding President Salva Kiir that it is only with peace that South Sudan and its people will be able to see the benefits of its abundant natural resources.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Commissioner has spoken of the immense challenges and the need to end the suffering of the people in South Sudan. Meanwhile, the UN Human Rights Committee has warned that South Sudan is on the brink of genocide, starvation, gang rape and fighting between militias escalating to levels that seem to amount to ethnic cleansing. The gravity of these crimes and the extraordinary violence, while there is impunity for the perpetrators, has to end.  Besides these atrocities, we see a crackdown on civil society and the media, preventing accountability and documentation. So it is very urgent that we act now as the European Union, as well as in context of cooperation with the African Union and the United Nations.
