We have to be aware that already hundreds of thousands have been killed since 2013 and over three million people have been displaced, and they in turn face starvation. It is crucial that the atrocities stop, a peace process is set up, and this cycle of violence, revenge, violence, revenge, must end.  I welcome the fact that there is an arms embargo in place, but we must be vigilant also on the export of systems that allow for the tracking and tracing of people – surveillance, hacking and exfiltrating information. There are known cases where, despite sanctions, systems from the EU have still been exported, including to South Sudan. So it is important that we ensure accountability and ensure that the EU takes a leading role in this terrible conflict.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the case of South Sudan is not the only one in Africa today. In the strategy of domination of peoples and the plundering of their wealth, the great powers divide states, foment wars, if necessary intervene militarily, as in Libya or Mali. We cannot disconnect the current situation from the process favored and promoted by the United States, the European Union, Israel and their allies, taking advantage and exacerbating internal differences, poverty, social injustices and ethnic differences, to fuel a prolonged conflict that would lead to their independence in 2011 , in a process similar to Kosovo. All in the name of geostrategic control and taking advantage of the considerable oil reserves and various minerals in the southern region, which also today guide international interests in the region. It is necessary to call for a cease-fire and an immediate end to the financing and sale of arms to the different parts of the conflict. It is necessary to defend a peaceful and political solution to the conflict, free from any interference and external military intervention.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation of the populations of South Sudan is dramatic: out of about 12 million inhabitants, four and a half are fighting hunger every day, two million are internal refugees and over 1.3 million are refugees in the countries neighbors, primarily Uganda. In the recent past, a certain vulgate has described the success of self-determination, the overcoming of the old colonial arrangements and the creation of a government of national unity. It is an optimistic picture, but reality has denied these fragile arrangements because, despite the fact that over the years there has been a massive injection of resources for development aid and the creation of an administrative system, the representatives of the two main factions, President Kiir and the Vice President Machar, they broke government cohabitation driven by ancient ethnic rifts accentuated by the oil interests at stake. The UN mission has proved powerless in restoring the rule of law and has only succeeded in creating sites for the protection of civilians fleeing violence, while the Regional Protection Force authorized by the Security Council is still far from materializing. Today the specter of a new Rwanda is becoming more concrete. To avoid this tragic eventuality, the humanitarian initiatives of the UN and those of individual countries such as Uganda are not enough ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, the situation in South Sudan has been significantly deteriorating in the past months. Massacres, gang rapes and destruction, combined with hunger, are leading to the population fleeing the country. There needs to be a political solution to the civil war. This involves advances on the proposed national dialogue and a return to the 2015 agreement. The EU should contribute to the South Sudan peace process, especially in the area of justice, where our assistance can be instrumental. I would therefore like to support the earlier call by the Vice-President/High Representative to establish a hybrid court that will investigate the atrocities committed. This is why our political and diplomatic influence can bring actual tangible results for the South Sudanese population, who deserve much more than the current international community is offering to them.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the crisis in South Sudan is one of those crises that appears and disappears in the media but has been with us for nearly forty years: All kinds of destructive wars for ethnic reasons, for religious reasons, for the fight for natural resources. It is a relatively young country, but its population has lived these decades of war around and around it. And I have to point out that it is time for us to make decisions to support those who have embarked on an exodus to neighboring countries, those who have displaced within South Sudan's own territory, those who are in need of humanitarian aid, which is practically the entire population of the country. 30% of the Trust Fund for Africa must be used for humanitarian assistance on the continent. We have to provide housing, we have to provide food and sanitation to those displaced, also financial aid. But above all I want to underline something that the Commissioner said: we have to be active, not only as witnesses but also as main actors, in guaranteeing the peace process. We have to be more active in guaranteeing the arms embargo and we have to be more active in persecuting those who are obstructing the achievement of peace in the country.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - Exactly a week ago the Dutch press, in the Reformatorisch Dagblad, published a penetrating and impressive article about a shelter for street children in Juba, the capital of South Sudan. The title of the article was already revealing: "When shooting flat on the ground and singing and praying". The article also touched on the dire situation in South Sudan. The street children have all learned one important lesson. If soldiers ever appear at the gate and ask who belongs to which people, the answer is simply, "We are all South Sudanese." In reality that is far away, but it is the future, we hope. However, the future of these street children looks bleak as both the African Union and the United Nations warn of an impending genocide in South Sudan. Both organizations have therefore recently sounded the alarm and argue for a direct international intervention. I want to emphasize that here because it is really going wrong.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Mr President, the civil war in Sudan is a war of continuation.The liberating war of South Sudanese black Christians against the Khartoum regime lasted for forty years.I lived in South Sudan at the time.I examined the symbiosis of war and famine, which developed into a humanitarian catastrophe, three hundred thousand people died, more than a million ended up as refugees.Christian Sudan has become independent.Immediately in 2013, a new war broke out, this time between the people of South Sudan themselves.The Khartoum regime did not accept the loss of South Sudan.Proof of this is the ongoing attacks on Christians.Recall that at the end of January, a Czech citizen, Christian missionary Petr Jašek, and with him Sudanese pastor Hassan Abdurahe Taour and Abdulmon Abdumaw were sentenced to 20 years in prison.I believe that the Khartoum representation will understand how devastating the confessional dispute is and will give the convicts pardon.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, we have heard already that over the past three years in the conflict in South Sudan tens of thousands of lives have been lost, three million displaced and 70% of women in camps raped. This cycle of violence must be broken. We have an arms embargo, but what are we doing to enforce it internationally? Companies in Ukraine have been fuelling violence through the sale of more helicopters; this cannot remain without consequences, Commissioner. This conflict is the result of the failure by us and others to invest in inclusiveness at the point of independence, leaving ethnic divisions vulnerable to those vying for power internally. By mid-2017, five million in the country will be in need of food aid. We have to ensure long-term international commitment to food security and work with the region to re-open trade routes. I have a couple of issues, Commissioner. What steps have been taken to push for full implementation of the 2015 peace agreement? What are we doing to promote social cohesion so that South Sudan’s children are not a lost generation? And how will we be coordinating a development and recovery programme, with an effective emergency response over the years to come? (Interruption by the President) After the Rwandan genocide we said ‘never again’. Let us hold to this.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: - Mister President! I was able to be there six years ago when South Sudan achieved its independence in a referendum to the great cheer of the population. Only this independence has brought the people no peace, no democracy, no prosperity, because those who are responsible for the leadership of the country let the country sink into civil war and bring unspeakable suffering to the people. At the same time, however, South Sudan is also an example of the failure of the international community. Neither the East African Community, nor the African Union, nor the United Nations are in a position to put an end to the death and suffering in South Sudan. It is striking that in December, at the suggestion of the United States, the Security Council submitted a motion to impose an arms embargo on South Sudan. This application failed. Only seven of the 15 council members voted in favor of a corresponding draft resolution. Eight countries, including the two veto powers Russia and China and the three African states Angola, Egypt and Senegal, abstained. It would have taken at least nine yes-votes to pass the resolution. That's a shame. I think that the only thing that will help here is sanctions against those who are responsible in South Sudan for killing people there.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in South Sudan is truly dramatic. There are widespread and systematic violations of human rights. The government continues to crack down on fundamental freedoms with arbitrary arrests of journalists and political leaders and a dramatic famine is added to the violence. In South Sudan, according to UN bodies (FAO, Unicef ​​and the World Food Program), more than 30,000 people are at risk of dying of hunger and tens of thousands are people at risk of famine. If the situation is not to deteriorate further, it is necessary for Europe and the international community to mobilize, also in collaboration with the African Union, to foster national reconciliation and to support a process of political and institutional reconstruction of the country. A political transition in South Sudan towards democratic forms of government is needed, a transition that could help the Sudanese population and also that of Darfur to emerge from the current state of underdevelopment, suffering and death.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the crisis in South Sudan has slipped off the radar of global publicity. After a period of relative calm after the end of the civil war that broke out in December 2013, South Sudan is now facing the collapse of the peace process and a return to violence, to the extent that there are fears of genocide. About sixty thousand people have fled the country as the conflict escalates recently. Violence has intensified since the collapse of the peace process and ethnic cleansing practices are already under way, with features of extreme famine, gang rape and the destruction of villages. In addition, millions of people, or three-quarters of the country's population, do not have access to basic necessities such as food, water and medicine. The international community has an obligation to prevent this situation from happening again in Rwanda.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the honourable Members for their contributions and interventions. The people of South Sudan have suffered immensely over the past six years. The lives of much of the population continue to hang in the balance, threatened by brutal violence, famine and destitution. The European Union will continue to deploy all the instruments available – political pressure, sanctions, humanitarian relief, development assistance, support for international justice – with a view to encouraging the parties to replace conflict with dialogue, in the hope of securing a better future for South Sudan.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable members, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Gabon are two countries in the Central African region that are experiencing serious political challenges related to the electoral process. As you know, our relationship is based on the principles and essential elements of the Cotonou Agreement and especially respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law. And, of course, we support the implementation of the African Charter on elections, democracy and governance.  The stability of Gabon and the Democratic Republic of Congo is of primary interest to the European Union, but genuine peace, stability and development do not come through enforced preservation of the status quo and repression of opposition voices.  On the Democratic Republic of Congo, the European Union considers that the political agreement signed on 31 December last year represents important progress, with remarkable mediation done by DRC Catholic bishops. The challenge now is to implement and to do it quickly. It is imperative that the transition period towards elections be as short as possible. In order to achieve this, the bishops should not be left alone and the European Union will actively seek the engagement of the region, as well as the United Nations, in pushing Congolese political actors to implement the agreement. A new government reflecting the inclusive support for the agreement must be in place as soon as possible. The DRC parliament will have a loaded agenda in its March session with the legislative acts necessary to move ahead with elections and the institutionalisation of the Comité National de Suivi, the oversight body that will also watch over the independence of the Electoral Commission. The Electoral Commission will then produce an electoral calendar that will reflect the urgency for holding elections and utmost care for the costs of the operation in a country that is experiencing a severe fiscal crisis and is failing to provide essential services to its population.  The European Union is ready to support this process politically and operationally, providing expertise when required to both national and international actors involved. The resolution of the Security Council that will be renewing the mandate of MONUSCO in March 2017, will be an important step in establishing a global consensus around the political agreement. This is important, as the legitimacy of President Kabila no longer rests on the constitution alone, but on inclusive political support for the agreement. The European Union imposed restrictive measures in December. The warning given in the EU Council conclusions of 23 May 2016 still stands. Individuals responsible for violence and those trying to obstruct a solution to the crisis in the DRC will be targeted. We shall exert vigilance on the human rights situation, on fundamental freedoms, including freedom of expression, and we are dedicating increased resources to that effect.  Let me now address Gabon. The electoral violence following the presidential elections of 27 August last year and climate of fear, repression and intimidation that followed and continues today, is an issue of great concern. Arbitrary arrests, long-term detentions, inhuman conditions and excessive restrictions of freedom of expression, assembly and manifestation are alarming. Grave human rights violations, including alleged torture, extra—judicial killings and disappearances, call for an independent investigation without any delay. We strongly encourage an independent inquiry in Gabon to conduct a quick fact-finding mission.  We also welcome the initiatives by the Gabonese Government, the opposition and civil society to request a preliminary inquiry into the post—electoral violence from the International Criminal Court. The European Union has also activated the human rights defenders mechanism to protect civil society activists in Gabon whose personal security was at risk.  We cannot disregard the conduct of the elections. The conclusions of the EU Election Observation Mission were clear. They do not allow us to turn the page and to carry on with ‘business as usual’. EU relations with Gabon have been reassessed and the Gabonese Government was invited to an intensified political dialogue with the European Union. The dialogue aims to accompany the government in their announced electoral and institutional reforms, based on the Election Observation Mission’s recommendations and to shed light on the human rights violations. We expect the government to recognise its best interest to engage in this constructive diplomatic exercise in order to avoid further consequences. Some of them are mentioned in the draft resolution before this House, such as individual measures, a review of our development cooperation or consultation under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement. In concluding, let me express my gratitude both for the debates and for the resolutions of the European Parliament, which reassure us in our firm diplomatic and development actions, and for your participation in the EU Electoral Mission. Let me thank in particular the Chief Observer, the honourable Member, Mariya Gabriel, for her dedication and courage.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I recently had the honor of leading the two European Union election observation missions in the DRC and Gabon. So I was on the front line to observe all the irregularities that occurred during the two processes, but today I will focus on Gabon. I would first like to stress the credibility, neutrality and impartiality of the electoral observation mission. The implementation of the recommendations that we have made is the cornerstone of the continuation of our dialogue. In addition, it is imperative to focus more on post-election violence. All light must be shed on these abuses. Those responsible for the post-election violence must answer for their actions. We cannot comply with impunity, we do not have the right to be forgotten. That is why it is just as imperative that the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights urgently send a mission, and I call on Member States to help in this regard. Finally, please, if the political dialogue does not yield results, targeted sanctions, such as the travel ban or the freezing of assets, must be adopted. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, first of all, I would like to express my support for the work done by the electoral observation mission chaired by Mrs Gabriel and, also, my agreement with what the Commissioner has expressed in relation to Gabon. I think we have to send a clear message. In Africa, in some African countries many things are happening that we should not consent to, but it is true that our possibilities of action are limited. But, regarding those possibilities of action that we have, we must be firm and forceful. How many times have we brought the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the debate in this house? Many times. We almost designed what was going to happen, month after month. And yet, we have not been able to intervene to stop what is being, on the one hand, a mockery of President Kabila towards his own people, but also a mockery of his commitments to the European institutions. We have to repeat to the African countries that democracy is a game of rules that no one can break. And that, in the dialogue that they maintain with us, third countries must be clear that we are not going to compromise with some of the drifts that are taking place, for example, in the Democratic Republic of the Congo or in Gabon. Because the possibility that we sometimes manifest in order not to end up breaking our relations with these countries, with these governments, many times ends up becoming complicity without our wanting it. But we have to break that vicious circle of possibility that ends up being the support of many governments that should not enjoy our trust. Dialogue is necessary because we do not want to abandon neither the Gabonese nor the Congolese, but sanctions, specifically directed at those responsible, must also be part of our action.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, since our previous debate on the DRC last November, I am pleased that there has been some progress in reaching a settlement for fresh elections and the standing—down of President Kabila. The deal reached at the end of December was a breakthrough, and we must praise the work of the Conference of Catholic Bishops in Congo for mediating the talks. There is, however, concern about the pace of progress towards elections. Recent reports of the escape of M23 rebel fighters from Uganda and their crossing into the DRC should also be a cause for alarm, with a risk of a return to fighting in the North Kivu province, which could potentially be exploited by Kabila as grounds for prolonging his DRC presidency.  Similarly, in Gabon we see huge violations of human rights and violence since the flawed presidential elections last August, so justice and reforms are absolutely essential in that country. Of course, the EU must maintain pressure on the Gabonese authorities to prevent a climate of impunity.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, 2016 was in fact a dark year for the sub-Saharan part of Africa. While we saw some positive developments in the western part, such as elections and transitions of power, we have mentioned today some of the countries – and I could add more – that have gone through a very violent period.  What lies ahead of us are more elections in 2007. There will be presidential elections in Angola and people will go to the polls in Kenya, Liberia, Rwanda, Somalia, Sierra Leone, etc. All these elections represent a real challenge for the continent and for the international community, which means of course for the European Union as well. I must say that, if nothing substantial is done, we will be having the same debate in a few months from now.  So the issue is that there is a role to play – with an appropriate political role for the Africans themselves – for the African Union, the international community and the European Union. Commissioner, I appreciate that you have highlighted the repression, the sanctions, the monitoring and all the instruments that we have. You also highlighted one element which I would like to dwell on in a little more detail, which is that we do have human rights defenders, independent social media and vibrant communities in civil society. So our task is to provide them with the necessary support on time and in time. We must have this twofold ambition.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, in Gabon, the elections of last August took place, indeed, in the presence of an observation mission from the European Union, and therefore with the agreement of the government in place. The mission report is damning. Thank you to our colleagues who participated, including because they were the victims of threats. Ali Bongo would have won by 6,000 votes. The results of Haut-Ogooué, province of origin of Mr. Bongo, with a miraculous turnout of 99.93% and an equally miraculous score of 95.47% in his favor, reversed the results. Immediate clashes took place, and reached their climax on September 1 during the sacking of Jean Ping's HQ. There have been many deaths and unbelievable human rights violations that continue. The mission did not draw the consequences of these findings, no doubt due to the implicit recognition of the results by the French government. So we can ask for sanctions, an independent investigation, a political dialogue, but first we must denounce the result of these rigged elections, this is the best way to proceed. This is the respect we owe the Gabonese people.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, we still have two countries, but I would say that it is a bit double standards, two measures. Why? Because I appreciated, Commissioner, what you said about the Republic of Congo. I find that there has been - one could say - a good point for Europe, because, faced with the coup that Joseph Kabila wanted to make to stay in power, we now learn that, thanks to diplomatic pressure, the intervention of Europe and the sanctions taken, it gives up and that, as you indicated, a process will be implemented. Even if it is fragile, it does exist, and we must be vigilant. On the other hand, in Gabon, I find that Europe has been quite absent, perhaps also because the French presidency is not dynamic enough to show the aberrations that have taken place in these elections. Ms. Gabrielle's report is very clear. It shows that there was ballot stuffing and that the results are completely aberrant. This is where Europe must intervene, to take sanctions. What I have heard about the Gabonese is that they no longer want travel visas for Ali Bongo's family; for the members of the government, those responsible for the coup and the repression, they want a ban on residence and movement in the European Union, a ban on aerial flights and a freeze of assets in Europe. If we do that, it will weaken the regime, and we expect the population to explode. At the same time, as you said, we must encourage an independent investigation into the post-electoral violence, because this must not go unpunished, but Europe must be more active at the level of Gabon. .

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, if there are two countries in sub-Saharan Africa that need great attention from the European Union, and perhaps from the whole civilized world, they are the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Gabon. As for the Congo, there is certainly a lot of concern about the implementation of the New Year's Eve agreements, a great result which, however, must be pursued with the cooperation and attention of international authorities and international institutions, given that it is so. pacification between these opposing factions is difficult and the release of political prisoners is proceeding very slowly and suspiciously. It seems to me, as the Episcopal Conference rightly denounces, a fundamental element in clarifying the real intentions of the old government. As for Gabon, I would say that there is concern about the continuing violence and I believe that we must also shed light on the electoral fraud and the holding of elections in these countries, which represent a common negative fact.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr Chairman! Failure to respect the rule of law, the constitution, and the fundamental rights of citizens are actions that contribute to state instability and conflicts. President Kabila's tight grip on power has led to bloody suppression of peaceful demonstrations, persecution of the opposition and restriction of media freedom. It is true that an agreement has been negotiated between Kabila and some of the opposition to hold credible elections in Congo this year, but unfortunately the president has not signed it yet. In Gabon, presidential elections were held in a chaotic manner, and the numerous irregularities reported by observation missions undermine their result. The effects of Ali Bongo's swearing-in as president were tragic: the country is in crisis, there have been numerous outbreaks of violence, arrests and restrictions on freedom of speech. I would like to point out that the situation in Gabon and the DRC has serious implications for other Central African countries and poses a threat to the stability of the region, so the authorities of both countries must establish an open dialogue with representatives of the opposition and conduct objective investigations into the violence and human rights violations related to the elections.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Ali Bongo manipulated the results of the presidential elections in Gabon. He is therefore not the legitimate president of this country. In frustration, he attacked the opposition camp. There were deaths and injuries. He established a regime of suppression and fear in the country. Parliament calls on the European Union to be ready to support the desire for democracy, justice and freedom of the population, and especially of the youth, in Gabon. We demand that the European Union use all the instruments it possesses to punish those responsible, starting with Ali Bongo and others from his team and his government. I think that the European Union must have the courage to take direct and effective measures, for example banning these officials from traveling or staying in the territory of the European Union, as well as freezing of their assets. This is exactly what Ali Bongo’s entourage fears the most: that he will no longer be able to enjoy the privileges and wealth resulting from the corruption, fraud and exploitation of the people of Gabon. I am convinced that we will act and I also hope that France will not block such steps and measures.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Congo was eliminated in the final round of the Africa Cup last Sunday, to the regret of the soccer-mad Congolese. But of course the people have other concerns. The country has been out of the championships of democratic countries for much longer. And unlike football, where defeat always has various causes, the reason for the failure of the Congolese state lies with its leaders. Coach Kabila, to use football terms again, irresponsibly holds on to power and history teaches us that a solution can never be found with a leader who has lost the trust of his own people and the fundamentals. of the constitution and democracy. An agreement was reached with the bishops' conference. Pending elections, the government must be led by the opposition. But Kabila no longer complies with this agreement and refuses to appoint the prime minister appointed by Étienne Tshisekedi. However, Kabila is not the solution to the problem, he is the cause. Stability and tranquility can only return when it disappears from the political scene and makes way. The question is whether that will happen. I therefore repeat my urgent question: Will the EU pursue effective sanctions against Kabila and his entourage?

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The debate that we are holding today and the vote that will take place tomorrow have a double objective: on the one hand, to express the concern of this Parliament about the situation of instability and violence that these countries are experiencing - the High Representative has already referred to this , the Council of Ministers of the Union and, as the Commissioner reminded us, the Security Council of the United Nations - and, on the other, to affirm the coherence of the electoral observation missions of the European Union, which are a flagship of our project and that have generated respect, prestige and credibility. For this reason, we must reject the pressures and threats that have been placed on the European Union's electoral observation mission, chaired by our colleague, Mrs. Gabriel, and mobilize, Mr. President, all our efforts to ensure the stability of this region, of these countries, which are key to Central Africa and the Great Lakes region.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Mr President, the current situation shows a deep crisis of democracy in Central Africa. Several countries are marked by electoral irregularities or, quite simply, the indefinite postponement of elections. I would like to stress the need to ensure the separation of powers in all countries. Without independence and transparency, democracy in Gabon cannot function properly. I denounce the murderous repression by the security forces of peaceful demonstrations. We must put the authors of these tragedies in front of their responsibilities. The leaders must listen to the grievances of their people and I call on the Council of the European Union to quickly take targeted sanctions against all those responsible for electoral fraud and irregularities, especially in Gabon. These people have many ties to Europe. This is why the freezing of their assets and the restrictions on their travel will affect them directly. With regard to Gabon specifically, I also strongly condemn the lack of transparency in the elections, noted in the final report of the electoral observation mission. I call on the Gabonese authorities to implement all the recommendations, in particular the reform of the electoral system. We must not allow Ali Bongo, the president, to let the political crisis rot, as happened in Burundi. Moreover, I ask the Gabonese authorities to formally deny the allegations of corruption by members of the mission, so as to restore the image of probity of the European institutions. As for the DRC, I end by saying that the elections must now be organized as soon as possible and before the end of 2017 so that, finally, Kabila can leave power and hand it over peacefully to the new authorities.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr. President, DRC and Gabon: two countries facing a major political blockage and a deterioration in the security and human rights situation. I regret that it was impossible to adopt a joint report on the limit of presidential terms at the last ACP-EU plenary assembly. Our message must be clear: respect for the constitution and the law is non-negotiable. There is one thing in common between the situations in the DRC and Gabon: they are two presidents who cling to power, either by violating the term of office or by defrauding during elections. The EU should focus on supporting political dialogue between power and opposition, and focus on prevention by making greater use of the tool of political dialogue under the Cotonou Agreement. Domnule președinte, profit că vorbim despre statul de drept și vă cer să vă vă solidarizați cu cetățenii care în București manifestă tot pentru statul de drept, de data asta în țara dumneavoastră. Mulțumesc pentru atenție.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, many things have already been said, but I want to emphasize that the 2016 elections in Gabon and the Democratic Republic of Congo confirmed the poor health of the rule of law in some countries on the African continent.We have put Gabon and the Democratic Republic of Congo under observation and I must say that, if on the one hand the negotiations mediated by the Congolese Conference of Catholic Bishops, which have led to the signing of a political agreement under which Kabila undertakes toto resign after the elections to be held in 2017, the situation in Gabon, on the other hand, appears very far from reaching a real compromise.I believe that, from this point of view, the European Union must be strongly committed to safeguarding the democratic aspirations of the citizens of Congo and Gabon and strongly condemn the threats, aggressions and the use of force.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent agreement that paves the way for peaceful elections by 2017 in the Democratic Republic of Congo is, finally, after a period of serious tensions, good news for this country of fundamental importance for the region of the Great Lakes and for all of Africa. In recent years, Congo has faced a situation of social and political insecurity, which the civilian population has suffered dramatically, with sudden internal migrations or to neighboring countries: a process that must be blocked if we do not want to find ourselves facing yet another humanitarian catastrophe. It is absolutely necessary that Europe and the international community work for the respect of the agreements, the national pacification of the country and to favor the establishment of a democratic political system that allows alternation in power, in compliance with the constitution. This is the basic and essential condition for pulling the country out of the difficult and dangerous situation in which it finds itself.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the UN Security Council has repeatedly expressed its concern about the human rights situation in both the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Gabon, and both countries have entered a period of destabilization. In particular, the security and human rights situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo continues to deteriorate, with Kabila's decision to extend his term in office provoking a storm of opposition. At the same time, the recent announcement of the re-election of President Ali Bongo for a third term in Gabon caused violent incidents in the country, with 1100 arrests and three deaths. Both countries face a problem of police violence, which is now hitting activists and dissidents, and the numerous arrests recorded raise serious concerns about whether the rule of law still exists. It is now clear that the international community must intervene in both of these countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been a very rich exchange and I am grateful to the honourable Members for their very valuable interventions. I believe it will be an important reassurance to the people of both Gabon and the Democratic Republic of Congo that this House is following developments with such attention and cares sincerely about their destiny.  From this debate, I conclude that we all share a common interest in engaging with the Gabonese Government in determining whether there is a genuine willingness to implement the Election Observation Mission’s recommendations on electoral reforms and on the investigation of human rights violations. If this is not the case, we will draw the consequences.  As regards the Democratic Republic of Congo, the European Union will remain vigilant and ready to use all instruments available to ensure that a transition period will end with democratic and transparent elections.  Finally, with the current volatile situation in both countries, let me remind you of the statements issued by the European Union, stressing that all parties must refrain from violence, from incitement or provocation, or from the use of excessive force. We will continue following both countries’ situation closely in every dimension, as I am sure you will do, too. I can assure you that we will continue to use all the tools at our disposal to assist in bringing a durable solution to the current crisis. We undertake to keep you fully informed of developments.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.The vote, to be held on Thursday, 2 February 2017, recorded seven motions for resolutions, tabled on the basis of a statement by: ECR, ALDE, GUE, S&D, EFDD, Verts / ALE and EPP.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- On the assumption that specific EU funds exist to help democratic development in third countries.It is impossible not to notice that in countries like Congo and Gabon the political and social situation is dramatic, there is practically a total absence of democracy.The current governments have taken power in a way that is anything but democratic, causing very strong social tensions and protests.The EU, having the tools, should act to help these two countries emerge from this profound democratic crisis.

name: David McALLISTER
text: written. - On December 19 last year, the term of office of the President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Joseph Kabila, officially ended. Even before the presidential elections at the end of November 2016, which were deliberately delayed, and afterwards, protests, some of them violent, broke out in the capital Kinshasa and other cities. The unrest in the country could lead to renewed influx of refugees within Africa and an increasing number of migrants in Europe. The EU is therefore rightly committed to resolving this conflict diplomatically. With this motion for a resolution on the crisis of the rule of law in the DRC, the European Parliament has taken a clear position against any use of force. Gabon suffers from a similar situation. Presidential elections took place there, with the result that President Ali Bongo won the election in August 2016. However, there are serious indications of election fraud, particularly in his home province of Haut-Ogooué. His challenger, Jean Ping, received the most votes in all other provinces. Only the result from the home province of Bongos ultimately led to his victory. In the DRK as well as in Gabon, the respective presidents are only concerned with maintaining power. The European Parliament rightly condemns the resulting violations of the rule of law and human rights and urges constitutional elections.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing.- As part of the debate on human rights issues, we have today addressed the difficult political situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Gabon, with a period of political instability and violence in both countries, especially in the context of the presidential elections in both countries.Street demonstrations broke out in both countries, which were violently suppressed, leading to the deaths of many people.The authorities there cracked down sharply against members of the opposition and civil society who expressed their opposition to the current government.In the European Parliament's joint resolution, we regret the loss of life, our deep concern at the increasingly volatile situation in both countries, and we urge the relevant authorities to respect their international obligations, guarantee human rights and the rule of law.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on zero tolerance for female genital mutilation (2017/2524 (RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, female genital mutilation (FGM) is one of the most serious grievous forms of violence against women. I am strongly committed to eliminating this practice. I stand for zero tolerance for it and I call on all of you to join me in this. I welcome the opportunity to discuss it with you today, ahead of the International Day of Zero Tolerance for FGM on 6 February. The estimated figures are really shocking, with half a million women and girls being victims of FGM in Europe, and 125 million worldwide. Thousands of girls are at risk of FGM. I would like to update you today on what the Commission has done in this area since we last discussed this serious issue in 2015. We have been following the 2013 action plan, the Communication ‘Towards the elimination of FGM’, and its five defined priorities: improving data collection and knowledge, prevention, prosecution, protection and eliminating FGM worldwide. In the strategic engagement for gender equality we commit ourselves to continue with the implementation of the measures set out in the communication.  I am proud to announce that this week a complex web-based knowledge platform, which serves as an online EU-wide multilingual resource and education centre for professionals, has been launched. It provides easily—accessible and culturally—appropriate information and support to professionals from diverse backgrounds across the EU. The aim is to raise awareness of FGM, to effectively deliver victim support and to protect women and girls living with, or at risk of, FGM. We reach out to all relevant professionals, including nurses, doctors, midwives, lawyers, judges, prosecutors, police officers, asylum officers, teachers, social workers, child protection professionals and also reporters and journalists. This project has gone live, also due the commitment of Parliament to this cause. I count on your further support to ensure a wide dissemination of the information on this new tool.  In addition, together with the European Institute for Gender Equality, we have developed a methodology to estimate the risk of FGM in different Member States, and we have funded a prevalence study to get more understanding of the phenomenon. We are working on the revision of the EU guidelines on the promotion and protection of the rights of the child. Preventive and protective measures against FGM are foreseen to be part of the recommendations towards Member States, notably with regard to children in migration. We are enforcing a correct and timely implementation of the Victims’ Rights Directive, which is of particular importance for victims of gender-based violence, including FGM, as it ensures access to free-of-charge and confidential specialist support services, including trauma support and counselling. In the proposed amendments to the Common European Asylum System we strengthen the safeguards for protection of persons with specific needs, including women applicants who have experienced gender-based harm. Access to medical care, legal support and appropriate trauma counselling and psychosocial care is to be ensured. The European Asylum Support Office has developed a practical support tool for the identification of persons with special needs and applies a training module on gender, gender identity and sexual orientation to officers.  Last, but not least, we are funding transnational projects that combat harmful practices such as FGM, both in the EU and beyond. In concrete terms, this means EUR 4.5 million in the Rights Equality and Citizenship Programme and EUR 11 million in the UNICEF Joint Programme on the abandonment of FGM.  Last year, I visited NGOs that help victims and support women who have undergone FGM and that focus on the prevention of girls from being cut. I have spoken to the women and men dedicated to ending this practice and listened to their concerns. One of the recurring issues was the prevailing lack of knowledge and understanding of professionals. This impedes girls and women in Europe from getting the best possible care and from having all their rights respected. If a doctor is surprised or horrified when an infibulated woman visits him or her, this can cause shame and certainly it would be a hurdle for visiting again and receiving appropriate care. If a police officer believes this is just a part of the culture, rather than a serious infringement of rights, coming forward can become so much harder. If a teacher has never heard of FGM, it will be impossible to pick up any signals and prevent a young girl from being cut. Hence, it is important to encourage all relevant professionals to act accordingly and provide care, protection and prevention. I believe the FGM platform we are launching these days, calling to unite to end FGM will be an important contribution to end this practice in Europe.  Finally, as you know, I have dedicated this year as a year of focused actions to combat violence against women. I will continue to fight harmful practices such as FGM as part of it, and count on your support.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what we denounce today is a real horror experienced by 500,000 women who live in Europe today, in the name of alleged traditional, social, cultural and religious practices . Around the world, according to WHO figures, some 140 million women, young women, young girls and little girls have undergone one or another form of female genital mutilation. February 6 - as you said, Commissioner - is the international day dedicated to zero tolerance against female genital mutilation. The European Parliament has always been committed with great persistence and constancy, over the past years, in order to alert public opinion, to show determination and commitment in the fight against this absolutely intolerable form of violence against women, of which - as we now know well, all the studies agree - the effects on health and well-being, but also on training and education paths, on professional paths, are very much felt. long in the victims. Female genital mutilation truly constitutes an intolerable attack on human dignity, on the integrity of the female body. You have told us, Commissioner, a very precise point on the actions undertaken, as well as on the platform which has just been installed. We thank you for this very precise point, for the intensity of the commitment, the mobilization that you show. We continue to support you, to encourage you, to always go further and, in particular, to put pressure - if you will allow me to use that expression - on the Member States which have not yet, as far as they are concerned, very concretely and in a very organized way, declined a voluntary action plan against this practice, once again, intolerable.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner. Today this Parliament has to serve as a speaker to denounce a practice, to denounce torture of women, a violation of human rights such as female genital mutilation; a reality that affects more than half a million women in the European Union and about 140 million women in the world. We therefore welcome the proposals made by the Commissioner on how to prevent, how to fight female genital mutilation, because I believe that it is essential to hold public institutions accountable at all levels. And let's not forget that we are not talking exclusively about women in the European Union, that we can also contribute to fighting this practice at the international level. For this reason, in the foreign policy and cooperation policy of the European Union we take this situation into account in order to eradicate this reality. And let us also bear in mind one thing, and that is that traditions and culture have a limit and that limit is respect for human rights, respect for women's rights.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! More than 140 million women worldwide - this is official data - have suffered from genital mutilation, more than half a million women in the European Union. This is an amazing problem: in the 21st century, women experience such suffering! There is a Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality in the European Parliament. Would you like to know whether this problem has found its place in the opinion on respect for human rights that this committee prepared last year? You will probably think: surely yes, a large part of this opinion was probably devoted to this barbarism. Well, I want to lead you out of the error: not a single word about the mutilation of women. Let's deal with these real problems. These mutilated women are screaming and asking for help. Let us not meet at seminars and debates - beautiful ladies from rich countries sympathetic to these circumcised women. Let us take real action. Let's talk about what is most important to these women. They are waiting for our help, they are crying - women and little girls who also experience this suffering. Let's not talk, let's do, let's help! Let us notice women's problems in a real way. I appeal to my colleagues on the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality: you know this opinion and you have not tabled amendments on this issue there.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I think we can all agree here that there is no reason for young girls to suffer genital mutilation. There is no place for such a practice in any civilised society. This so—called tradition, like many others, is nothing but a violation of women’s rights which goes back many centuries, and we can no longer tolerate it happening in the 21st century. We should be committed every day, not just on the International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation as such.  The EU has been advancing on this file. However, we should strengthen the instruments at our disposal. As regards supporting victims of FGM, the provisions of the EU Directive on Victims’ Rights apply to all victims of crime, including FGM. The signing of the Directive on Victims’ Rights meant that tremendous progress was made in strengthening victims’ rights. The European Parliament, as co—legislator, had as a clear objective to seriously recognise the needs of victims in criminal proceedings. We now need to focus on the implementation of this important piece of EU legislation, which should have been transposed into national law by all EU Member States by November 2015. However, progress made on the transposition front is very disappointing. I would like to ask the Commissioner about the state of play of implementation. Another complementary tool in the fight against FGM was the Istanbul Convention as it was the first treaty to recognise that FGM exists in Europe and needs to be systematically addressed. I would therefore repeat my call on the Commission and on the Council to undertake whatever is needed to make the EU accession to the Istanbul Convention happen as soon as possible.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the cutting of women’s genitals and clitorises is a very serious form of violence against women. As colleagues have said, approximately 130 to 140 million women and girls have been victims of FGM. FGM is older than Christianity or Islam. It has nothing to do with religion, but it has all to do with patriarchy. It is also symptomatic for me that the clitoris almost everywhere has been systematically neglected and erased. Many people don’t even know what it looks like, and the dictionaries in 2017 still get it wrong. This is what it looks like, a real-sized clitoris. This is a simple 3D print that I think every woman should be proud to be in possession of, because knowing your body is also a way to take back control, to take back power. This is being used by many FGM activists that fight against FGM, and it gives us the power to protect it.  Saying a firm ‘no’ to FGM for me also means that we have to have protective laws and we have to provide strong support to the grassroots organisations that work on this. But saying no to FGM also demands that we say no to all forms of patriarchal control of our bodies. Today we see the attacks on women’s bodies from the likes of Trump with his awful gag rule that wants to threaten women’s sexual and reproductive health and rights worldwide.  Colleagues, Commission, our message must be clear. These struggles are linked. We say no to FGM, support grassroots organisations. We say no to all forms of patriarchal control over our bodies, and we say yes to sexual freedom and choice for women and for proper sexuality education where we can learn about our rights, our women’s rights and our bodies, and about the clitoris.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, defending women’s and girls’ rights has actually become even more urgent in the last week, most recently when Donald Trump signed an executive order to reinstate the Global Gag Rule. This rule will not only cut funding for family planning organisations that give consultations on safe abortion but will also cut funding for very important things like HIV prevention, medical care and helping victims of female genital mutilation (FGM). Now is the time for the European Union to step up and say that it is going to counterbalance what is being cut by the American administration, not only financially but also organisationally, and is going to support giving consultation and all medical care to victims of female genital mutilation, because female genital mutilation is a deeply traumatising form of sexualised violence. We need to step up our efforts to fight against all forms of violence against women. I must say that I am very surprised by our colleagues on the right, who are now claiming that we never speak about FGM because actually the ratification of the Istanbul Convention would be a very important step to do exactly that. So once again the International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation should be a reminder to you Commissioner, and also to all Member States, to ratify the Istanbul Convention and take these very decisive steps not only against FGM, but against all forms of violence against women.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, we all agree that female genital mutilation is atrocious and barbaric practice and that it goes against our cultures and our European civilization. According to the latest figures provided by Unicef ​​in 2016, 200 million women and girls are victims in the world, ie 70 million more than in 2014. In France, we estimate the number of women and girls victims of this barbaric practice between 45,000 and 60,000. This is intolerable. I imagine that, like me, you want these dangerous practices with very serious consequences for the women and girls who are victims to stop for good. But what is your answer? In Ms Honeyball's report on the status of refugee women, in paragraph 15, it says: "Protection must be guaranteed for victims of female genital mutilation (FGM) through systematic asylum procedures". You who get involved in everything in countries that ask you nothing, you are once again showing cowardice on this subject and doing nothing to stem this phenomenon in the countries concerned. In reality, what you are going to create is a new pathway to immigration. Encouraging massive immigration, as the European Union has done for decades, without requiring the assimilation of populations, amounts to establishing a communitarianism which does not allow us to protect all these women victims of genital mutilation. Denouncing genital mutilation in this Chamber is not enough, just as it is not enough to send an envelope of ten million euros to Egypt to put an end to this practice. Let us leave it to the Member States, whose exclusive competence it is, to act. Let us give all the help we can to the countries which fight against these barbaric practices and stop this destructive migration policy, so much for women victims of mutilation than for our countries.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, a case of female genital mutilation (FGM) in England is reported every 109 minutes. Just think of what that means in terms of incidence. The fact that there such a level of FGM is an absolute outrage, but practices based on cultural or quasi-religious beliefs are difficult to eradicate, and when family members are involved it is actually near impossible. When authorities want to stop FGM being undertaken, but in many instances are prevented from doing so, then a resolution to the problem becomes that much more difficult. In the United Kingdom, I welcome and applaud the fact that schoolteachers, border officers and many public servants are now at the forefront of resources to stop FGM. This is not an EU matter: this is an issue for Member States, whose internal systems are best placed and can be directly resourced to thwart and stop this cruel and unimaginable horror – an affront to human decency. The European Union call for zero tolerance for FGM is, as always, words. Nothing that this particular proposal identifies can be delivered because it all contradicts the EU stance on human rights, that is to say interference in travel freedoms, the right to exercise cultural practices, recognition of cultures and societies. But Member States can actually do something and that is what I want to see happen. If zero tolerance is achieved, it will be achieved by national governments.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, female genital mutilation is a crime and it should be treated as such. These barbaric practices, as my colleagues have said, still affect millions of girls around the world and in Europe, and more are at risk. We are talking about serious breaches of the rights of girls, some of whom are aged as young as two years old, causing physical and psychological damage. Commissioner, I welcome your commitment and action. It is time for the Member States to do more to enforce the existing legislation, to ratify and enforce the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women, and to accelerate EU accession to the Istanbul Convention. The Convention specifically criminalises female genital mutilation and provides specific measures for prevention and protection of victims, such as the training of judges and healthcare for victims. To eradicate FGM we need to eradicate impunity and ensure that the perpetrators, and even the guilty parents, are prosecuted. Let us say it loud and clear: child abuse and gender-based violence can never be justified by any religion, any tradition or any culture. The EU must do more in its external and humanitarian action. We have to support awareness-raising, education on child rights and the medical risks, and support the adoption of national laws banning this practice. We also have to work with activists in civil society at grassroots level to empower women and girls to speak up in their communities. It is about recovering their dignity and it is about respecting the integrity of girls’ bodies. I will finish by saying this: let us continue to join forces in tirelessly repeating that we have to stand up for zero tolerance for female genital mutilation, for as long as it takes.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Dear Colleagues, in 2015, in Kenya, Barack Obama said the following: “There is no excuse for sexual assault or domestic violence. There is no reason for young girls to undergo genital mutilation. ” These traditions may be centuries old, said Barack Obama, but they have no place in the 21st century. On February 6, we mark another International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation and the problem persists. It has now been a year since the European Union reiterated its commitment to the elimination of this practice. This hidden violence has nothing to do with culture. It is pure torture. There is a need for a commitment from the international community to criminalize this practice in all countries. Whoever treats their women and children badly cannot, in fact, be a credible partner. I thank the Commissioner for indicating what has been done, but I have some specific questions that I would like to see answered. What results are there in the communities that carry out this practice? How is the collection and processing of data inside and outside the European Union? And what punishment measures are being planned? Finally, what strength do we have, in terms of foreign policy, to combat precisely this scourge?

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: - I am pleased that we have the debate here today on female genital mutilation. Europe must not avert this problem. It is a form of violence against women that does not only take place outside our European borders. It has already been mentioned here, research shows that unfortunately it also occurs in many European Member States, including here in Belgium itself. 2017 is the European Year of Combating Violence against Women and if we really want to act on this, we must also work for girls and women who are victims of genital mutilation. These are people who even flee their country for this. We also need better care for the girls and women who have been victims of female genital mutilation and I am therefore very pleased that my proposal for a pilot project for clitoral reconstruction for women who have been victims of female genital mutilation is European funding this year Will get. So thank you for that.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, female genital mutilation without medical reasons is an unacceptable, anachronistic and barbaric practice which must not only be condemned but also completely eliminated. It is a shame for civilized humanity, in the 21st century, to allow women's human rights to be violated and to tolerate states that treat girls and women as animals, to accept or be indifferent to their abuse and biological and psychological problems that arise in them, problems from which no one knows when and if they will ever get rid of. According to available data, 140 million girls and women in Africa, the Middle East and 500,000 in the European Union have fallen victim to this barbaric practice. In what sense of logic and morality do we allow girls to be deprived of the sacred right to motherhood for these women? As the European Union, we must act immediately so that the perpetrators of these crimes are punished by example and this unacceptable custom is completely eradicated from all countries of the world.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, female genital mutilation consists of partially or totally amputating the clitoris. If we visualize it, we will understand more clearly the barbarity suffered by two hundred million women and girls in more than thirty countries. I recognize that it is not easy to face this complex web of discrimination, customs, ignorance and religion that enslaves so many innocent girls who suffer mutilation in silence that will mark them for the rest of their lives. It is necessary to change the mentality to achieve the abandonment of the knife, which endangers not only physical but also psychological integrity. Our action must not be aggressive, but must aim at raising awareness of the communities that practice it and at education, since it is the best way to combat this scourge, which has a very strong cultural resistance. The women assume it, but the drivers are the men, obviously because they do not mutilate them. Unfortunately, a woman who is not mutilated is considered impure, as a result of which she suffers from social exclusion. I add my voice to all zero-tolerance campaigns against genital mutilation, which, although it is practiced mostly outside Europe, also affects us here, since there are many girls at risk in our countries, due to family beliefs, although these cases they don't always come to light. Although there are signs of hope, since there are African countries that have prohibited ablation by law, the reality is that it is still practiced clandestinely. The road is long, but all the effort is little to restore the dignity of so many defenseless girls, victims of a very serious violation of the rights of the child, or rather, the rights of girls.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I am proud to stand here with colleagues to reaffirm that the EU will continue to fight to end violence against women and girls, including the appalling practice of female genital mutilation (FGM), and this is another issue where European cooperation makes a real difference. We know that every year 180 000 young women and girls are at risk of FGM, so tackling that phenomenon must be a women-led effort in intercultural dialogue, actively supported by men in the community. We must support grassroots efforts working directly with communities, with mothers, grandmothers and sisters, to change attitudes and break a harmful cycle. We need to fund and empower the social services needed to support victims as well as community activists. The fight against FGM must be a vehicle for women’s empowerment and social inclusion, and I would like to extend my thanks to all the civil society organisations, and especially the End FGM network, who work on the ground and bring their advocacy and expertise to the European Parliament. Without you we could not do our work.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: - Mr President, the figures are shocking, yes, but today we are also the voice of the 200 million women and girls who have undergone some form of female genital mutilation. There is no excuse, neither cultural nor religious, which can justify this. First, we all pay attention to the laws. Yes, legal measures have been adopted by a number of countries. They should be encouraged, but above all we must ensure implementation and awareness. On the implementation side: It is absolutely necessary to continue to insist on data collection. This will give us an ever clearer idea of ​​the extent of the problem, it will allow us to identify good practices, it will allow us to put forward the word "prevention". I put a lot of emphasis on awareness raising and information campaigns. Let us not lose sight of these unconventional instruments, which have positive repercussions: plays in the villages, awareness-raising carried out among men by imams in Mali, comics in Senegal. Raising awareness among girls and boys from an early age, fostering dialogue between generations, providing training to avoid medicalized genital mutilation, these are some of the challenges we can take up. Finally, a question: how could we collaborate with regional organizations, such as the African Union, in order to create synergies in this common fight? Real will and coordination of actions are essential. The key word is "zero tolerance".

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Mr. President, "I am circumcised and I do not want my daughter to undergo this practice in her turn." “My wife gave birth to a baby girl, how can I protect her from excision? We would like to protect her, but my mother-in-law insists that she be circumcised. " These testimonies are real and such practices are unfortunately perpetuated. In 2017, refusing excision remains an act of bravery. The excisor who buries her knife, the mother who says no to her in-laws, the doctor who refuses to be an accomplice: all of them take a risk by saying no to mutilation. Social pressure is very strong in the name of tradition. I am not going to recall here the unbearable horror of these mutilations. Nor will I recall that this Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize to a remarkable man, Dr Denis Mukwege. Here, I humbly want to say bravo to all those women and men who said: “No, these traditions will not pass through me”. Our turn to help them by saying no. Commissioner, these women are also counting on you. Offer them solutions now, because as you said, there is still a long way to go.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman! Today we are discussing an unequivocally shameful phenomenon, and not only because of the values ​​that we believe in here in Europe. We are talking about a phenomenon that is de facto related to the restriction of women's sexual freedom, and this restriction is most often justified by tradition and religion, but in fact, in my opinion, this justification is most often untrue. In fact, it is about such barbaric domination of men over women. These are men who want to have this sphere of female sexuality only for themselves and, using religion or tradition, cultivate the barbarity we are talking about. But the more difficult it is to fight it, because it is very difficult to win against something that is cultivated under the banner of religion and tradition. That is why actions are needed in various fields, on various levels, not only legal, because in fact, I am sorry to say that the law will always lose against tradition and religion. What is needed is social education, what is needed is the involvement of civil society and non-governmental organizations, but also involving the countries in which this practice is carried out in joint activities of the European Union and the Member States. This is what I would expect from the European Commission.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the practice of genital mutilation is a serious form of violence against women and girls, it is an unacceptable violation of their right to physical integrity.Such practices must never be justified by religion, culture or tradition.Commissioner, I welcome the Commission's commitment to facilitating the exchange of experience and good practice on genital mutilation between Member States.The use of European Union funds to prevent these practices plays a vital role in protecting women and girls, identifying victims and taking action.Preventing genital mutilation is an international human rights obligation for every Member State and a firm approach and maximum vigilance are needed to combat these practices.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, half a million women and girls in Europe live with the physical and psychological consequences of genital mutilation practices, yet many Member States still do not have an action plan on this. A proposal for a legislative act is needed to establish preventive measures against all forms of violence against women and, as indicated in the Stockholm program, a strategy that includes further joint and structured action plans to put an end to female genital mutilation. Member States should make use of existing mechanisms, for example Directive 2012/29 / EU, to protect women and children and to prosecute, convict and punish those responsible for female genital mutilation offenses, even if committed beyond state borders. interested member. It is therefore necessary that the principle of extraterritoriality be included in the provisions of all Member States in the area of ​​criminal law so that the offense can be prosecuted in the same way in the 28 Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, according to a UNICEF survey, at least 200 million girls and women have had their genitals mutilated in thirty countries around the world. Somalia, Guinea, Djibouti, Sierra Leone, Egypt and Eritrea are the countries where this unacceptable and inhumane tactic is most often carried out. The only positive development is the latest in Egypt, where the government has decided to toughen its stance against this barbaric custom and enacted a law that provides for seven years in prison for those who perform such operations. In Europe, despite the explicit ban on this practice, the number of women who have had their genitals mutilated is estimated at half a million. Sometimes genital mutilation goes hand in hand with forced marriages, something that is seen in the UK and elsewhere. The European Union must take steps to completely eliminate this kind of inhuman treatment.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, just like the last time when we had a heated discussion, today I feel very strong support from Parliament for all the strong and efficient measures we have taken against this barbarian habit – or to call it by its proper name, crime and torture. Thank you for this, because it is very encouraging.  I would like to comment on some of your proposals or comments. I spoke to many professionals, including the people working in the FGM Network, which was mentioned here by Ms Ward, and they always speak about very complex phenomena. Of course, I always say that we should do more law enforcement, and fight against this crime by means of criminal justice. But I always hear horrible stories about the custom of taking a girl to Africa for a summer holiday and then doing it to her there in Africa. When she comes back and the parents or the granny are on European soil could and should be prosecuted, the professionals tell me it would be further trauma for the girl. There are many stories of this kind, so we need to understand very well the complexity of this phenomenon and to use really efficient measures which will bring about a difference. We speak about ‘zero tolerance’: there are several factors which are necessary. The first thing is political will. We must be absolutely clear that there is no excuse for it, based on some something like tradition or culture. This must be absolutely clear to everyone – all politicians, all influential people must know that this is a crime which must be punished. To my taste, we suffer from too much relativism in many other important things. Here, we should not do this.  The second thing – and I spoke about it before – is that professionals, from teachers to nurses, doctors, police and prosecutors, must understand what this is about and how to fight against it and engage with it. Thirdly, the law enforcement side, which I have also mentioned: there must be no excuse, but there must also be proper provision of care to the victims, because this must be balanced. And the fourth thing, which I find the most difficult but also the most important factor, is that we here with a kind of taboo. In violence against women, we fight against the fact that quite a large part of our societies think that it is normal. With FGM, we see that we have to fight against a taboo. I myself go to many conferences, I speak to many people, and I always mention FGM because it must be heard by hundreds of thousands of people in Europe, and I always receive the same reaction: ‘What? FGM in Europe in the 21st century?’ There is such a low awareness about this phenomenon that we have to do more, and I agree with some of the comments I heard here that it must not be at our seminars and conferences where the people who know about it are participating. We must not invade the open door – we have to address the communities where this barbaric habit is being carried out.  As you know we are now running a campaign against violence against women. To my disappointment, the Member States where we have identified high numbers – France, Portugal, UK, Sweden, Belgium, Cyprus, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain, and I am naming without shaming but we must be aware of where this happening – have not asked for money to fight against this. But I don’t want to say that they are not doing anything, because they have their own policy, and it was said here clearly that first of all it is the task of the Member States to take the necessary action against this. But, coming back to the need to address the communities, we have opened the call for proposals for the NGOs, and I will encourage the NGOs from these countries which I mentioned to ask for the funding and to go more closely into the communities and to work on the ground. This is to be closed on 8 March. There is EUR 6 million. If you know about those NGOs who could help, please let them know. This is now a practical thing.  I know I have been speaking for too long, but I will finalise quickly. I have mentioned the Member States where we see high figures, but the statistics are still very inaccurate. We still do not have proper data collection, and this is also connected with the taboo factor. We have to be much better, and as I said we are working with the Agency on Gender Equality. We are also pushing for the adoption of the Istanbul Convention. I will talk about it tomorrow with Maltese Minister Ms Helena Dalli, who is very much engaged with it.
