I hope we can achieve it at the March Council or in June. We have the signatures of 28 Member States, but the ratification of only 14, unfortunately.  Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your support. FGM is one of those matters where I will always feel we do not do enough, that we need to do more, and that if we do it together it will be more successful. Thank you very much for your future cooperation.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Commissioner Jourová, thank you very much, especially for your last speech.Every minute we listened to you was a won minute for us.In this room, you received not only the support you asked for - you received encouragement, even an appeal, and it was beyond divisions.Please act, as long as it is effective.Thank you very much.I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing.- On February 6th, the International Day of Female Genital Mutilation is once again marked.It is estimated that there are at least 200 million girls and women who have been the target of this practice, in clear violation of their fundamental rights.In the European Union alone, data from 2013, there are still 180,000 girls who, every year, are at risk of being mutilated.Since 2013, some steps have already been taken.Recently, by way of example, this Parliament called for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention.But much remains to be done: adequate international protection policies, information on national policies, more regular statistics.It is also important to assess the state of implementation of the combat action plan.That is why Parliament must - once again - mark this date and call for a reinforced effort.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - Female genital mutilation is a violation of the fundamental right to life of girls and women, safety, dignity, equality between women and men, non-discrimination, and physical and emotional integrity. Globally, it is estimated that between 100 million and 140 million girls and women have undergone some form of female genital mutilation, and, if current trends continue, another 15 million girls between the ages of 15 and 19 will be subject to this cruelty by 2030. It is essential that the European Executive and the EEAS include the issue of female genital mutilation in the EU's annual dialogues with civil society organizations in partner countries where this practice exists and continue to promote the protection of international gender protection. women at risk of genital mutilation worldwide, in their relations with third countries and in international fora. Close cooperation is also needed with the African Union and the African Group at the UN to adopt new initiatives to strengthen the global fight against female genital mutilation and to support capacity-building initiatives of public and social organizations. civil.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - Female genital mutilation would affect, according to the World Health Organization, 100 to 140 million girls and women in the world, mainly in some African and Asian states. Deeply rooted in certain ancestral traditions, these mutilations constitute an extreme form of discrimination, even persecution, against women and children, since they are usually carried out on young girls under the age of fifteen. This is without counting their sometimes fatal complications since only 18% of them are performed by healthcare professionals. In Europe, half a million women and girls have suffered, or are at risk of suffering, this type of mutilation in the European Union, according to a European Parliament resolution of March 24, 2009. Thus, Madam MP, Malin Björk stressed in an interview dated February 6, 2017 the risk for some migrant women to undergo such mutilations in Europe, unless they have undergone it in their countries of origin. If the overall prevalence of these mutilations tends to decline, their resurgence in Europe underlines the deterioration of the condition of women and calls for an implacable criminal response from national courts.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: written.- Circumcision of girls is a common practice.It happens in Africa, but it is honest to say that girls are also mutilated in Europe.The tradition is appalling and causes lifelong suffering for girls and women.However, the situation is not addressed by waving our finger, but by better training and cooperation.The EU must make the eradication of girl mutilation a top priority in foreign and development policy.This requires close inter-institutional cooperation.Parliament's delegations should have a common line with the Commission, the EEAS and the EU delegations.The message and course of action must be jointly agreed and clear.The aim must be to ban circumcision of girls by law and to eradicate tradition everywhere.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: signed up.- According to the World Health Organization, approximately four million girls suffer from genital mutilation each year.This practice is part of local cultural rituals and customs in various communities or countries in Africa and the Middle East, but unfortunately continues to exist even in places where it is prohibited by national law.More action is needed from the European Commission.This must make development aid conditional on developing countries' efforts to eliminate this barbaric practice.Today, I call on the Commission to pay particular attention to cases taking place in the territory of the Member States and to work closely with local and national authorities to firmly combat this practice.No girl living in the EU should suffer genital mutilation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Every day and in every part of the world, in rich or poor countries, in all age groups and all walks of life, women and girls face violence, especially from men. Female genital mutilation involves all changes and injuries to the female genitalia for non-medical purposes and is one of the most serious human rights violations, causing serious health complications, including fatalities. According to the World Health Organization, between 120 and 140 million women are affected each year, and 3 million girls are at risk. This reflects deep-rooted gender inequalities and represents an extreme form of discrimination against women and girls. At the same time, their right to safety and the right to life are violated when this outrageous act leads to death. In order to prevent and eradicate female genital mutilation in the long term, systematic and coordinated action is needed, with the participation and empowerment of entire communities, to launch a clear social dialogue based on the protection of human rights and the promotion of gender equality. Regardless of the type of violence against women and girls, strong political support and training of society to tackle the problem is also crucial to stop perpetrators once and for all, to ensure security, equality and dignity for women and girls around the world.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Marielle de Sarnez, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 19/2013 on the implementation of the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilization mechanism for bananas,concluded in the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other hand, and amending Regulation (EU) No 20/2013 on the implementation of the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilization mechanism for bananas,concluded in the Agreement establishing an association between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Central America, on the other hand (COM (2015) 0220 - C8-0131 / 2015 - 2015/0112 (COD)) (A8-0277 / 2016).

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, last December our Parliament ratified Ecuador's protocol of accession to the free trade agreement concluded in 2013 between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. The leading banana producer in the world and the leading exporter to the Union, Ecuador will now benefit from a significant reduction in customs duties for its exports to the Union. This obviously changes the situation and risks destabilizing the European banana industry in the long term. However, this plays an essential economic role in the outermost regions of Europe. It is the source of some 37,000 jobs. It should also be remembered that the banana is part of the European list of so-called "sensitive" agricultural products and that it meets high sustainability standards in social, environmental or health matters, standards that are not applied in the production chain. Latin American. In this context, it is therefore very important that European banana producers are better protected. That is why I am very happy that our Parliament's position has been heard and taken into account by the Commission and the Council. I especially thank our curator, Cécilia Malmström. I also want to thank the chairman of our INTA committee, the shadow rapporteurs and the colleagues who have been deeply involved in this dossier. Thanks to all of you, we have a text which constitutes substantial progress and which provides concrete answers to preserve our industry. From now on, producers will not only be better informed, but they will also be more involved in monitoring market developments. The Commission will have to carry out an annual and in-depth study of the situation on the European banana market and that of European producers, including after the mechanism expires. It will also have to involve the Member States and the parties stakeholders, by allowing them to exchange views in the context of ad hoc meetings on developments in the European banana market. This is important and it responds directly to a major demand from producers. This will make it possible to establish a regular dialogue between the stakeholders and the Commission and to address all the concerns of producers, such as the evolution of volumes and the impact of imports on prices and on European production. The Commission will also have to improve its statistical databases in order to allow much more detailed and regular monitoring of the situation on the European banana market, and to make this data more accessible. Finally, and this is very important, an early warning mechanism is created when 80% of the trigger volume of the stabilization mechanism is reached by one of the countries covered by the mechanism. The Commission will now have a legal obligation to inform Parliament and the Council in writing. It should also provide all the statistical data and import volumes for the other eight countries covered, so that stakeholders can have a general overview of the situation and better predict future overruns. If the thresholds are found to be exceeded by one of the countries covered by the mechanism, the Commission will have a legal obligation to act, either by temporarily suspending the preferential rights, or by demonstrating that such an imposition is not required. The Commission will have to carry out a full assessment of the functioning of the mechanism by 1 January 2019, i.e. one year before its expiry. If, at the end of this assessment, it considers that the situation of producers has deteriorated, it will have to extend the period of validity of the mechanism after agreement of the stakeholders. The Commission will also have to continue to conduct annual analyzes of the market situation, of those of producers after 2020, and take action in the event of production degradation.All of these changes will apply to Peru, Colombia, Ecuador, but also to the Central American countries which are parties to the association agreement with the European Union.Our Parliament will be vigilant with regard to the application of the joint declaration which now binds our three institutions and with respect to the commitment made by the Commission during our trilogues to precede any new free trade agreement by a studyimpact on our outermost regions.I hope that this report will be widely adopted tomorrow by our Parliament.We will thus have done useful work for these regions so important to our Europe.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, following Parliament’s consent on 14 December on the Protocol of Accession of Ecuador, I am very pleased to confirm that this agreement has been provisionally applied since 1 January this year. This is good news because a new trade agreement that creates new export opportunities for Ecuador – and of course opportunities for our goods and services – is also very good news for Ecuador. It is the first trade agreement with a developed country, an agreement that respects the level of development in Ecuador, and provides the opportunity for them to diversify the economy, reduce dependency on oil exports and raw materials and create new jobs for Ecuadorians.  I would like to thank the Committee on International Trade, and its rapporteur, Mr Scholz, for the work that it did to make this agreement possible. Since the agreement has been applied, the next step is, of course, to amend the banana stabilisation mechanism as well, and that is what we are debating today. This mechanism needed to be amended to incorporate Ecuador.  I very much welcome the constructive discussions and the agreement that we reached just before Christmas under the leadership of the rapporteur, Mrs de Sarnez, and also the co-rapporteurs, shadow rapporteurs and the Chairman, Mr Lange. The banana stabilisation mechanism, to which imports of bananas from Ecuador will be subject, is a good and efficient mechanism to ensure stability in the EU market in case of a surge in imports of bananas from Ecuador. Mrs de Sarnez gave a very long explanation of its content, but let me just reiterate the main points.  With the amendments proposed by this Parliament, the amending regulation further improves the mechanism. There will be an early warning mechanism when imports reach 80% of their relevant yearly threshold. Transparency will be improved, and data on imports will be made regularly available and in a user—friendly manner. Finally, the institutions also agreed that before the stabilisation mechanism expires at the end of 2019, the Commission will assess the situation of EU banana producers. Even after the expiry, we will continue to regularly analyse the state of the market and the EU producers and, where necessary, take appropriate action. In the light of this provisional application of the trade agreement since January, I hope that this amended regulation on the banana stabilisation mechanism can be adopted, hopefully voted on with a big majority tomorrow, and then applied as soon as possible.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, although the European banana sector and, in particular, the Canary Islands are always under threat, after the agreement that we are going to vote on tomorrow, I am sure that our future will be much better, but it has not been easy. For many, it was much more important to approve the agreement with Ecuador than to guarantee the future of the banana sector. It was not for me, but it was for many and for that reason I really thank the commissioner for getting involved, almost at the last moment, but it was enough that she got involved and that this went ahead. Because we have to remember the reality: producers in the outermost regions are always the losers of free trade agreements and that is why these safeguard clauses and the stabilization mechanism are important, because perhaps it is the last resort that our producers have to do. versus imports, very often led by powerful multinationals that control markets worldwide. When we faced this debate, we did it knowing that the mechanism had not worked until now. It was not working well and we have seen it with a very clear example, that of Peru, which for four years has widely exceeded the threshold set by the agreement and nothing had been done about it. For this reason, we understood that this system had to be modified and I think it has been modified on the right track. I am not going to explain the characteristics much, because both the rapporteur and the commissioner have already said them, but I do believe that it is good that there is this early warning mechanism that obliges the Commission to alert Parliament and the Council when the volume of imports reach 80% of the thresholds. And I believe that it is also important that the sector, the producers themselves, can also participate together with the Member States in monitoring the evolution of trade. Transparency, control, information and act in case of necessity are keywords in this new system.We believe that it is very important that action can be taken in the event of a serious deterioration in the market situation and also after 2020. But we must not lower our guard.We must continue working on improving the marketing of our fruit.We have, I have said many times, the best banana in the world, without a doubt, but we have to be able to compete against anyone if we succeed in making the consumer continue to prefer the European banana, the Canarian banana, before any other.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner. The Spanish socialists in the European Parliament always welcome the acts, instruments and agreements that express the political commitment of the European Union with Latin America. And, therefore, we welcome multiparty trade agreements, trade agreements with Colombia and Peru, and their extension to Ecuador. But, having said that, we give all the importance - and, of course, I give it myself - to the stabilization mechanism, and to updating and improving the stabilization mechanism of the banana, which is how we call bananas in the Canary Islands. Because we cannot ignore that there are banana producers - plantain - in the European Union, in outermost regions, and that bananas maintain nearly thirty thousand jobs in those outermost regions, seven thousand of them in the Canary Islands. Therefore, it must be said clearly that the European Union fulfills the duty to inform this European Parliament, through the Commission, in the event that the maximum volume of banana imports from that Central American region is going to be reached. , but, above all, to maintain your early warning and your ability to respond. Because banana producers in the outermost regions are not simply looking for compensation here. They seek, above all, tools to defend themselves. To defend against the breach of the terms indicated in the agreement itself. And that requires maintaining early warning, informing this European Parliament - that is what the improvements introduced are - of any situation that deserves attention, analysis, monitoring and annual review, where appropriate, of the agreed terms and, also , the anticipation of the compensatory response, if applicable. Therefore, we welcome an agreement that is respectful with the environment, which has clauses for growth and inclusive regional development in Latin America, but we call the attention of the Commission on the essential need to strictly observe the terms of the stabilization mechanism for plantain, thinking that it is a product of extreme sensitivity in the outermost regions.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner. This safeguard for Canarian banana products and producers that we approved this week is a success for European policy. It is the result of a collective work in which the producers, the Government of the Canary Islands and the MEPs who work here have been involved - and, of course, our speaker, Marielle de Sarnez, whom I thank for her excellent work - so that a voice is heard European. She listened, despite the fact that she comes from the outermost periphery. I highlight and acknowledge the sensitivity with which the Canarian claims were accepted in the European Commission and I appreciate the work done by Mrs. Malmström and her team, who have reached an agreement that includes all the critical points to prevent the incorporation of Ecuador into the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru destabilize this European industry. Transfer, also, the gratitude of the Canarian institutions - of the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries and the Presidency of the Government itself - for the success of this collective work. And I conclude by expressing our commitment on behalf of the Canary Coalition and the government that presides over the protection of the primary sector of this outermost region. We are here to remember every day the fragility in which these producers live vis-à-vis third countries and to cooperate so that the Union is a useful framework of stability, support, promotion and protection. Today we have achieved it.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! The law on safeguard clauses, in particular on the accompanying measures for European banana farmers, which we are debating here today, represents a good compromise which was certainly not easy to achieve, but which ultimately avoided a trade conflict at the last minute. Small farmers need protection. Importers and exporters need predictability and reliability, in the reality of everyday economic and social life for all parties involved. The law forms the final building block in Ecuador's accession process to the trade agreement with the Andean countries of Peru and Colombia, for which I was allowed to be rapporteur. Ecuador wanted this accession out of economic and political constraints and at the same time in order to continue the independent path of sustainable development of the "Buen Vivis". Today's law is intended to support us in our task and duty to ensure in the years to come that the agreement is positive for the well-being of our people, on the side of both contracting parties. I hope that this time my group's negative fears and those of my group will not materialize and that we will take a step forward with this agreement.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, bananas are symbolic fruit. They play such an important part in the politics of some countries that the phrase ‘banana republic’ is used to describe a corrupt regime dominated by powerful corporations. How can it be rational that a tropical fruit which travels so far and bruises so easily is eaten more than any other in the UK? This modified regulation enshrines even more of the worst aspects of our irrational relationship with this humble fruit. Its focus is to ensure supermarkets’ ability to continue to use bananas as a loss leader, so that their price does not reflect their true environmental cost. It simultaneously increases the risk that Andean countries will lose the preferential tariffs which underpin the livelihoods of poor farmers in countries like Ecuador, where 200 000 families depend on banana production, and 56% of the banana plantations are smaller than 10 hectares. The Greens’ priority for trade is to ensure a comfortable life for all, without wasting energy and resources. Our priority for agriculture is to protect the livelihoods of small producers against the power of global corporations. This regulation does nothing to constrain the power of such powerful retailers, who undermine the minimum wage in the Ecuadorian banana sector. This so-called safeguard regulation dismisses social and ecological aspects of production, and should leave a bitter taste in the mouths of the millions of European consumers who choose a banana before other locally grown fruit.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the opening up of the European banana market to Ecuador is a major risk for West Indian producers. Indeed, Ecuador is the fourth largest producer of bananas in the world: it is a giant compared to the French Antilles. Admittedly, this proposal for a regulation provides for safeguard instruments, but none seems sufficient. The most important is a stabilization mechanism, which allows tariffs to be increased if a threshold for the volume of imported bananas is exceeded. However, it has never been used against Peru, which has nevertheless exceeded this threshold every year since 2013. Admittedly, the proposal attempts to improve it, by creating an early warning mechanism as soon as 80% of the threshold is reached. and by assigning the Commission an obligation to react, but there is no guarantee that the Commission will actually react. These safeguard instruments are therefore decoys. I accuse the European Union of deliberately sacrificing West Indian banana producers on the altar of ultra-liberalism.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: - Mr President, the regulatory change that we are discussing today has as its main focus banana, which is one of the most consumed fruits in the European Union, which absorbs one third of world exports, with its main origin being Ecuador. European producers are concentrated in the outermost regions of Portugal, Spain and France, and are responsible for only 11.4% of European consumption, in fact, their only market. In Portugal, production is located mainly in the Autonomous Region of Madeira and also in the Azores, and constitutes an important lever for economic development, job creation, settling populations and, interestingly, also the landscape modeling that is important to preserve. From this important interinstitutional commitment, I would like to highlight the creation of reliable statistical instruments on the evolution of quantities and prices of imports, the assessment of the situation of European producers and the presentation of a report on the application of the stabilization mechanism for bananas. I also highlight the creation of an alert system on the effects of imports on the European market and the adoption of any compensatory measures. Finally, I emphasize the possibility and the interest in extending the validity of these post-2020 mechanisms, following, moreover, what is proposed by the rapporteur herself.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, in the initial proposal the Commission considered that the stabilization mechanism for bananas worked perfectly. She wanted to add only the term “Ecuador”. We did not share this position and we acted to modify and strengthen the measures to preserve European production. I would like to thank the excellent work of Mrs de Sarnez and the listening of the Commissioner. We all know that this stabilization mechanism was never applied either for the Andean community or for Central America. The proposed early warning system and other improvements should make it easier to trigger this mechanism for the benefit of our producers. Today I would like the Commission to clarify its position on the issue of tariff dismantling. As such, I would like her to commit to no longer reducing the tariff which has been reduced from 114 euros to 75 euros per tonne for South American bananas. This is to protect the already fragile socio-economic balance of our outermost regions and the ACP countries.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Ecuador's adhesion to the free trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru is, in global terms, good news, since it contributes to the intensification of trade flows and investments between the parties. . But we must not forget that Ecuador is the largest exporter of bananas to the European Union, so the reinforcement of the safeguard clause has been one of the priorities of this Parliament to protect the banana sector of several peripheral European regions, including Canary Islands. I am pleased with the result of the trilogue, for which a good agreement has been reached, thanks in large part to the tenacity of Mr Mato. This tripartite dialogue includes our demands on the establishment of an early warning system, effective market monitoring and the possibility of compensatory measures for producers. I firmly believe that the agreement, together with the clause, is good news for the European Union. In addition, the agreement strengthens the Union's position in the region, will promote economic growth and, with the clause, we protect Union producers.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Economic and trade relations between the European Union and the countries of Latin America are of the utmost importance and I believe that, in the current international circumstances, they must be rapidly increased. Ecuador and Colombia, where more than half of the bananas consumed in Europe come from, are, moreover, the example of two countries that deserve to be helped and supported by the European Union. But, on the other hand, we must not forget that there are 37 000 jobs that depend, directly or indirectly, on banana production in five European Union countries. My country, Portugal, is the third banana producer in Europe. Madeira and the Azores produce about 20,000 tonnes of this fruit every year. This sector must be taken care of, not least because this activity concerns ultra-peripheral territories, geographically isolated islands and, therefore, less able to diversify its economy in case of serious losses. The protection mechanisms now established by the European Commission and now refined by this Parliament, in the sense of better monitoring and control, are a valuable contribution to correct imbalances in the European market, resulting from substantial increases in banana imports. They prove that the expectations and concerns of the producers of this fruit, most of which, in fact, are small producers, are not indifferent to us in the European context. The solution found has the merit of safeguarding European interests without calling into question, which seems equally important, the interests of these Latin American countries, whose banana export volumes will continue to have room for growth.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, by joining the EU-Columbia and Peru Trade Agreement, Ecuador will enjoy improved access for the main exports to the EU, such as fisheries, cut flowers, coffee, cocoa, fruits and nuts. Although banana imports will also benefit from our preferential rate, an additional stabilisation mechanism will protect European producers from potential import surges. A better and more stringent system of information, based on reliable statistics on the trends in imports of bananas from three countries to the EU, will be in place. In particular, when volumes of these imports reach 80% of the threshold the Commission must inform the European Parliament and the Council, giving them an analysis of the impact of these imports. However, preferences can be suspended if the annual threshold has been reached. With all this in place, I can fully support this proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank all the efforts of the Commissioner and the colleagues who worked on this agreement, in such a way that, today and tomorrow, I expect a very positive vote and an approval of this agreement. An agreement that safeguards all European banana farmers and producers. The biggest victory in business terms has been achieved. From now on, we will have a safeguard clause that could suspend imports from Central America. From now on, we will have access to more information on imported quantities. From now on, the impact of imports on local economies will be analyzed. And what impact do these imports have in regions like ours, the outermost regions? Banana producers, whether in the Azores, but especially in Madeira, have effective protection in this new regulation. There are around 40 000 jobs safeguarded and it is a whole sector that contributes, directly and indirectly, to the economic and social development of our regions, which today and which I hope will be strengthened tomorrow.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union imports around five million tonnes of bananas per year, with a production of around 650,000 tonnes entirely destined for the internal market. In the outermost territories of the Union, in particular, the banana production sector plays a key economic role. About 40 000 jobs depend directly or indirectly on banana production and the sector ensures the sustainability of maritime connections, allowing them to supply these regions on a regular basis. The protection of such a virtuous and economically important sector therefore cannot be delegated only to measures to limit imports. Instead, it is appropriate to invest in the specificity of the European supply chain by focusing on innovation and sustainability and maintaining high requirements for the entire sector. Only in this way is it possible to create lasting effects of stabilization of the market, avoiding contributing to a leveling down in the quality of the products.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, since December 2012, the European Union has signed a free trade agreement with Colombia and Peru, which provides for the phasing out of customs duties on bananas of EUR 75 per tonne by 1 January 2020. At the same time In order to avoid destabilizing the European market and not harming Union producers, the European Union has introduced a bilateral safeguard clause and a stabilization mechanism. However, as the banana sector plays an important economic role in various European Member States and directly or indirectly employs 37,000 people, the European Union must oppose any free trade agreement expected to harm European banana growers, not just in the Canary Islands. , but also in Crete and also lead to the downsizing of small businesses and the deregulation of labor relations. The aim of the Union must be the protection of the Union banana growers and not the profitability of the multinationals.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for the debate here today. The free-trade agreement with Ecuador is a possibility to support Ecuador, its economy, its development and its efforts in diversifying its economy and giving new possibilities to the people. It also contains a chapter on sustainable development. However, I know that there have been concerns by banana producers in the European Union, and that is why the amended regulation that we are about to vote on tomorrow is a good legislative tool, and I really hope that it can calm some of the concerns that you have expressed here on behalf of them. It is a tool that will guarantee the stability of the banana market and the long—term sustainability of this sector, which is so important for many Europeans, especially in our outermost regions.  The new regulation will provide more information. It will regularly be available, and imports will be monitored closely. It would be transparent and user—friendly, so that everybody can follow what is going on and get a full picture. You can be assured that the Commission – and I, personally – will be fully dedicated to this procedure, and we will be informing and engaging with you and the whole Parliament on this regularly, and we are of course ready to discuss at any moment if you have questions on this. Thank you very much again, rapporteur Mrs Samez, for the work you have done. I would also like to thank the rest of Parliament, and I am looking forward to the vote tomorrow.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: rapporteur.- Mr President, I want to thank each and every one of the speakers, those who have spoken this evening, I thank again Commissioner Cecilia Malmström and I want to say something simple to you, I believe that we have a very good agreement there.It is a protective agreement for our European producers, it is a protective agreement for our overseas territories and for our outermost regions, which are a formidable asset for our European Union and which must be valued.I am therefore optimistic, I find all of this very constructive, and I hope that this agreement will receive broad approval from our Assembly tomorrow.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 2 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- It is regrettable that, as a result of the lack of legislative initiative from this Parliament, we have to take advantage of a technical proposal from the Commission to introduce such an important demand for banana producers in the Canary Islands, such as the strengthening of safeguard mechanisms againstimports.We support Parliament's amendments, but nevertheless maintain our fundamental opposition to trade liberalization, which is the root cause of the difficulties for European production and which, by forcing peripheral countries into the world market,It condemns them to economic dependence on the large Western transnationals.We regret that the EU is willing to accept the strengthening of safeguard mechanisms only as a counterpart to an aggressive trade policy which, unfortunately, will amplify the difficulties our farmers are going through.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Linnéa Engström, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the sustainable management of external fishing fleets and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1006/2008 (COM (2015) 0636 -C8-0393 / 2015 - 2015/0289 (COD)) (A8-0377 / 2016).

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first I would like to thank everyone for the work they have done on this important report and the good cooperation and interesting discussions we have had on this topic, the sustainable management of the EU external fishing fleet. We are about to raise standards in the management of the EU external fishing fleet. For many years the EU had a very bad reputation when fishing outside EU waters, but for the last ten years things have considerably improved with the control regulation, the IUU regulation and the reformed CFP in place. The report that we are going to vote on tomorrow is a regulation that is part of the EU control system on fisheries. It is actually the most fundamental one because it decides who shall have the right to fish outside EU waters. We can be proud of ourselves for we have voted for a very ambitious Parliament position in the committee vote. On several points we have strengthened the Commission proposal, which I have to say was a very good proposal to start with. For instance, we have added that EU vessels can only get direct authorisations if there is a surplus of fish available that the coastal state cannot catch. We have added that fishing on the high seas must be based on a scientific evaluation, showing the sustainability of that fishing activity. We introduced the requirement that vessels returning to the EU fleet register must provide their complete flag history during their period off the register. But, above all, we agreed that the new public register on authorisations must also include the name of the owner of the company, as well as the beneficial owner. This would then mean that, for the first time, we will see who benefits from global fishing through a public register. Tomorrow we will vote in plenary, and some things are still to be settled. It is an important principle that only EU vessels with a clean record of compliance should be able to fish outside EU waters. This is already a provision in the current regulation that we need to keep. Otherwise we undermine our own credibility in our work to curb the IUU fishing of other fishing nations. So it is crucial to reinstate Article 5.1(d) that fell in a tight vote in the Committee. I therefore urge you, colleagues, to vote against Amendment 30 and to support Amendment 78. Another fundamental principle is the exclusivity clause in the sustainable fisheries partnership agreements. This is stipulated in Article 31 of the basic regulation. I agree that there could be situations when the Commission should try to reactivate so—called dormant agreements. This idea was adopted in Amendment 18 in the Committee vote. But under no circumstances should fishing vessels be allowed to engage in direct authorisations, just like that, if there has not been any protocol in force for three years. This is exactly what Amendment 48 suggests. It suggests that fishing could start again without any prior assessment of the situation, yet there can be many reasons why there is no protocol in force – for example that the fish stocks situation does not allow for more fishing or the coastal state wants to keep the resource to itself for political reasons. That is why the Commission first needs to assess the situation and check coherence with other EU policies, such as developing and foreign policies. The Commission needs to ensure a level playing field. So please join me and delete Amendment 48, which is in fact not in line with the basic regulation.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, my sincere thanks go to the rapporteur, Ms Engström, so thank you, Linnéa, for the work on this report, along with the other shadows and their teams, who have worked hard to find a good compromise in relation to this Commission proposal. The proposal on the sustainable management of the external fleets is of prime importance to reinforce the role of the European Union as a key global actor in fisheries and in ocean governance. With the new rules, the Commission aims to create a benchmark at international level regarding the management and the control of external fleets. I am pleased to see that the overwhelming majority of the amendments tabled follow this objective overall, and even reinforce the key elements of our proposal. The Commission would therefore be favourable to these amendments as long as they do not lead to disproportionate administrative burdens for our Member States and for our operators. The efforts deployed so far to simplify the text, reduce administrative burdens and improve the consistency and structure of the proposal could be of inspiration during the upcoming trilogues.  In relation to the database I am confident we will be able to increase openness and transparency, while striking a good balance with respect for sensitive, personal and commercial data. In order to maintain the reputation of the EU’s external fleet, we need to ensure that only good conduct vessels and operators complying with the rules are allowed to fish outside EU waters. Therefore, a clean record from sanctions for serious infringements in the last 12 months should be one of the conditions for a fishing authorisation.  Finally, as you know, the European Union is responsible for the activities of its vessels operating outside EU waters, and that is why it is particularly important to allow the Commission to withdraw the fishing authorisation of a vessel when the flag Member State does not take action to stop that vessel from causing damage. The Union has now become a strong global actor in shaping international oceans governance, and this has to be reflected also in our legislation and in our actions. I therefore trust that together we will manage to improve fisheries governance through better control and monitoring of our extended fleet. Let me thank you once again for this report and for the fruitful upcoming discussion. We look forward to further working with Parliament in a good spirit of cooperation.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, the first thing is to congratulate the rapporteur on her work. I think we have achieved a somewhat improved text by reducing the bureaucratic burden, especially in the so-called private agreements, by introducing a fast track; The procedure for granting licenses has also been changed, allowing Member States to better control the process. Logically, there are also points with which I do not fully agree, including the one referring to the Union's fishing authorization register (Article 39). The text approved by the Fisheries Commission seems excessive to me: it requires the publication of data that could threaten the privacy of companies and make them reveal their business strategies. Your original proposal, Commissioner, seems to me much more balanced. My political group supports transparency, but this regulation does not seem to me the ideal one to regulate a matter that is horizontal in nature. I want to dwell on the so-called double sanction, that of article 5, paragraph 1, which I understand penalizes without a license boats that had been sanctioned a year before the authorization request. We managed to remove this provision in the Committee on Fisheries, but now - as you see - it is brought back to plenary with an amendment. This rule, which may be counterproductive, would seriously harm the Union's external fleet. Due to their special characteristics, in many cases these vessels cannot be converted and fish in Union waters. The one-year stoppage would imply unaffordable economic losses. It is not consistent either with the basic Regulation, which says that the European Union must contribute to sustainable, economically viable and job-creating fishing activities. And furthermore, this requirement does not apply to the fleet operating in Union waters, thus creating a situation of discrimination. For all this, I ask for the support of the amendment 30, which is the position that was approved in the Fisheries Commission.Commissioner, legislation on fisheries must also take into account its economic and social dimension.We cannot make it impossible for the European fishing fleet to fish in third country waters.We will harm employment, we will harm our companies and we will favor fleets from third countries, which are much less controlled and fish in an unsustainable way

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I must congratulate the rapporteur on the inclusive work she has done with the shadow rapporteurs and their teams. We may not agree with some details, but everything was done with openness, clarity and commitment on the part of all the political groups that were involved in the discussion of a regulation that has enormous relevance for the management of external fisheries. As time is short, I want to focus on three essential points. First, I think it is essential not to expunge this regulation from a provision that already existed beforehand and which makes it possible to penalize access to international fishing agreements to vessels and master fishermen who have committed serious infringements. It would be a historic setback in the context of European legislation. Secondly, it seems to me essential to ensure that there is transparency regarding information on vessels fishing in international waters, what are the associated fishing opportunities, who are their owners and, very importantly, who are the final beneficiaries, that is , who are the beneficial owners. We must ensure that European fisheries are not used as a tool for tax evasion or money laundering. Finally, I would like to explain why it seems to me important to prevent dormant international agreements from perpetuating. When certifying the legality and transparency of the sector, which is guaranteed precisely by this regulation, then we also have to ensure that dormant agreements are not perpetuated to the detriment of the fleets of the Member States of the European Union, with harmful effect downstream and , while we are asleep, we promote the establishment of doubtful and malevolent fleets. If we want to combat UI fishing and slavery, and promote respect for the environment and local communities in third countries, then we cannot allow inefficient European international agreements to become continue for at least more than three years.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - I want European fishermen inside and outside European waters to contribute to the proper management of our creation and for fishing activities inside and outside EU waters to be based on the same principles. That is also the case in the common fisheries policy. Sustainable management of fish stocks must be the starting point. Only fish where it is justified, also report transparently and then not just flag back to dubious flag states if that is convenient. A European flag on the back of a fishing boat should symbolize responsible management. Unfortunately, the fishing vessels from, for example, China and Russia apply different principles. Europe must not participate in this, but the European Union must set a good example. We must continue to insist that improper fishing methods, whereby the world's seas are rudely drained, cannot be done. And we continue to hold those countries to account that they have to change their policies. There is one point in the Commission proposal that I cannot support, in particular the fact that the European Commission would have the right to withdraw permits. I think that Europe cannot do that, that is really something that is reserved for the Member States. But otherwise I wholeheartedly support the Commission proposal.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner. I want to thank the rapporteur and the rest for the work done and say that the external dimension of the CFP obliges the entire European fleet to comply with the same rules and to operate with the same principles inside and outside our waters. This Regulation will improve the transparency, control and sustainability of the activities of the more than seven hundred European vessels that fish under agreements with third countries, under United Nations legislation, through private agreements or carrying out activities on the high seas. The first success is thus to control the fleet regardless of its type of activity, establish procedures against abusive flag changes and authorize fishing rights only when there are surpluses not used by local communities. The second, to establish more and better control measures, such as the electronic register of ships of the European Union or the European supervision of authorizations. The third, the legal certainty that it adds for all operators. However, we want the common eligibility criteria that should be required for licensing to only apply to vessels and not to operators or captains. Thus, we want to avoid double sanctions for the fleet and operators of the States that have best applied the 2009 Control Regulation. Since 2015, the Commission owes us an evaluation report, but we know that not in all States members the same behaviors imply the same sanctions. In this situation, with the Commission's original proposal, countries that have been less rigorous in control so far have an advantage. For this reason, I propose to vote in favor of Amendment 30, letter d), and also in favor of Amendment 48, because it is necessary to find solutions in favor of the agreements that are latent.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (The speaker is showing a large photo of the fishing vessel she refers to in her speech.) This is the Annelies Ilena. The Annelies Ilena is 144 meters long, making it Europe's largest monster ship. This Dutch ship catches 400 tons of fish a day. It catches more fish per week than 7,000 African traditional fishing boats catch in an entire year. When I think about the destruction Annelies Ilena is causing, I am ashamed that I am Dutch. In Mauretania this ship was nicknamed "ship from hell". And that is not surprising. The ship looted the entire West African coast, and this is just one of dozens of monster boats that Europe is sending across the world to empty the oceans. Half of all the fish we eat in Europe comes from the developing world, which is unacceptable. The Party for the Animals supports the proposal to limit charter agreements between European industrial fishermen and developing countries. As far as we are concerned, monster boats like the Annelies Ilena will from now on be chained. I also believe that European agriculture and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the rapporteur has already spoken for my group. I will use this minute only to give an example of how necessary this regulation is. Many years ago, Spain adopted a highly regarded law which ensured that the provisions of the CFP were applied to their vessels wherever they operated. Last year, however, the Spanish Supreme Court overcame the application of this principle in a case that will have strong far-reaching repercussions and may seriously undermine Spain's possibilities to strengthen the provisions of the CFP and thus fisheries control. A well-known fishing company was accused, among other things, of falsifying documents and committing crimes against the environment while fishing in the Antarctic, for a turnover of 100 million euros. Unfortunately, Spanish law alone does not have the legal tools to condemn shipowners, who could be a school for other illegal fishing companies. This case demonstrates the absolute need for a strengthening of common rules in the control of fishing in external waters, as well as in continental waters. Member States alone are clearly unable to do this themselves. As the rapporteur has already said, this regulation is essential and it is necessary, in particular, to vote against amendments 30 and 48.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, tonight we debate sustainability, and I see by the numbers tonight the importance this European Parliament puts on the jobs of UK fishermen. The common fisheries policy does not know the meaning of the word ‘sustainability’. In UK waters, the common fisheries policy allows non-British fishing ships to decimate the number of fish, devastate the breeding stock of whole species and destroy the livelihoods and prosperity of whole ports such as Grimsby and Hull. The report also talks of external waters and fleets. It is straightforward: the UK must use Brexit to regain control of our waters when the EU becomes an external fleet. They must take second place – play second fiddle to the needs of our ports and our boats. For too long, our waters have been stripped by others. It must stop, and I will do all I can to make it stop. So it must be goodbye to external fleets, goodbye to the CFP on our patch, and goodbye to unworkable rules. Then it can be: hello, real sustainability.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Mr. president. I want to express my gratitude to the rapporteur and to all those who have intervened and, to Mr Affronte, simply to remind him that he has just forgotten to say something that I think is important: that Spain is a clear example in terms of control and in terms of having the most respectful fleet in the world. And that said, what for some are positive elements, for me I think they can be absolutely distorting. We are talking about the obligation of surpluses. We are talking about the public registry, which, beyond transparency, is - as Paco Millán said very well - violating the minimum principles of the strategy itself that operators may have commercially and the double sanction. I think that we are putting so many obstacles in the way of the foreign fleet - which is one of the fleets, I said, more sustainable and more respectful - that it seems that some want to put an end to it, and I think this is a huge mistake. And the greatest example of this is, and there I disagree with the rapporteur, the double penalty. I think Amendment 30 must be voted on, clearly, among other things, because, do you know what we can achieve? That the countries that more strictly apply the United Nations Control Regulation and regulations on fishing are being penalized. We are inviting countries to relax control and sanctions. For what? To avoid double sanction and to avoid being prevented from giving licenses. You have to be very careful. Do you have to control? Undoubtedly. Should we sanction? Undoubtedly. But we cannot in any way accept a double sanction that does not make any sense.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: - Mr President, we are, as all the people who have preceded my speech have said, before an important regulation. I want to acknowledge the work of both the rapporteur, Mrs Engström, and the shadow rapporteurs. I think a great job has been done and I think the result is balanced. The result. You can't win everything, Mrs Engström, you can't win everything. I believe that the result is quite balanced, taking into account that we are talking about an important regulation, with a fundamental importance, and I believe that a balance has been achieved in that. There are some things that I like more, like some, and there are other things that I like less. But - as Mr Mato has said very clearly - the Spanish fleet is an example of control and I do not like that, when it comes to the foreign fleet, it is said that it is a fleet that is depleting absolutely everything. I think there is very light talk about many people behind this, very serious and hard-working. Therefore, let's stop criminalizing in general terms. There are people who do it well and people who do it badly. And there are countries that control better and countries that control worse. In this case, we are going to have a good Regulation that simplifies the current system, harmonizes the data requirements and clarifies the responsibilities of all the agents involved; it also gives greater coherence to all Regulations. Therefore, I believe that it is a balanced agreement. You cannot win everything. Let's give the foreign fleet a good regulation, but that it can continue working.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - There was an excellent occasion for the new regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the sustainable management of external fishing fleets to introduce clear, equal and fair rules for the operation of the EU fishing fleet and the fleet of third countries.Meanwhile, unfortunately, instead of simplifying the rules and procedures, there is a greater bureaucratic burden on both shipowners and the administrations of the Member States.Moreover, the EU fleet may be discriminated against against the third country fleet, as third country ships will not have to comply with all administrative requirements.Thus, the EU fleet may be driven out of the market by the fleet of third countries.In addition, imposing difficult requirements on shipowners, this regulation may deprive the issuing of direct authorizations.On the subject of amendment 30: it is indeed necessary to be very careful, personally I am against double punishment.

name: Werner KUHN
text: - Mister President! Dear Commissioner Vella, Mrs Engström, thank you very much for your commitment, particularly with regard to the regulation on the authorization of fishing vessels of the European Union to fish outside Union waters, but the regulation also applies to fishing vessels from third countries which are in Union waters fishing. That is why we have to weigh things up, and I think it is very sensible that a register of fishing permits should be set up here and that monitoring of the external fleet should be ensured and that authorization must be obtained to operate in the relevant fishing areas. And here I am simply calling again on the partnership agreements with third countries, which we have discussed intensively every time here in Parliament and also in the Fisheries Committee. Whether it's the Seychelles, Madagascar, Mauritania, Greenland or West Africa: We discussed all of that with each other. It is therefore really only sensible and sensible that the basic regulation, which is applied in our Union waters, is also applied in operational work outside, in the third countries in which we have fishing permits. There is of course the landing obligation, and there are the TACs and quotas on a scientific basis, MSY and other reference values ​​and, of course, the control institution. But because there is constant debate about the fact that Europe is working with a huge fleet on the world's oceans and destroying the stocks there: China, Indonesia and India together have more than 50% of wild catches and aquaculture, Mr President! I just wanted to say that again very briefly. Europe is in fourth place with 4.5%, which is why it is very important that we bring the European fisheries policy closer to the others who work there and that we combat illegal fishing.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Commissioner, the rapporteur - who did not have an easy task, because the dossier was still demanding - and all the shadow rapporteurs because the compromise we have reached is certainly a good job, even if there are some aspects perhaps still to be perfected. The proposal for a regulation that we are discussing has been long awaited because it responds to the need to reform the management of external fishing fleets in the light of the objectives and principles of the CFP. The point on which I would like to draw the attention of this House is that relating to dormant agreements, which at present create a regulatory vacuum that could undermine the sustainability of resource management in waters outside the European Union. In fact, these are partnership agreements whose operational protocol has expired and not renewed and which, as a result of the exclusivity clause contained therein, do not allow direct authorizations in favor of boats flying the EU flag. The concrete risk of these agreements is that non-EU countries that do not recognize the high standards of sustainability like us - for example social and economic sustainability - may take over the capture of surpluses in a predatory way and that do not take into account the aspects of cooperation to basis of our agreements. Indeed, it must be emphasized that the EU's external fishing fleets represent the CFP at the international level and the European Union has achieved remarkable results in terms of sustainability standards, which must be consistently achieved also in the external dimension. Only in this way can the European Union continue to be a positive and credible example.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, while seeking the sustainable exploitation of the seas, we should not forget about increasing the effectiveness of the current system. We also need to remember to promote a level playing field for Union operators, contrary to the third country operators. Most importantly, we have to create this level playing field. I am talking about the effective closure of the EU market for products coming from third country vessels that do not meet the requirements of this legislation. The EU should create a level playing field so that EU fishing vessels can compete with vessels from third countries.  Finally, I would like to mention the important Article 5.1(d). I fully agree with the fact that this point implies a double sanction for this sector and could seriously hurt the fishing activities of the long—distance fleet. We should not forget that the EU external fishing fleet is already subject to sanctions for serious infringements by the Control and IUU regulations. We have to remember this because it puts additional and unnecessary strain on our operators. In doing so, we will only hurt the sector and will also hurt the environment because we are the most important and most responsible operators on the seas all over the world.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is not fully capable of monitoring its fleet wherever it operates and regardless of the framework in which its activities take place. A review of the current regulation on fishing authorizations is therefore necessary. I congratulate Commissioner Vella and the rapporteur for the work they have done. I think the Commission has made a good proposal that will allow the European Union to more effectively monitor its ships operating outside EU waters, by clarifying the procedures for granting authorizations and by introducing common eligibility rules for such vessels. This proposal will ensure a level playing field for all fishing activities carried out by vessels flying the flag of the Union by ensuring that the European Union fulfills its responsibilities as a flag State as well as a State of beneficiary ownership. The Fishing Authorization Regulation will also make a concrete contribution to the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, thus following the FAO International Action Plan against Illegal Fishing, approved by the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the European Union's overseas fleet is an important part of the overall fleet and contributes to employment and fish supply in the Union market. However, the current regulation on fishing licenses for these fishing activities has failed, showing serious weaknesses, as the operation of European Union vessels outside Union waters is not regulated by the current regulation. For this reason, it is necessary to set up a sustainable external fleet management. In addition, in many Member States of the Union, coastal and island regions are experiencing a significant economic downturn leading to a reduction in the population of the regions. In countries such as Greece, which is affected by the memoranda and austerity measures, fishermen are experiencing the consequences of the agricultural memorandum, resulting in the economic recession and their targeting. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to restructure the primary sector, focus on the blue economy, increase funding for the fisheries sector and boost employment, especially in the Aegean islands.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone once again for this fruitful discussion. This week, I had the pleasure of discussing with many of you the importance of ocean governance at the Seas, Rivers, Islands and Coastal Areas Intergroup. Your vote on this proposal will be a very important step towards improving ocean governance overall. It will contribute to the sustainable exploitation of global fisheries resources. The European Union must be seen to act responsibly outside its own waters if we expect others also to fish sustainably. We are accountable for the actions of our own fleets. We need to provide these vessels with clear, simple and coherent rules in order to ensure that fishing authorisations are granted on objective and proportionate eligibility criteria, and that vessel activities are constantly monitored and transparent. The Commission proposal, which you will soon discuss in trialogues, presents an approach that will achieve these objectives. I welcome Ms Engström’s report, which reinforces our policy objectives and brings in some constructive suggestions as well. Turning to some of the specific points raised by Members this evening, some of you do not agree that past serious infringements should be taken into account in granting authorisations – I am referring to Amendment 30. I think that this measure is proportionate and justified. We should ensure that only good conduct vessels are allowed to fish outside EU waters, and the absence of serious – let stress and underline the word ‘serious’ – infringements in the last 12 months is a good indication of good conduct. It is also a cost—effective way to control who can fish outside our waters and who cannot.  There were also some comments on the clawback clause. The European Union is responsible before third countries and international organisations for the activities of its vessels operating outside EU waters. Not having a legal basis to stop fishing vessels from causing harm without the impunity of the flagged Member State would put the European Union in a situation of not being able to comply with its international obligation of due diligence, as pointed out by the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS). The clawback clause allows the Commission to withdraw a fishing authorisation in cases where Member States do not stop fishing vessels flying their flag in the cases provided by the law and where those vessels continue fishing, causing harm.  There was also some mention of the dormant agreements and, although we sympathise, we cannot accept them for legal reasons. We understand that this is an important issue for a number of Members, and our proposal addresses direct authorisations with the objective of ensuring sustainability. This may eventually lead to our reviewing dormant agreements in the context of the negotiation of sustainable fishing partnership agreements.  Some comments were also made about the minimum length of vessel fleets. I have to say that it is very difficult to quantify the effect of the amendment, because we do not have information on high seas fisheries conducted by the EU vessels. However, to give you an idea, in 2015 there were around 70 000 EU vessels licensed to fish in our FMOs, with the bulk coming from the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) and the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT). In the Mediterranean, most of the vessels are small—scale and normally fish on the high seas, although not adding a minimum length may bring problems of monitoring and control as well, because not all vessels are obliged to carry VMS, AIS and IMO numbers.  Some of you also expressed concern about data protection. As I have already said, we believe that the balance between information requirements and privacy in the proposal is the right one, but I am happy to look at proposals that would improve transparency within the limit of our data protection rules. I am sure that this will be an issue for intense discussion in the trialogues. I look forward to further working with Parliament in a good spirit of cooperation as we take this file forward.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone here and Commissioner Vella for their contributions. I have some last points, and the first is that I really want to support the idea that we keep in the report the second part of Amendment 32, which gives the Commission the possibility to act if a Member State fails to. I think this is crucial as a provision to guarantee the level playing field among fleets. I hope that this will be confirmed in tomorrow’s vote. I urge you to vote in favour of Amendment 32 – all parts.  The second point is that some colleagues claim that prohibiting vessels that have committed a serious infringement from fishing abroad would be a double penalty, and this is definitely not the case, as Commissioner Vella also stressed. It is an eligibility criterion designed to ensure that only vessels with a clean record are allowed to fish outside EU waters. My last point: let me come back to Amendment 48. If vessels are allowed after three years of a dormant agreement to set up their own terms with a third country, they will be able to ignore those very provisions in the CFP that have served to improve EU standards. They could negotiate weaker terms despite the existence of a bilateral agreement, and that is not maintaining the high standards of the EU. It is serving to undermine them. So I urge you all to keep up the good standards of EU external fishing and to refer to, and vote against, Amendment 48. Once more, my thanks to all of you for the very good cooperation that we have had, and I am looking forward to working with you once more.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 2 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - With the proposal to amend the Regulation on the sustainable management of external fishing fleets, Europe has an opportunity to distance itself from unsustainable fishing practices. Establishing effective control measures for our fleets is part of the objective of this proposal and will set the European Union as an example of sustainable management of its fishing fleet, even in third country waters. In a world in the process of changing towards economies compatible with the conservation of natural resources, the fishing sector cannot be absent, much less when it comes to EU-flagged vessels operating outside its waters. These vessels are the visible presence of the European Union throughout the world and have to maintain the high standards that the world expects from Europe. Therefore, we must prevent vessels that have recently operated illegally from accessing fishing licenses abroad. This eligibility criterion, designed to ensure that only vessels with a clean record can fish outside EU waters, is a similar criterion to that followed in the European point system for serious fishing offenses.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - The ecosystem approach and precautionary management of fisheries increases the transparency of external fishing activities and makes it difficult to circumvent CFP rules, while limiting administrative burdens and increasing legal certainty. I agree that, in order to achieve the objectives of the CFP, clear and comprehensive rules and viable databases are needed regarding the authorization and monitoring of EU vessels when fishing outside EU waters, but also the conditions for authorization. of fishing vessels from third countries fishing in Union waters. European Union vessels may fish in third country waters either under the EU Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements with those third countries or as a result of obtaining direct fishing authorizations from those third countries. Obviously, the authorization of fishing vessels (with all related elements) must be based on a set of common eligibility criteria. To this end, the EU and the Member States must take appropriate measures to ensure the sustainable management and conservation of marine resources, in the context of food security and poverty eradication. Cooperation is also absolutely necessary to transform the world we live in by conserving and sustainably using the oceans, seas and marine resources.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - Thanks to external fishing authorizations, we set the framework for the sustainability of our fishing activities around the world. These objectives are particularly ambitious in terms of control and relations with our international partners. It is thanks to the irreproachable behavior of our fisheries that we will succeed in maintaining our image as world leaders in sustainability in the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, known as IUU. However, I would like to alert you: the battle against IUU fishing cannot have as its only lever the exemplary nature of our fleets. Justice and equity require that we be intransigent with our partners who do not respect the rules of the game. In this fight for the sustainability of our oceans, our sole example will not be enough to change practices, it is trade agreements which are Achilles heels. It is therefore essential that we use all the levers at our disposal. In this way, I hope that relations between DG Mare and DG Trade can be intensified, so that the European Commission adopts a coherent approach to promoting sustainable fishing at global level.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Milan Zver, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the application of Regulation (EU) No. 1288/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, ofDecember 11, 2013, which creates the "Erasmus +" program for education, training, youth and sport of the Union and repeals Decisions No. 1719/2006 / EC, No. 1720 /2006 / CE and No. 1298/2008 / CE (2015/2327 (INI)) (A8-0389 / 2016).

name: Milan ZVER
text: Rapporteur. - We have before us a report on the implementation of the Erasmus + program, the umbrella program in the field of education, training, youth and sport, which was formally established on 11 December 2013 and became operational in 2014. The report was adopted by the Culture Committee in November 2016. most of. Let me take this opportunity to express my heartfelt thanks to all the co-rapporteurs of the political groups who took an active part in drafting the report and enriching it in terms of content. But this report has ramified roots. In terms of content, it also involved individuals, non-governmental organizations and educational institutions that deal with this issue throughout Europe, including in practice. This breadth also seemed useful to me in preparing the draft, because due to the relatively early preparation of the report and the short deadline for the implementation of the program, I could not use the results of official research and analysis because they simply did not yet exist. The European Parliament has carried out two surveys, and the Commission has also made available everything it has had so far about the operation of this new umbrella program, which has a great deal of support from the European public. Thanks again for helping the professional services of Parliament and the Commission. It is well known that Erasmus + was created by merging various previous programs and is therefore extremely complex. Therefore, simplifications, mainly related to the digitization of application procedures and projects, are very welcome. At the same time, we emphasize the integrated approach, as Erasmus + also brings together previously established programs such as Youth in Action, Erasmus Mundus, Erasmus, Grundtvig, Comenius and Leonardo da Vinci). Despite the established horizontal integration, the Commission has managed to functionally decentralize the program and transfer responsibilities - or greater responsibilities - to national agencies. The general visibility of the Erasmus + program has increased, and the most important decision in the report is that the program is working well, that it has brought a number of innovations. But there are also disadvantages that will have to be phased out. As an example, stakeholders sometimes complain that there are still too many bureaucratic obstacles, that new information and communication technology is not the most user-friendly, that inter-ministerial cooperation is not intensive enough, that the success rate in some parts of Erasmus + is significantly too low. forward. But the biggest problem is the gap between the potential of Erasmus +, which is reflected in the large number of applications, and the real financial possibilities. In some parts of the program, as many as three quarters of projects (or applications) are rejected, even if they are of good quality because there is not enough money. A 40% increase in the budget in this financial perspective will only be felt in reality this year. This will increase the absorption capacity of Erasmus + over the next four years, with 4 million people, mostly young people, expected to benefit from the Erasmus + program by the end of 2020. In the next financial perspective, we will have to increase the budget for this program, as it has invaluable positive effects.

name: Milan ZVER
