text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this year we are celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of Erasmus, one of the EU’s biggest success stories. This is the perfect opportunity for us to take stock of how we have moved from Erasmus to Erasmus+ and to celebrate what we have achieved so far. It is also a greater opportunity to debate where we want to take the programme in the future.  I therefore welcome the fact that the European Parliament has appointed a standing rapporteur for the Erasmus+ Programme who keeps a critical eye on its implementation. I want to thank Mr Sver and his shadow rapporteurs for their positive and constructive report, and their suggestions, especially with a view to the upcoming mid-term evaluation of Erasmus+. I welcome this report, and I am very happy to comment on some of the points it raises. I am fully aware that Erasmus+ had some teething problems in its first year. Merging various former programmes into one and trying to apply uniform rules to the whole programme was not an easy task, but we have overcome these initial difficulties I am therefore pleased that your report recognises the efforts the Commission has put and continues to put into improving the implementation of the programme. This would not have been possible without your regular feedback and without us closely cooperating with our stakeholders and national agencies who implement the programme at national level. Your report rightly identifies the cross-sectorial approach as a main feature of Erasmus+. As you point out, we have seen many positive developments over the course of only a couple of years. What we do in education, training, youth and sport is much more visible. We have built bridges between these fears which has led to an exchange of ideas, and has also translated into a significant increase in the funding available to the benefit of all beneficiaries. Moreover, funding rules have been streamlined and simplified funding mechanisms such as lump sums have been widely introduced. Communication to beneficiaries has been streamlined and, finally, this leaner management has made the programme more flexible, so that it can respond to changing political priorities. I am very proud that Erasmus+ is a much more open and inclusive programme than its predecessors. First of all, Erasmus+ is much more than student mobility. It is about learners in vocational education and training, and youth workers. It is about providing practical support to teachers and helping organisations and educational institutions to forge international partnerships. It is about kick—starting innovation across the fields of education, training and youth. It is about supporting our sports organisations, and much more. Erasmus+ also covers important horizontal dimensions. To name just one: language learning. Language learning is definitely a must in today’s world. This is why Erasmus+ provides flexible online linguistic support in many languages. The programme also offers additional funding to disadvantaged learners, including people who come from difficult socio-economic backgrounds, or who have special needs, because these people are the ones who need the extra boost to participate in the programme. I am happy to see that as a result of our efforts, one out of ten mobility participants come from disadvantaged backgrounds or have fewer opportunities. I believe that inclusion and accessibility go hand in hand. I am therefore glad to read in your report that you appreciate our attempts to simplify the application procedures through a range of digital solutions. We have established a strong relationship with our national agencies and beneficiaries. My services have put in place a long-term IT action plan to adapt our IT tools to the needs of participants and to make the tools as user—friendly as possible. We have already achieved high satisfaction rates here, but we will keep up the work. Thanks to the use of online application forms and the online programme guide, we are now moving to the next level of digitalisation. This is in line with the call included in your report. Let me stress one more thing: if we are to ensure the future success of the programme and the positive impact it has on the lives of so many young people across Europe, we need adequate funding. Already now, the programme is heavily over-subscribed, and as you rightly say in your report, it creates frustration when high—quality projects have to be turned down for the simple reason of lack of funds. Given the back—loading of the programme, which means that most of the funds earmarked for Erasmus+ will be spent between now and 2020 when the current programme ends, we need an increase of funds for the next programming period, just to maintain current funding levels. The thirtieth anniversary of Erasmus+ this year provides us with an excellent opportunity to make the case for such an increase. As you know, just last week we organised a launch event at the Parliamentarium for a year full of anniversary events all across Europe. I would like to invite you all to get involved in these events, as we have so much to learn from listening to the Erasmus generation and their ideas. We need to involve them in building a stronger, better Europe.  Honourable Members, your report is a manifestation of our shared dedication to the programme and of our constructive relationship. I want to thank you for the time and effort you have devoted to drafting it. Let me assure you that your conclusions and recommendations will be carefully taken into account in the ongoing mid-term evaluation of the programme. Together we can make sure that Erasmus+ will continue to be one of Europe’s greatest success stories.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, we all see Erasmus + as a very successful program that contributes to improving the quality of education, employment and also to building a European identity. I am not afraid to use the word 'Europeanism' here. All those who use this program are asking us to continue the program, to develop it, to increase the budget, and also to simplify administration. We present all this in our report, and I would like to thank my colleague Zver, who deals with it in great detail, for this report. After less than three years, I must state that the Erasmus + brand meant visibility and simplification of communication. Everyone knows that there is mobility and partnership for all groups, from teachers to pupils to volunteers and athletes. Nevertheless, we have demands for improvement. An increase in the budget of 40% for this period is excellent, but we will need more to make the success even higher and also to make it more efficient, so it is necessary to simplify the administration, such as simplifying the program guide. Erasmus + should also contribute more to improving language skills, to which preparation before going abroad should contribute. We would also like to strengthen the volunteer program, the forthcoming solidarity corps should not be a competition, but rather a complement to this successful volunteer program. Support for entrepreneurship education should also continue and teacher mobility should be a mandatory part of their career progression. Thank you, Commissioner, for this program and I wish you all the best for the next thirty.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr Chairman! Erasmus is one of the most important programs contributing to a new generation of Europeans. A generation that sees international mobility and multiculturalism as an opportunity, not a threat. Therefore, we all care about the high quality of the program, its efficiency and transparency. Mr Zver's report under discussion correctly identifies the problems. I would like to highlight three aspects of this program. First of all - availability. Despite some improvement, the socially selective nature of participation in mobility persists. Many low-income people cannot afford to participate in the program without the help of third parties. In order to increase the participation opportunities for these people, Commissioner, it is necessary to align the amount of the subsidy with the cost of living in the host country. Second case - the budget. The Commissioner spoke about this. Indeed, the funds are insufficient due to the enormous popularity of the program, but therefore it is unacceptable to create new, even good, programs that are financed by Erasmus, such as the European Solidarity Corps, among others. I also propose that for those good projects that are rejected due to lack of funds, a patent should be introduced to distinguish them so that they have priority in reaching for funds from other sources. Third - student loans. The student loan guarantee instrument needs to be assessed critically. Only one hundred and thirty people have used this instrument so far. I urge the Commission, in consultation with Parliament, to present a strategy for reallocating a portion of the budget that is unlikely to be used by 2020. The last question I ask - what is the lesson from this successful program for Member States' education systems? Most importantly, learning mobility should be a permanent part of the core curriculum, both in academic education and in professional development. I sincerely hope that This is how the Member States will celebrate the 30th anniversary of Erasmus.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Erasmus + is an example of success in the European Union, and I hope that with common efforts this will continue. In the Committee on Culture and Education we were given the opportunity to work on this report on the implementation of the program for about a year and I think it is very important to have such reports so that through us, the MPs, the views of point of the citizens as well as of all stakeholders. My colleagues and I worked on this report, we were overwhelmed by the opinions of citizens and organizations. The overly complicated administrative procedure was one of the most common complaints, which is why I made recommendations and amendments in this direction. National agencies are known to play a very important role in this program, and I believe that it is important to have an exchange of good practice between them in order to make rapid progress and to identify and eradicate the issue quickly and efficiently. The Erasmus + program in its current form was established in 2013 for the 2014-2020 programming period, with the integration of programs such as: Lifelong Learning, Youth in Action, Erasmus Tempus. As with any innovation, it takes some time to align procedures and coordination. The program is very useful in terms of forming qualities in young people, as well as those who want to learn at a later stage.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the good rapporteur, Milan Zver, for his good work. It is quite true, as has been said here, under the leadership of Milan Zver and the Commissioner, that the Erasmus program is a special success story in the European Union and in the field of education policy. It is good to remember that we are celebrating its 30th anniversary, and that even those people who are otherwise quite critical or negative about the whole European process still think that Erasmus + has been a success story. It has raised the level of European education, exchanged best practice and thus taken Europe forward. However, we want the program to be even better, and that has been the idea of ​​this mid-term review. It is still appropriate to underline a few things that may still improve this program. One of them is that the application processes should be further simplified so that voluntary organizations in particular can be better involved in the various programs. We also need cross-sectoral cooperation in the field of education. The student loan guarantee scheme has also not really taken the wind off and has not succeeded because the banking sector rejected the initiative. New initiatives must also be taken on this side in such a way that all Europeans have the opportunity to take part in the Erasmus program. It must also be further developed. It is very important that European citizens can benefit as much as possible from this program. I can say that we need simplification, especially with regard to search processes. Nothing but continued success for this good program.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, therefore, let us try to understand: as Erasmus was one of the few prides of this institution, it worked well for 13 years and created European citizens, so we have decided to change it. And instead of drawing inspiration from the founding values ​​of our Union, for example that of the right to education, we want to transform it into a system of imitation of a system that has failed in America, namely the student loan. This is what is really happening. Since the new version of Erasmus, Erasmus +, was approved in 2014, alongside important things that we have supported, such as transparency, bureaucratic simplification and integration of disciplines, this virus has been introduced, which is that of student loan . It is a system that in the United States has caused and is causing an economic collapse, a bubble of 1 300 billion of debt - largely bad debt - that threatens to overwhelm an entire credit system. Fortunately, I must say, in Europe it has been used very little, by 130 students in these three years in just three countries. So we should change course and go back to Erasmus, which was successful. Instead, we are moving forward on a path that will destroy one of the few beloved and rightly popular tools of this institution to pursue models that have failed elsewhere and give other arguments to anti-Europeanism, which already has enough.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! We have just celebrated Erasmus 30th birthday. We have reached over ten million people, especially young people. So, it is clear: it is a real European success story. The budget has increased by 40% in this planning period, but it is clear: that is not enough either. But above all I want to take a quick look at what still needs to be changed in order to make the Erasmus program better: Small school projects should be given more support, the importance of formal and informal learning should be recognized and, in particular, the importance of informal learning should be strengthened . We must give more consideration to disadvantaged young people and allocate more money to young people in the field of sport in the internal distribution of funds. All application procedures and electronic guides should also be simplified. I would like to mention three extra points: The European Solidarity Corps is in principle a good thing - I also support that - but it must not be paid for from Erasmus + funds, but rather the funds that are now available for it should be used for the main areas of Erasmus +. The same applies to the idea of ​​the Interrail ticket: that too is good if young people have the opportunity to travel with it, but it must not be financed from the funds of the Erasmus program. And then there is the idea - and I am very prepared, especially with Trump's policy, to think about the need for a new security policy in Europe - but the Erasmus funds should not be used first for possible military cooperation. So we are concentrating on the real tasks, on building up the funds for an Erasmus, for which we have now fought so hard, and if there are additional good policy areas, then fresh money has to be found for them.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work he has done and for the spirit of collaboration shown. The report we are about to vote on constitutes a good balance between the groups. If the Erasmus + program is indeed one of the most successful programs among the European ones, nevertheless some aspects of it can be improved and the report has the merit of recognizing it. Thus, for example, it is emphasized that the loan guarantee instrument has not achieved the intended results and its critical evaluation is requested. In my opinion, it is absolutely impossible for students to have to go into debt in order to participate in the program. It is unacceptable that those who have few, sometimes very few resources must also be burdened with an additional burden. It is the community that must take charge of it. Another aspect on which the accent is correctly placed is that relating to the fact that, if on the one hand it is correct to recognize the role of volunteering within this program, on the other, however, volunteering cannot in any way replace the workforce and public investment. Finally, I consider positive the references to the need for a simplification of administrative procedures, which have often proved too cumbersome. I would like to close my speech with a general reflection: the Erasmus program is always cited - as my colleagues have done - as a positive example to demonstrate that the European Union basically works and can generate positive results. However, if the success of Erasmus is undoubted, we must not fall into the error of using this program as a propaganda tool for the European Union, because the latter is affected by too many evils that cannot and must not be overlooked, to start with austerity policies. The acceptance of the European project does not it can be something uncritical.The Union must go back to being a community, to place citizens at the center of its project and, to do this, the Erasmus program has certainly been and is a good starting point.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, I would first of all like to thank the rapporteur because, in this mid-term report on the implementation of Erasmus +, he was able to gather the main necessary information, in particular that concerning the feedback from national agencies on the transition with previous programs and their expectations for necessary improvements. The report indicates, despite some progress, that much remains to be done in the area of ​​administrative simplification, as 75% of national agencies still face difficulties in this area. I also support the rapporteur in his desire to rebalance the share of funding between small and large projects. Regarding the budget, I take note of the 12.7% increase in the total budget in 2017 compared to 2016. However, I would like to stress that these new allocated funds will only have a concrete positive impact in the to the extent that they will be managed responsibly. Finally, I support the rapporteur in his desire to improve the accessibility of the program, in particular for people with disabilities and people from rural or mountainous areas.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: Maidel (PPE). - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, Erasmus is not only one of the European Union's most famous programs, but also one of the most developed over the years. Thirty years ago, the program really started as a student mobility scheme, and today "Erasmus +" means training for pupils and students of all ages, internships, volunteering, youth exchanges, vocational training for adults, sports. The program is an example of how the European Union is constantly building on successful projects and policies and delivering concrete results to its citizens. That is why, when we push for increased funding for Erasmus +, we do not just want more student exchanges, we want better trained workers with more quality skills for success in the 21st century, students who know more languages, students with professional experience from a foreign country. One example is enough to understand the importance of Erasmus + in shaping European self-awareness among young people. In 2015, the country that sent the most Erasmus students was the United Kingdom. Here we are joking with young people that if the program was fifty years old today, maybe Brexit would not have happened. We will be happy to see greater access for primary schools in small towns to get the same chance as language schools in large cities and to send students and teachers on exchange.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, for me the Erasmus programme is the biggest success story of the EU. In 2014 alone, the programme provided the UK with more than EUR 79 million in grants and allowed 36 734 British people to study, train or volunteer abroad. These grants helped – and continue to help – young people enhance their skills and employability and intercultural awareness. They also encourage young people to participate in democratic life. Compared to previous generations of programmes, the new Erasmus+ provides stronger support for learners from disadvantaged backgrounds, which I welcome. By funding cooperation projects, Erasmus+ also fosters modernisation and EU-wide collaboration, which in turn stimulate innovation, creativity and improved job prospects.  Leaving the EU will have a major impact on higher education in the UK, with an important loss of income due to a fall in the numbers of EU nationals studying in the UK. Losing access to EU funding, such as Horizon 2020 grants, which accounts for a quarter of all public investment in UK research could further tarnish the attractiveness of the UK as a place to study for international students, including those from non-EU countries. Furthermore, by ending freedom of movement, a hard Brexit would deprive future generations of young Britons of the chance to broaden their minds, learn a foreign language, enjoy a new culture and gain a valuable European experience.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I want to join my predecessors, who have in principle praised the Erasmus + program. As practitioners, we probably know very well that if something from the European Union works clearly and the positive side of the European Union can be clearly declared, especially for young people, it is the Erasmus + program. At least that is how I have practical experience from the Czech Republic, if I meet students as a university cantor, then we are talking about Erasmus +, everyone here feels and sees a clear positive. Among other things, I believe, and this is particularly important for us, for the former post-communist country, that Erasmus allows young people to learn how other EU countries work and to be less subject to the populist language of some politicians who base their vision on the anti-European note. , on anti - European ideology. So I very much welcome this, but I am glad that this report describes clear concrete improvements and clear specific problems that the Commission should address and that should influence the Commission's work. I will not list it all here, it is a question of mobility not only of university students, but also, for example, apprentices, mobility of young start-ups. These are issues related to sufficient money, especially for the countries of Eastern and Central Europe. There is not much money and it is often not enough. It is a question of mutual mobility, not only of students from post-communist countries to the West, but in the future it is also necessary to support just that students from Western Europe travel more to Central and Eastern Europe, etc. So thank you and I support the proposal.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, the Erasmus program is arguably one of the most successful programs in the European Union, allowing millions of young people to experience what it is like to live in another Member State, thus strengthening the idea of ​​European belonging. Although the EU has little competence in the field of education, I take this opportunity to draw attention to the millions who do not participate in the Erasmus program. There are many of them and, unfortunately, the education systems of some Member States put them at a serious competitive disadvantage. The education systems of the Member States should prepare our young people for the changed labor market conditions, the changed world, but this is not the case in some countries. These countries are lagging behind for decades and thus the whole of the Union is losing competitiveness, so this is also our common cause. Member States' systems should be brought closer together than at present, otherwise this serious difference between Member States will be preserved.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Erasmus + is the most important support tool in the fields of youth education and training. The results of the study on the impact of the Erasmus program confirm that those who studied or trained abroad are twice as likely to find work as those without similar experiences. However, the study also shows the persistence of social selectivity in enrolling in mobility programs in some Member States. Inequalities within and between Member States are making access to the program difficult as they hinder applicants with lower income. Many working students are giving up on programs due to the potential for loss of income. The elimination of obstacles to mobility is an indispensable step to ensure equal access to this program. I believe that the Commission and the Member States must increase the financial envelope to facilitate the participation of those who are unable to participate for economic reasons and look for further possibilities to facilitate their mobility so that Erasmus + can actually become accessible to all.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, from 2017 onwards funding for the Erasmus + program is expected to increase, as low funding for the period 2014-2016 resulted in very low success rates for some parts of the program and as a high number of applications were rejected resulting in refuting the expectations of many applicants. However, as we see extreme imbalances in unemployment rates in the countries of the Union, Erasmus + funding should be tailored to the economic needs of each country. The program could be a breath of fresh air for young people and especially for Greeks affected by the memoranda and unemployment. At the moment, the dreams of young children for a better tomorrow fall into the void, as they see that the labor market in Greece can not offer them a position that meets their needs and their educational level. For these reasons they emigrate en masse abroad. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to allocate more funds to countries affected by high unemployment rates such as Greece.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, for thirty years, tens of millions of participants, hundreds of millions of euros invested in our citizens. Big capital for the European Union. Investing in youth, invested in learning, invested in the people who are creating Europe with us today. And I think that is really rightly often said as one of the best programs that the European Union has designed, as one of the trademarks of the European Union. However, I asked for the floor to point out to you, Mr. Commissioner, another experience that exists, and that is the Eurodissey program, which exists within the Assembly of European Regions and where the partnership of local and regional self-government units, ie regions and cities, creates something like Erasmus +. I invite you to think and create a partnership not only with the Member States but also with many regions and cities that have funds for their students, for their young people. I think there lies another great potential for creating an even stronger Erasmus program.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! As we hear today, all my colleagues' speeches prove that this is a very good program, especially if we look at the 30 years of success of European integration. But as with any instrument that works well, many of today's statements and comments are also concerned with what Erasmus + is, has been and will be. This is a problem of success, but you always have to work and support your success. I will no longer repeat all the arguments that many colleagues have used, but the fact that in the 2014-2020 period the program will offer further study, training or volunteering opportunities to 4 million Europeans is an interesting element. It would not be possible without an increase in the budget - a 40% increase in funds and the integration of all programs in the field of education and training of young people results in the Erasmus + program. Besides - what is very important from my personal point of view - sport is finally included in it. But for the programme's success over the long term, it is essential that the Commission continues its efforts to further increase the programme's budget, also in the next period of implementation, and continues its efforts to simplify program procedures. First of all, I am calling for a transparent message for the beneficiaries of the program, as well as for the improvement of the tools available to the national agencies.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: -  Mister President! This is my first speech in the House, which is a particularly great honor for me. I am delighted to be able to give this speech on the Erasmus + program. As a young person I know many EU citizens who benefit from it. The program makes an unbeatable contribution to the growing together in the European Union, especially by opening up to vocational training. The report highlights the enormous importance of Erasmus +. Erasmus makes an important contribution to vocational training, especially in border regions. We should further strengthen the program in this area and also make it possible for trainees who go back to their home country during the week to receive funding and funding. This applies, for example, in the area of ​​care. The promotion of Europe's youth is an important contribution to the future of the European Union and allows us to grow closer together. That is why this program is so important.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I support this report and I will be happy to vote on it.I worked and met a lot of young people who went through this project.Erasmus + is a step forward.Although the visibility of the program has increased, personally, I think that it still needs to be improved and access should be simplified, especially.Absorption capacity exists in Europe, but there is a need for increased funding, given the demands of young people, especially in Eastern countries.Mr President, please adjourn the meeting.I do not think that this is how an intervention can take place in the plenary of the Parliament.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Please, ladies and gentlemen, be quiet.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, we believe that there is a permanent rapporteur for Erasmus, as well as the mid-term evaluation, and I hope that the evaluation will be followed by measures as well.As other colleagues have mentioned, there are still problems to be solved and I believe, Commissioner, that it is a pity to reject projects that are good, you yourself have confirmed this.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: - Mr President, I will refer to the subject on the agenda, I am referring here to Erasmus +, which is celebrating its 30th anniversary this year and, as my predecessors said, has already helped millions of young people and education professionals. But by 2020, Erasmus + needs to support another two million higher education students. 650,000 young people in vocational training, 500 thousand volunteers and young people in exchange for experience, 800 thousand lecturers, teacher educators, but, nevertheless, only 7% of young Europeans can benefit from this opportunity today. With 17 billion out of a total of one trillion euros as we have the European budget for the period 2014-2020 is too little to meet the objectives of such a program. Therefore, we need to ensure that Erasmus + is properly funded and implemented in such a way that the participation rate is higher. There are many things that can be done by reducing co-financing, recognizing volunteer hours as co-financing in projects, better framing participants or project sustainability. I believe that together the European Parliament and the Commission can do more to make this program more effective.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for their participation and remarks in the debate. Both the critical and the supportive remarks are very useful to us in building up the project for the years to come and the upcoming multiannual financial framework.  Indeed, the Erasmus programme, which started its career 30 years ago as a student mobility programme, transformed into a very complex programme with higher education aspects. It is no longer only about student mobility, but strategic alliances among higher education institutions, the exchange of ideas and best practices, and a strong and institutionalised cooperation among higher education institutions. It has a chapter on volunteering which can be very useful for young Europeans to gain experience and skills in volunteering which can be used on the labour market. We have some funding programmes for sports, especially for grassroots sports, and we have projects in youth policy as well. This means that Erasmus+ is today much more than a student mobility programme. It is a complex programme for the future because it not only helps young people to find their own place in today’s and tomorrow’s societies, but it also helps them to develop a complementary European identity which is not antagonistic to local, regional or national identities, but complements them. It adds to their personality and thereby hopefully helps European integration in this very critical period.  There is, of course, a lot of room for improvement. That is why I thanked you for all the remarks which raised the issue of funding. The structure of the Erasmus+ budget is an incremental one, which means that from 2017 until 2020, there is a 10% increase in the budget, which means wider opportunities in the future. I thank you for all the critical remarks on the administrative burden. We are working on simplifying procedures and IT solutions. I understood Mr Jakovčić’s remarks on possible synergies. Together with local authorities or regional authorities, I think that could be a good opportunity for broadening the social and geographical appeal of Erasmus+ in the next period of the lifespan of that programme. All in all, Erasmus+ is a success story. We have to protect all the achievements and to improve the structure and the outcomes of Erasmus+. That is why we offer some additional policy instruments aimed at helping young people to use the best opportunities in Erasmus+, for instance the student loan or the apprenticeship and traineeship programmes in Erasmus+. In the future we would like to broaden its social appeal and we would like to make it more available for those people who come from social circumstances and a social environment which are not so fortunate.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Rapporteur. - Thank you all for a good debate on Erasmus +. Let me emphasize at the end that we have an implementation report in front of us and that we cannot radically change the situation with it. However, we can gradually improve them step by step, and the European Commission will prepare an interim report later this year and will be able to rectify any shortcomings on the basis of its own findings. The new European Erasmus + program therefore enjoys the kind support of all the European institutions, and Parliament in particular, and I have no doubt that tomorrow's vote will be positive. So in this short period of his life, we, Erasmus +, of course, have greatly increased his budget and eliminated some technical problems, such as ... such as simplification of application procedures, easier access to smaller organizations in programs. Cross-sectoral cooperation has improved, greater decentralization in the operation of the program has been introduced, and the positive responses of participants in the program and the increase in interest in participating in it are particularly important. Therefore, it will be necessary to continue to close the gap between the limited budgetary capacity and the broad potential of the program in the future. Finally, let me conclude by acknowledging that, in reality, Erasmus + is gaining in importance and that it represents invaluable added value for the future development of the European Union in personal, social and economic terms.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - Many EU citizens see the European Union's Erasmus + program in education, training, youth and sport as an important tool for supporting activities in the fields of education, training, youth and sport and see it as a successful example of European integration. Regarding the visibility of the program, two conclusions are drawn. On the one hand, merging the different programs into a single program has increased the visibility of EU support, which has led to greater public and political attention. On the other hand, many stakeholders are critical of the fact that, due to the overall complexity of the program, the various sectors are now not sufficiently visible. The goal of simplification has largely been achieved through the introduction of a number of new tools, such as digital solutions for the application process and project management. A number of stakeholders also welcome the introduction of a unit price system, which has simplified the financial management of the program. However, the first two and a half years of implementation were undoubtedly difficult and difficult. So far, the Commission has improved its implementation arrangements and continues to implement actions. But for the program to be truly successful, much remains to be done.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague Milan Zver on his report. This year, the 30-year mobility program has so far enabled more than 3 million students to study at a foreign university. The European Parliament will continue to support this great mobility program so that as many young people as possible can take part in it and, in addition to knowledge, gain cultural experiences, experiences and new skills. Multilingualism is important for improving the labor market opportunities of young people, so more Erasmus + projects are needed within the Erasmus + program, which provide opportunities for language learning and multilingual communication. The main attraction of Erasmus + is that young people who have experience in foreign universities and institutions are enriched with skills and knowledge that are a plus for them in the labor market or when starting a business. I believe that the program should also give priority to and support language learning in minority languages. It is difficult for almost all regional and minority language communities to ensure the survival and development of their languages. The Erasmus + program should support all students, regardless of whether they belong to the majority or national minority community. Linguistic mobility means not only that people belonging to a minority community learn the language of those belonging to the majority community, but vice versa, enabling those belonging to the majority community to cultivate closer links with minority language communities and a better understanding of their culture.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - Over 9 million direct participants and millions of other indirect beneficiaries - this is a satisfactory balance for the student mobility project launched in 1987. The 30th anniversary of the Erasmus program also coincides with the 60th anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Erasmus. in Rome, which promotes an ever closer union in Europe. This platform for mobility and European and international cooperation has provided and continues to offer the opportunity for people from different backgrounds to come together, acquire the skills needed to have a full and independent life, find their place in society and develop a sense of belonging. of European identity. Unfortunately, there are still a number of barriers to access to the program for low-income or rural students, people with special needs and people from disadvantaged backgrounds, which need to be removed through the joint efforts of all Member States. .

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Honorable Members! Erasmus +, now 30 years old, builds on the foundations of EU programs in the 1980s and 1990s, such as Socrates or Leonardo da Vinci. Erasmus + is the largest budget of its kind in European history. So far, more than 3 million students have had the opportunity to study abroad. What is particularly gratifying is that this is the first time that the EU has supported sport in this form, which I also consider to be particularly important for maintaining good health. The million participant numbers speak for themselves. According to surveys, young people who have also studied abroad are much more likely to apply for a later job. This is very important in view of the very high levels of youth unemployment in many Member States. Hopefully, Erasmus + will continue to be so successful in the years to come, and many more young people will be enriched by experience abroad, which can be of great benefit later on.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. - As a Polish MEP, I would like to refer to the report on the implementation of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing Erasmus +, the EU program for education, training, youth and sport. Launched in 2014, Erasmus + brought together several smaller programs in the field of education, training and youth and, for the first time, included the sport sector as a new field of support. It is currently the main vehicle for supporting activities in the fields of education, training, youth and sport and should be positively assessed and implemented as such. Unfortunately, the shape of the report on the implementation of the Erasmus + program, containing recommendations for its further development, forced me to refrain from voting. The rapporteur omits the problematic aspects of the program, as well as the proposals for their correction, even though they are constantly indicated by the stakeholders themselves, i.e. the academic community. Moreover, the presentation of the mobility as the main goal of the program in the report, and the neglect of its true goal of improving the quality of education, makes Erasmus + a consumer-oriented program. The rapporteur's move towards the so-called soft skills, and not promoting the acquisition of real knowledge so far. Summing up, I personally assess the Erasmus + framework program as extremely valuable and I will support its implementation, however, the shape of the report, its assumptions and the attempt to smuggle in many polemical expressions into it aroused my concern.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. - The Erasmus program is one of the best recognized and positively assessed EU programs. The 30th anniversary of its inception is a good occasion not only to celebrate, but also to reflect more broadly on how to make it even better and how other policies and initiatives can benefit from this success story. The budget increase for this year by over 12% is a good decision. I believe that only sufficient resources will ensure the inclusive approach so necessary for the success of this program. It is also important to fully use the potential of not only student exchanges, but also all other elements of the program, because Erasmus + is also a staff exchange or university cooperation, which is not always equally visible. With the new financial perspective, new elements were also introduced into the program, but their visibility still needs to be strengthened. The Erasmus program has had clear, tangible results, and this has largely determined its success. I agree with the rapporteur that in order to maintain this trend, the program should be transparent, only changing what needs to be simplified and which will facilitate the use of the program by beneficiaries. Individual goals should, however, maintain their own separate budget, which will facilitate their implementation and enhance effectiveness. I believe that many of these principles can also apply to other EU programs.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - The Erasmus Plus program plays a key role in strengthening European identity and integration. It contributes to the quality of education. He has a high success rate. According to statistics, graduates of this program have a much better chance of getting a job. At the same time, it is an important element in the field of mobility, education and training of young people and lifelong learning. It is necessary to focus this project more on high school youth. At the same time, there is a need to simplify the rules, ensure clarity and interpretation of the terms, use flat-rate financing and reduce payment deadlines, which are often a problem for smaller organizations to get involved in projects. It is about supporting teachers, students, the program supports sports organizations. Provides flexible language support on the Internet. Every tenth participant in the project comes from a disadvantaged background or has special needs. The program has many more applicants than we can cover. That is why we need to ask for a further increase in funding.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - In 30 years of activity, the Erasmus program has contributed to enriching the lives of many young Europeans, improving their skills and abilities, opening "windows" to new cultures, encouraging their participation in democratic life, in their own countries and beyond, concretely increasing their employment opportunities. To date, around 4 million children and young people, and as many as 125 000 institutions have benefited from this program. More than two million university students, 500,000 volunteers, 800,000 educators, 650,000 trainees have decided to implement part of their training abroad. These numbers confirm the importance of the program. The report on the implementation of ERASMUS + recognizes its great potential and, precisely in the light of these, the need to provide for a wide possibility of access, to solve the issues related to the decentralization of the financing of key actions, to involve stakeholders and beneficiaries in the meetings of the ERASMUS + program committee. Investing in training and education and supporting transnational mobility, for study or work reasons, can and must be the way to go to, at the same time, support the growth of the real economy and employment; counteract the dangerous spread of feelings of intolerance and social exclusion and promote a sense of common European citizenship.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: in writing.- Erasmus + is one of the most successful programs in the EU, so there is no doubt that it needs to be continued, developed and improved.Importantly, the integration of all education and training and youth programs has not only increased the visibility of the program, but has also contributed to the development of young people's European identity, the formation of a conscious relationship with Europe and cultural dialogue.In view of the positive aspects of this program, I would suggest avoiding hasty structural restructuring, but we must improve the financial mechanisms and cut red tape.Particular attention must be paid to those whose insufficient personal financial resources create barriers to accessing the program.I share the need to increase funding for Erasmus + and to ensure financial transparency and efficiency.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The initial concept of the Erasmus + program and its complexity have forced it to become more effective for the benefit of those who use it.This approach allows for cooperation between the different sectors of the program and the education sectors that Erasmus + opens up to young people and those who wish to benefit from it.In addition, we are working to eliminate the injustices that can occur when selecting candidates and to simplify the existing tools of this program instead of adding more.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: written.- We have just celebrated the 30th anniversary of the Erasmus program.The Erasmus program stands like no other initiative for the growing together of the young European generation.With the program we reached over 10 million young people.This makes it the most successful European educational program.I am sure that we can reach even more young people in the future.But the latest news that money from Erasmus + will be spent on the Free Interrail idea is pointing in the wrong direction.Erasmus + is characterized by the fact that it pursues sustainable educational goals and training goals.The Interrail idea is not at all suitable for addressing young people from socially disadvantaged families in particular and offering them prospects for a good education.So I ask you to invest the EU money more sensibly in expanding the existing Erasmus + programs.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- Erasmus + is one of the European Union's most successful programs and, in addition to skills, employability and reducing the risk of long-term unemployment among young Europeans, also encourages active citizenship and social inclusion of young people.These are all the more important values we need to build on today, when the European Union is facing the biggest crisis since its inception, as reflected in the decline in citizens' trust in the EU.I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal, which proposed an increase of EUR 200 million by the end of the current multiannual financial framework.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. - Under the current Treaty, the Union's competences in the field of education and training are still limited to "encouraging, encouraging and, where necessary, complementing" cooperation between Member States, and Member States have sole responsibility for all matters affecting their national education and training systems. However, the disparity in quality between Member States is widening the gap, which the EU cannot continue to look at with its hands folded. The current quality, effectiveness and efficiency of education and training are not only the key elements of strengthening economic competitiveness and growth potential, but also one of the most important keys to increasing prosperity, preserving and re-creating social cohesion. Therefore, education must be a high priority for the European Union. The Erasmus + program should be extended to those in secondary education and vocational training, and its resources should be substantially increased.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - I consider the report on the implementation of the Erasmus + program crucial both from the perspective of reviewing the implementation of the program over the last two and a half years since its establishment, as well as from the perspective of making recommendations for its further implementation. I would also like to point out that the conclusions drawn by the rapporteur and other members of the Committee on Culture and Education should provide valuable background material for the European Commission when preparing the mid-term evaluation report of the program expected at the end of 2017. As budget rapporteur for the EP Committee on Culture and Education for 2016 and 2017, I would like to pay particular attention to the aspects related to the funding of Erasmus +. The budget of the program was significantly increased compared to its previous edition. This year's 40% increase is a signal that the political and economic value of the program has been recognized. Recognizing and appreciating the actions taken so far to improve the implementation measures of the program implementation process, I would like to emphasize that it is necessary to constantly monitor the effectiveness of its financial management in order to maintain the high level of program effectiveness and the undeniable name of one of the flagship successes of European integration.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Next on the agenda is the debate on the report by Hannu Takkula, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on an integrated approach to sport policy: good governance, accessibility and integrity (2016/2143 (INI)) (A8-0381 / 2016)

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: demonstrator. - (FI) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, lack of exercise is the fourth most common cause of death, according to the World Health Organization. We also need to move more in Europe. Sports policy deserves cross-sectoral reflection and more resources. The European Union has had competence in the field of sport for seven years now. My report assesses these developments and is the only one in the current parliamentary term that deals exclusively with sport. It contains the European Parliament's policy recommendations to the Member States, sports organizations and the Commission, which will carry out a mid-term review of the European Union's sports policy this spring. Concrete proposals include measures to increase physical activity, such as a proposal for a VAT reduction and other financial incentives for grassroots sport. In particular, we want to emphasize that at the grassroots level, people across Europe can move. That's where the foundation is. The report also highlights the broad economic importance of sport for society. The sports sector is growing faster than the rest of the economy, already employing around 3% and a half of European Union citizens. Other sectors in Europe could also learn from this boost in the sports sector. Exercise improves public health and thus also has a positive effect on the age structure. This has a direct link with the economies of the Member States affected by the age structure. Sport is also a fundamental right of every human being. It also helps to better integrate into society. Therefore, sports and sports services must be equally accessible to all, including people with disabilities, immigrants, young people and the elderly. Accessibility of sport is an issue that needs to be more clearly reflected in the European Union's sports policy. The Erasmus + program we just discussed is a great program and a success story, but it also needs further investment. specifically for sport. We certainly all also know that there have been nasty cases of corruption and doping in organized sport, which have tarnished the reputation of the sport. This report calls for zero tolerance for corruption in sport and makes proposals for the development of good governance in sports organizations, which often receive public support. The governance and cash flows of sports organizations must be transparent. We also emphasize ensuring the integrity of sport and measures to that end, such as the fight against match-fixing and doping. These are problems that tarnish the international reputation of sport, in which the European Union and its Member States also have an important role to play. Finally, I would like to express the hope that the European Commission will take the proposals in this report into account in the mid-term review of sport policy. As there are many proposals, monitoring should continue beyond this spring. It is also important to monitor the implementation of the proposals in the Member States and in sports organizations. That is why we are making these programs, not just on a shelf in a folder, but that they would come into practice and that they would also be implemented in the various Member States and sports organizations. I therefore propose that we hold an annual follow-up meeting to the proposals in this sports report here in the European Parliament, in cooperation with the European Commission, the Council and stakeholders. In this way, we can ensure that this broadly consolidated position of the European Parliament on sport can become a living and working reality in practice in all the Member States of the European Union. Thank you.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague Takkula for presenting this report. I particularly welcome the proposals to increase the accessibility of sport for all sections of the population. As he himself mentioned, lack of physical activity is the fourth most common cause of death in the world, and according to the same organization, a third of children between the ages of six and nine in the European Union were obese in 2010. This is, I think, quite alarming news. Of course: physical activity, support for physical education and sport are essential conditions for us to do something about this negative development as well. I agree that it is primarily the Member States that are responsible for promoting sport, but at European level we are sending a signal that the European Union supports sporting activities as a tool against the development of social pathological phenomena, in combating these phenomena and also to improve health status of the population.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I welcome the call for an integrated policy in sport adopted by this report, which addresses a broad range of issues, such as the challenges linked to racism and homophobia, the social aspects of sport and the need to ensure inclusive access, including for people with disabilities, the contribution of sport to wellbeing and health – notably mental health, and the need to strongly combat unethical practices such as match fixing, corruption and doping. Integrity is a vital component of sport. We must restore trust in sporting institutions and re-establish the values of solidarity, peace and social inclusion that sport can engender. The EU should pay particular attention to the issue of human rights in sport. The circumstances surrounding the preparation of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar are deeply regrettable. It is estimated that 4000 people might die before the first ball is even kicked. The EU must condemn the abuses that have been taking place. Sport must remain a vehicle for promoting human rights, not a justification for breaching them.  Finally, I’d like to address the issue of gender equality in sport and the fair representation of women in governing bodies: having more women in sport decision—making would have a positive outcome, not only on the transparency and accountability of sports organisations and access to sports activities for women, but might also counter the poor media coverage given to women’s sport and the socially discriminating and sexually stereotyped reporting found in the media.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, sport is a large and rapidly growing sector of the economy of the Member States of the Union and contributes significantly to growth and employment, while also playing an important role in the lives of European citizens. However, the image of sport is often tarnished. either through hooliganism and violence that discourage fans from attending sporting events, or through ever-increasing doping cases that violate the ethical values ​​and principles of sport. At the same time, various pan-European professional sports federations are state-by-state, enforcing coercive heterogeneity and have become ad hoc monopolies that violate competition rules in the European Union and abuse their dominant position in the European sports market. There should be zero tolerance for corruption in sport, and the World Anti-Doping Agency should take more steps to crack down on doping itself worldwide.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I would certainly like to support the report of my esteemed colleague Takkula, in all those elements when we talk about the importance of sports, the impact of sports, especially on the younger population, but also on the older ones, even on those a little fuller like me. example. I would like, however, to give two dimensions. The dimension of those countries such as, say, Croatia, from which I come, which has very large and successful results. A very small country, top athletes in football, basketball, water polo and handball, I am all the world's top. Big problems in the construction of sports facilities and sports infrastructure. In small towns, in small towns, we need to really enable the financing of sports infrastructure, because without that, of course, there is no active sport. Many countries, especially those that are poorer, have big problems with this. On the other hand, I want to emphasize the dimension of tourism and sports, where we can really find many links, and I also call on the Commission to seriously consider how to develop a program for financing tourism and sports infrastructure through tourism.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr Chairman! I congratulate Mr Takkula for this important report at a time when the reputation of sport, the image of sports federations, is severely damaged. The European Parliament must send a strong political signal to the federations, unions, athletes and fans that the principle of fair play applies not only on the pitch, but also in sport management. The key is good governance in sports federations, which are at the top of the European sport model. Recent scandals have shown that profound changes and reforms are needed. Efforts should also be made to prevent criminal activities that pose a threat to sport: doping, trafficking in human beings or the exploitation of minors. I would also like to call on the Maltese Presidency to take action to sign and ratify the Council of Europe's Match-Fixing Convention. As a former athlete, I particularly appreciate the support in the report of effective dual career systems and access to further education and mobility for athletes.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all congratulations to my colleague on an excellent report. Increasing attention to individual physical well-being also increases the need for policies that take sport into account, beyond its professional dimension. Sporting activity is widely perceived as a fundamental right and everyone, including the most socially vulnerable groups, such as the elderly, migrants and people with disabilities, must have the same opportunities to access it. Europe is forced to face serious social challenges and needs to protect and strengthen every tool capable of generating inclusion, tolerance and positive confrontation. The priority, therefore, must be to direct resources towards sporting activities that produce cohesion, that are sustainable and that effectively bring value to the places that host them. We certainly cannot forget the economic and symbolic value of major sporting events, but I believe that only with investments aimed at guaranteeing everyone the right to sport will we really respond to the needs of European citizens.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Thank you President. Honourable Members of the European Parliament, we normally see sport as a vehicle for our health and well—being, but sport is more: it mirrors the values that our societies are built on, and in today’s polarised world, sport is also a tool for building bridges. Since the European Parliament’s report by Santiago Fisas Ayxela back in 2011, the way in which sport is organised, watched, televised or gambled on has changed. This has important implications for the amount of money flowing into sport and sporting events, more specifically, and how this money is distributed. What is more, sport has never been as closely scrutinised as it is today, either through technology, social media or investigative journalism, and this has uncovered some home truths about sport. This is why this report is welcome. We have to readjust our focus to take recent developments into account. Mr Takkula, you and your shadow rapporteurs have gone to great lengths to recognise all these aspects precisely at a time when the topic of integrity is a top priority for the global sports movement and the public alike. Let me assure you that the Commission will continue its work to protect the integrity of sport. We strongly support the call to find a solution to unblock the signing and ratification of the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions. It is important that the EU and the Member States who wish to participate can play a strong part in implementing the Convention from the very beginning. Good governance should be embedded within the culture of sport, become part of its DNA, so that sport can continue to inspire us all. This is paramount not only to safeguard the integrity of sport and its credibility, but also to help sports organisations to do their work more effectively. That is why I launched an initiative in September last year inviting sports federations to sign up to, and put in practice, good governance principles. Some have done so, but this can only be a first step. I will continue to urge all sports federations in the EU to stand up and be counted.  Your report also rightly highlights the importance that needs to be attached to accessibility. I fully support this focus and the call to ensure the sport is accessible to everyone. The Commission is committed to helping to ensure that persons with a disability can participate in sport activities. The Commission proposal for a directive harmonising accessibility in the EU – the so-called European accessibility Act – will also contribute to this goal. Sport can play a vital role in fostering social inclusion and help us build inclusive societies. It can provide positive role models to young people. It can make an important contribution to help integrate migrants in the EU. In fact, sport has the potential, matched by few other areas, to promote values such as tolerance, solidarity, respect and understanding between nations and cultures both within Europe and beyond.  The report also highlights the economic impact of sport, as well as its potential for providing young people with opportunities to develop skills – skills that enable them to find fulfilling work and become independent active citizens. This is of great importance to the Commission. Sport faces many challenges. To tackle them, we must all work together: sports organisations, the Commission, Member States and civil society. And we have to work across policy areas. We will continue to use all our instruments to support and encourage Member States and sport bodies. The sport chapter of Erasmus+ can play a key role here. Indeed, the report suggests actions in many areas that we are already supporting through Erasmus+. These include promoting grassroots sport, fighting match-fixing, fostering social inclusion, protecting young athletes and helping to preserve traditional sports.  The report also comes at a time when Member States and the Council are discussing new priorities for their cooperation in this field and the structure of the next EU work plan for sport. Your report will provide valuable input to these discussions. To conclude, this report identifies the same challenges and priorities that the Commission is working on. I am very pleased to see that the European Parliament is a strong ally supporting our work. I therefore very much welcome this initiative, and wish to thank Mr Takkula, in particular, for his commitment.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulations)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This report is a "catch-all" text attempting to cover all aspects of sport. There are some good ideas there, in particular concerning the fight against doping or corruption. Moreover, in committee, I tried to flesh out these proposals by recalling the new challenge of technological doping, or by emphasizing the dangers represented by the communitarianism present in certain sports associations at the local level. While I welcome certain measures in the report, such as the fight against human beings, particularly underage athletes, I regret that the text does not go far enough in other areas. Indeed, the rapporteur affirms the need to ensure the security of sporting events without jeopardizing terrorism and the security challenges to be met. Furthermore, I believe it is urgent to ensure the social, economic and ecological sustainability of these major events, their immediate economic interest not having to supplant the viability of the territories. Finally, I regret that this text on sport has been transformed into an ideological tool in favor of the integration of migrants, to the detriment, for example, of improving accessibility to sports facilities for disabled athletes.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I support the common European sport policy.Sport is more than just a leisure activity or competitive sport.Sport is a means of integrating people across cultural, ethnic, social and national barriers. That is why I welcome international sporting events and initiatives that enable refugees, migrants and asylum seekers to actively participate in sporting competitions.An important requirement of the report is a zero-tolerance policy against corruption in sport.In this context, I support the call for more responsible administration and greater transparency.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - Sport plays a key role in the lives of millions of EU citizens, and the right to sport and physical activity is a fundamental right. The beneficial effects of exercise are undeniable: it results in a better quality of life, helps prevent disease, supports active aging and has a positive impact on society as a whole, as it transcends origin, religion, promotes inclusion, cohesion, integration, promotes mutual respect and understanding between different cultures. I would like to draw attention to two important points. Firstly, in order to preserve the credibility and attractiveness of sport, it is essential to ensure the purity, integrity and transparency of sport, all the more so as more and more money is circulating in the sports sector, in the field of competitive sport, sport has become an economic activity. Corruption and the use of illegal performance enhancers and drugs are areas that need to be tackled through international efforts and cooperation. In addition, the mobility of elite athletes should be supported so that they can successfully find a job at the end of their careers. Competitive sports mean long hours of daily training, with athletes fighting for and sacrificing results every day. It is important that when their sports careers come to an end, they can find a place in other areas of the labor market. Their efforts in this direction must therefore be actively supported.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. - Sport is not only about competition and fans' emotions. Sport is also a huge educational potential. That is why we must eliminate all forms of corruption, doping and unfair practices from sport, so as not to lose this important educational role of sport. Sport can also help to shape pro-social attitudes and fight against contemporary challenges such as radicalization and xenophobia. Sport is also of great importance in the process of social inclusion of disadvantaged groups and people with disabilities. Therefore, educational projects are needed to promote equal opportunities, fair competition and practices in sport, referring to ancient models of harmonious development of mind and body. The Erasmus + program that we have just discussed is an important tool in the Union's sport policy with which we can support anti-doping projects and good governance in sport. An important element of it should also be the improvement of the two-track career system in order to ensure the future of athletes after the end of their sports career.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Article 165 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union offers the European Union new competences for sports, contributes to the promotion of sport issues and provides for EU actions aimed at developing the European dimension in sport. The report highlights the main issues in sports that still need to be addressed, such as the value of sport, fairness of sporting competitions, opportunities and jobs, tourism, traditional sports and games, training, mobility and zero tolerance for corruption in sports. This report states that Erasmus+ continues to be the most effective tool in EU sports policy while calling for more funds to be allocated to sports under the programme. It is important for sports to provide a positive and sustainable legacy in sport events while also enhancing cohesion, tourism and local businesses in the organising cities and countries.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while we are having this debate in Romania, more than 300,000 people are protesting in the streets, in the cold, against an emergency ordinance adopted last night by the Romanian Government, which makes essential changes. to the Criminal Code, amendments that decriminalize abuse of office. This ordinance will lead to the cessation of several ongoing investigations, will benefit many politicians accused of corruption, including the President of the Romanian Parliament. Corrupt politicians want to affect the judiciary, which has begun to function in Romania. It is the biggest blow to justice in Romania since the fall of communism, twenty-seven years ago. What to do? I call on all international partners to put pressure on the Romanian Government so that these changes adopted last night do not enter into force within the deadline set in ten days. Why is it important for Europe to be with the people of Romania now? Because the citizens of Romania are waiting for the European Union to defend them in the fight against corrupt politicians. The support that the European Union will enjoy in Romania in the future depends directly on the support that Europe will give these days to the Romanian people.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, I was preparing to talk about the MCV Report - ten years for Romania and, of course, on behalf of the citizens, I would like to ask the Commission, after ten years, finally for this report to be lifted given that there are no criteria to compare the results of cross-border justice in the European Union. Obviously, the events in Romania force me to raise this issue as well, but I will raise it through what the professional associations of judges in Romania say, namely they signaled that through the intervention of the country's president at the CSAT level the intelligence services received the endorsement to I intervened illegally in the criminal investigation act and I also want to quote from the statement of a SCM judge: "the untimely presence of the country's president at today's SCM meeting is an obvious intolerable interference in the activity of justice". So I am glad that there will be a plenary debate tomorrow and we have requested a debate in the LIBE Committee and at our home to see what the situation really is.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, extraordinary circumstances have forced me to change my statement, and these extraordinary circumstances are an extremely aggressive and brazen provocation that we have witnessed in recent hours, namely the announcement on Turkish pages and websites of the flag of the Bulgarian Turks. This flag is very reminiscent of the Turkish flag in occupied Cyprus, occupied by the Turkish army. These actions of the Turkish state are extremely disturbing because they are a request for separatism and are a threat to the territorial integrity and integrity of the Bulgarian state and the Bulgarian statehood. We will not allow such an intervention, similar to the one in Cyprus. And I want to strongly object here to the actions of the Turkish administration and the candidate for a new Turkish sultan, namely Mr Erdogan. I state clearly that the proclamation of flags of any Bulgarian community is completely unacceptable and we will not allow any threat to be imposed on the territorial integrity and national sovereignty of the Republic of Bulgaria.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, in June 2016, I and a poultry producer complained to the European Commission about the abuse of the flat-rate VAT scheme in Ireland. Despite new legislation being passed, we still have delays and hold—ups with no serious attempt to counter this abuse. Yet, one year ago, emails between Irish Revenue and Finance explicitly showed knowledge of this abuse: in one of these emails, it states ‘abuse of flat-rate addition happening in certain sectors’. Examples include avoidance in the poultry industry, where the price of poultry feed is artificially inflated by the processor, who contracts with the farmer to rear poultry, resulting in an inflated amount of flat—rate VAT addition, etc. This is been happening in some cases since 2004, and yet it continues. So what does this say to VAT-compliant farmers and processors? What does this mean for other agricultural sectors that have to compete? And finally, in the same week that Commissioner Vestager was in Dublin speaking about illegal staid aid to Apple, is this illegal state aid to the poultry sector?

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Mr. President, the measures announced by Mr. Trump, such as the veto of Muslims, the construction of the wall with Mexico or his declarations on torture are in direct conflict with human rights and it is important to give a strong response, but without hypocrisy.We are glad that today they are raising their voices against Trump who kept silent when Obama deported almost three million people, who said nothing about the torture in Guantánamo or who seem not to know that the wall was started by Mr. Bill Clinton.Now the situation with Trump is much worse, but we might not have gotten this far if he hadn't shut up then.And there are also those who try to take advantage of Trump's brutalities to hide his shame, like Mr. Rajoy, saying that he is not in favor of vetoes or borders.It would not be bad for Mr. Rajoy to go around Ceuta and Melilla.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: - Mr President, last week the President of Catalonia explained in this Parliament the determination of his Government that in Catalonia we vote on our political future no later than this September. We will do it through an independence referendum. A referendum that if agreed with the Spanish State will be held and, if not, also. Because we have a democratic mandate that we do not plan to renounce and we will do so in a legal, legitimate, democratic and peaceful way, as things are done in Europe. While some seek to intimidate the democratic path, threatening to seal off the polling stations and take our politicians to court, we remain unfazed on the path of democracy.
